prompt: According to recent news, the demand for solar installations is expected to continue growing in 2018, with China being the key driver behind this growth. The country has successfully diversified its market and achieved strong momentum in the distributed generation segment. However, there are uncertainties in other leading PV markets, such as the U.S. and India, due to pending decisions on trade cases and anti-dumping duties.  In terms of polysilicon supply, there is currently a global polysilicon factory boom underway, with both new and existing players planning to add a total of 167kT of new capacity by the end of 2018. This increase in supply is expected to result in a 10% increase in production in 2018, reaching around 490,000 tons. This would be enough to meet the demand for 118 GW of crystalline silicon PV modules.  Despite the increase in supply, module prices are expected to drop to as low as US$0.30/W for market leaders. However, there is limited movement expected in polysilicon prices in the first half of 2018, with market leaders anticipating prices of around $0.33/W (based on 10% gross margin) in H1 and $0.30/W by mid-year.  In terms of government support, India has proposed a capital subsidy for new polysilicon manufacturing facilities and upgrades. This subsidy would provide a 30% capital subsidy for setting up and/or upgrading domestic manufacturing capacities. Additionally, manufacturers setting up new capacities of polysilicon, wafer, and cells would be eligible for an interest subvention of 3% on loans taken through nationalized banks. The government has also proposed exempting capital goods required for setting up solar manufacturing facilities from customs duties.  Overall, the news suggests that the polysilicon market is expected to stabilize in 2018, with increased supply and improved cost-efficiencies. However, the demand for solar installations, particularly in China, will continue to drive the market. It is important for companies to closely monitor trade cases, anti-dumping duties, and government policies, as these factors can have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices./n

Based on the news articles, there are several factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.   Firstly, the Indian government has proposed capital subsidies and interest subventions for manufacturers setting up new capacities of polysilicon, wafer, and cells. This could lead to an increase in domestic manufacturing capacities in India and potentially impact the global supply and demand dynamics of polysilicon.  Secondly, there are predictions of trade wars affecting the market and the possibility of a price war between companies. This could lead to increased competition and potentially lower prices for polysilicon.  Thirdly, there are geopolitical conflicts and government subsidies that could impact the polysilicon market. For example, the Chinese government has expressed interest in acquiring bankrupt PV cell and module producer Suniva, which could have implications for the global polysilicon market.  Additionally, there are technological advancements such as the use of diamond and black silicon, as well as the rise of monosilicon and half-cut cells, which could drive down costs and potentially impact polysilicon prices.  Overall, the news suggests that there are several factors at play that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. It is important for strategic experts to closely monitor these developments and make informed decisions based on the minor details and trends in the news./n

According to the news, the polysilicon market is expected to experience a boom in the coming months. China, in particular, is predicted to be a key driver of this growth, as the country has successfully diversified its market and achieved strong momentum in the distributed generation segment. The demand for solar installations is expected to reach 108 GW by the end of 2018, with further growth projected for 2019.  One significant factor contributing to this growth is the increase in polysilicon production capacity. Both new and existing players are investing in new factories, with a total of 167kT of new capacity planned by the end of 2018. This increase in supply is expected to result in a 10% increase in overall supply in 2018, reaching around 490,000 tons of polysilicon. This will be enough to meet the demand for 118 GW of crystalline silicon PV modules.  Despite the increase in supply, module prices are expected to drop, with market leaders potentially seeing prices as low as US$0.30/W. However, there is limited movement expected in polysilicon prices in the first half of 2018, with market leaders likely to see prices around $0.33/W. By mid-year, prices are expected to drop to $0.30/W.  In addition to the increase in production capacity, government subsidies and policies are also expected to have an impact on polysilicon prices. In India, for example, the government has proposed a capital subsidy for new facilities and upgrades, as well as an interest subvention for manufacturers setting up new capacities. The government has also proposed exemptions from customs duties for capital goods required for setting up solar manufacturing facilities.  Overall, the news suggests that the polysilicon market is set to experience growth in the coming months, driven by increased production capacity and government support. While module prices are expected to drop, the impact on polysilicon prices may be limited in the short term. However, the increase in supply and government subsidies could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices./n

According to the news, the polysilicon market is expected to stabilize in 2018, with increased demand from China driving growth in the solar industry. The demand for solar installations is predicted to reach 108 GW by the end of the year, with China leading the way in diversifying its market and achieving strong momentum in distributed generation. However, there are uncertainties in other PV markets, such as the US awaiting a decision on the section 201 case and India considering anti-dumping duties.  The news also highlights a global polysilicon factory boom, with both new and existing players planning to add a total of 167kT of new capacity by the end of 2018. This includes established players like Korea's OCI and new entrants like China-based East Hope. Overall, the supply of polysilicon is expected to increase by 10% in 2018, reaching around 490,000 tons, enough for 118 GW of crystalline silicon PV modules.  Module prices are expected to drop to as low as US$0.30/W for market leaders, with limited movement on polysilicon prices in the first half of 2018. The report suggests that market leaders can expect H1 prices of around $0.33/W (based on 10% gross margin) and $0.30/W by mid-year.  In terms of trends, the news mentions that trade wars, diamond and black silicon technologies, and the mainstream adoption of PERC and half-cut modules will shape the market in 2018. Additionally, the inverter landscape is expected to be influenced by Chinese dominance, the evolution of growth strategies, modular design, and the threat of component shortages.  Overall, the news highlights the strong growth of the solar PV industry, particularly in China, and the increasing capacity of polysilicon production. The stabilization of polysilicon prices and the adoption of new technologies are expected to drive the market in the coming months./n

Based on the news provided, there are several factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices.   Firstly, it is worth noting that China has built up its own polysilicon production, which could potentially impact the global PV market. This suggests that China may become less reliant on importing polysilicon, which could lead to a decrease in demand and potentially lower prices.  Secondly, there is news of a price war between companies in the PV market. This could indicate that companies are competing to offer lower prices for polysilicon, which could drive down prices in the future.  Additionally, government subsidies play a role in the PV market. The European Union, for example, is providing a significant grant for energy infrastructure, which could potentially lead to increased demand for polysilicon and higher prices.  Geopolitical conflicts also have the potential to impact polysilicon prices. South Korea, for instance, has requested consultations with the US government over solar import tariffs. If these conflicts escalate, it could lead to trade disruptions and potentially affect the supply and demand dynamics of polysilicon.  Overall, the news suggests that there are several factors that could influence future polysilicon prices, including the development of China's own production, price wars between companies, government subsidies, and geopolitical conflicts. It is important to closely monitor these factors to make informed strategic decisions in the polysilicon market./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. Firstly, there is a new polysilicon factory boom underway, with production forecasted to increase from 445,600 metric tons in 2017 to 490,000 tons in 2018. This growth in demand is mainly due to temporary scarcity of metallurgical silicon feedstock and scheduled maintenance of polysilicon factories, which led to a tight balance of supply and demand in 2017.  Additionally, Daqo New Energy has confirmed that its polysilicon order book for 2018 is already 90.2% full, with the company signing multiple long-term contracts with Chinese solar PV manufacturers. This indicates that supply for polysilicon for mono wafers is expected to tighten significantly later this year, leading to leading cell and module developers pre-paying for their polysilicon to secure their supply.  The average selling price (ASP) of polysilicon tends to vary quarter-by-quarter and is influenced by global solar demand. Last year, the ASP for polysilicon was $14.96/kg, but it ended 2017 closer to $16.20/kg. Daqo's average production costs are around $8.95/kg. This suggests that as demand increases and supply tightens, the ASP for polysilicon is likely to rise.  Furthermore, China has requested consultations with the US over its decision to apply a safeguard measure on imports of crystalline silicon photovoltaic cells. This indicates a potential geopolitical conflict that could impact the polysilicon market. If the US implements measures that restrict imports, it could lead to a decrease in supply and potentially drive up prices.  Overall, the news suggests that there is a growing demand for polysilicon, with supply expected to tighten. This, coupled with potential geopolitical conflicts and fluctuations in global solar demand, indicates that polysilicon prices are likely to increase in the future. As a strategic expert, it would be advisable to closely monitor these factors and consider the potential impact on the Chinese and global PV market./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. Firstly, Daqo New Energy has confirmed that its polysilicon order book for 2018 is already 90.2% full, indicating high demand for polysilicon. This is attributed to the signing of multiple long-term contracts with Chinese solar PV manufacturers. Daqo forecasts that supply for polysilicon for mono wafers will tighten later this year, leading to pre-payment by leading cell and module developers to secure their supply.   Secondly, the average selling price (ASP) of polysilicon tends to vary quarter-by-quarter and is influenced by global solar demand. Last year, the ASP for polysilicon was $14.96/kg, but it ended 2017 closer to $16.20/kg. Daqo's average production costs are around $8.95/kg. This indicates that the ASP is susceptible to fluctuations and can be influenced by supply and demand dynamics.  Furthermore, the Institute for Solar Energy Research Hamelin (ISFH) and the Leibniz Universit√§t Hannover have achieved a cell conversion efficiency of 26.1% using polysilicon on oxide (POLO) junctions. This demonstrates that there are alternative pathways to achieve high efficiencies with silicon at potentially low cost, without the need for n-type silicon or boron-diffusions.  In addition, China has requested consultations with the US over its decision to apply a safeguard measure on imports of crystalline silicon photovoltaic cells. This indicates potential geopolitical conflicts that could impact the polysilicon market.  Lastly, Longi Solar's plans to significantly ramp up its production of monocrystalline wafer capacity could lead to an oversupply problem in the second half of the year. This could result in a sharp decline in mono wafer prices and potentially squeeze margins for mono wafer companies.  Overall, the news suggests that there is high demand for polysilicon, potential supply constraints, fluctuations in ASP, technological advancements, geopolitical conflicts, and the possibility of oversupply in the mono wafer market. These factors will likely have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.   Firstly, there is a new polysilicon factory boom underway, with production forecasted to increase from 445,600 metric tons in 2017 to 490,000 tons in 2018. This growth in production is mainly due to temporary scarcity of metallurgical silicon feedstock and scheduled maintenance of polysilicon factories, which led to a tight balance of supply and demand in 2017.  However, the ongoing solar trade dispute between the US and China could have a negative impact on the US polysilicon companies attempting to sell in the China market. The recent announcement by the US administration is forecasted to slow down PV demand in the US, indirectly reducing the total demand for polysilicon in 2018. This could hinder the removal of current barriers to export US polysilicon into China.  Furthermore, the reaction of Chinese companies to the new tariffs imposed by the US was muted and calm, suggesting that they do not have a major problem with the tariffs. This indicates that the volume of polysilicon imported to China has not fluctuated greatly, although imports have fallen as a percentage due to China meeting more demand domestically. China is replacing additional demand for polysilicon imports through domestic production.  In terms of production expansion outside of China, there are few plans among polysilicon producers at the moment, which supports the theory that demand for imports is stagnating. South Korea's OCI is one of the only companies contemplating expansion outside of China, with plans for a new facility in Malaysia still under review.  In terms of specific companies, Daqo New Energy has confirmed that its polysilicon order book for 2018 is already 90.2% full, with multiple long-term contracts signed with Chinese solar PV manufacturers. This indicates a tightening supply for polysilicon for mono wafers later this year, leading to pre-fixed purchase volumes. Daqo's average production costs are around $8.95/kg, while the average selling price for polysilicon tends to vary quarter-by-quarter.  Overall, the news suggests that there is a boom in polysilicon production, but the ongoing trade dispute between the US and China could have a negative impact on the US polysilicon companies. The reaction of Chinese companies to the new tariffs indicates that the volume of polysilicon imported to China has not fluctuated greatly, and China is meeting more demand domestically. The lack of production expansion plans outside of China suggests that demand for imports is stagnating. Daqo New Energy's high order book filling indicates a tightening supply for polysilicon for mono wafers, leading to pre-fixed purchase volumes./n

The news related to polysilicon prices in the upcoming months suggests several factors that could have a significant effect on the China and global PV market. One important factor is the rapid expansion of companies like Longi and Zhonghuan Semiconductor, which exclusively produce monocrystalline products. The question arises as to how these companies will cover their demand for high-purity polysilicon.  Another factor to consider is the impact of government subsidies and geopolitical conflicts on polysilicon prices. For instance, the announcement made by the U.S. administration is forecasted to have a negative effect on PV demand in the U.S., which could indirectly reduce the total demand for polysilicon in 2018. This could also hinder the removal of current barriers to export U.S. polysilicon into China.  The news also suggests that there may be a slight shortage of polysilicon inside China, particularly in Q3. Higher tariffs on imports could exacerbate this shortage. However, Chinese companies seem to have a muted and calm reaction to the new tariffs, indicating that they may not have a major problem with them.  Furthermore, the growth of polysilicon imports to China is slowing down, as China is meeting more of its demand domestically through increased production. This suggests that the demand for imports is stagnating, and expansion plans for production outside of China among polysilicon producers are few and far between.  In terms of specific companies, Daqo New Energy has confirmed that its polysilicon order book for 2018 is already 90.2% full. The company attributes this high pre-fixed purchase volume to the signing of multiple long-term contracts with Chinese solar PV manufacturers. Daqo forecasts that supply for polysilicon for mono wafers will tighten significantly later this year, leading to pre-payment by leading cell and module developers to secure their supply.  Overall, the news indicates that there are several factors at play that could affect future polysilicon prices. These include the expansion plans of certain companies, government subsidies and geopolitical conflicts, and the balance between domestic production and imports in China. It will be important to closely monitor these factors to make strategic decisions regarding the polysilicon market in China./n

The news related to polysilicon prices in the upcoming months suggests several factors that will have a significant effect on the China and global PV market. One important factor is the rapid expansions of Longi and Zhonghuan Semiconductor, both of which exclusively produce monocrystalline products. The question arises as to how these companies will cover their demand for high-purity polysilicon. This could potentially lead to a shortage of polysilicon in the market.  Another factor to consider is the price war between companies. The increase in Chinese polysilicon production has led to a decrease in imports and a decrease in the share of imports in China's polysilicon supply. Chinese manufacturers are continuously expanding their production capacities, which has resulted in a decrease in the global share of polysilicon output from other countries. This increase in production capacity and decrease in imports could lead to a decrease in polysilicon prices.  Government subsidies also play a role in the future prices of polysilicon. The announcement made by the U.S. administration regarding tariffs on imports is forecasted to have a negative effect on PV demand in the U.S. This could indirectly impact the total demand for polysilicon in 2018. Additionally, the reaction of Chinese companies to the new tariffs suggests that they do not have a major problem with them. This could further impact the demand for polysilicon and potentially lead to a shortage.  Geopolitical conflicts also have the potential to affect polysilicon prices. The current barriers to export U.S. polysilicon into China are not expected to be removed, and the prospect of a short-term polysilicon shortage may not be enough to encourage China to provide access to U.S. suppliers. This could further impact the supply and demand dynamics of the polysilicon market.  Overall, the news suggests that the growth of polysilicon imports to China is slowing down, and China is replacing additional demand for polysilicon imports through domestic production. Expansion plans for production outside of China are few and far between, indicating that demand for imports is stagnating. However, concerns remain over the quality of the polysilicon being produced in China, especially for monocrystalline products that require higher purity polysilicon.  In conclusion, the news indicates that the future prices of polysilicon will be influenced by factors such as the rapid expansions of monocrystalline producers, the price war between companies, government subsidies, and geopolitical conflicts. These factors could potentially lead to a shortage of polysilicon and a decrease in prices./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market. One important factor is the rapid expansion of companies like Longi and Zhonghuan Semiconductor, which exclusively produce monocrystalline products. However, it remains uncertain how these companies will cover their demand for high-purity polysilicon.  Another factor to consider is the potential link between cost reduction measures and the implementation of enhanced cell concepts and improved module technologies. This could lead to higher output power for modules made from multicrystalline silicon (mc-Si) and p-type mono-Si by 2028.  The contribution of polysilicon to the final price of solar modules has nearly doubled from 12% to 23% in recent years. Wafers and cells have slightly decreased in their contribution, while module production still takes the largest share of the final module price. With no supply shortage expected in the value chain, producers will continue to face pressure to cut costs.  Geopolitical conflicts, such as the trade war between the US and China, also have an impact on polysilicon prices. The US administration's announcement of tariffs on Chinese goods is forecasted to have a negative effect on PV demand in the US, indirectly reducing the total demand for polysilicon in 2018. This could also hinder US polysilicon companies from exporting to China.  China's efforts to meet more of its own demand for polysilicon domestically have led to a slowdown in the growth of imports. Expansion plans for production outside of China among polysilicon producers are limited, indicating stagnating demand for imports.  In terms of specific companies, Daqo New Energy expects to sell a significant amount of polysilicon in the first quarter of this year and is focused on reducing costs through technological improvements. OCI from South Korea is one of the few companies considering expansion outside of China, with plans for a new facility in Malaysia.  Overall, the future prices of polysilicon will be influenced by factors such as the expansion plans of key producers, the implementation of cost reduction measures, geopolitical conflicts, and the balance between domestic production and imports in China./n

According to a report, companies in the polysilicon industry may be able to reduce costs and improve module technologies, leading to higher output power for solar modules by 2028. The report also highlights the changing contributions of polysilicon, wafers, cells, and modules to the final price of solar modules. Polysilicon's share of the final price nearly doubled to 23%, while wafers and cells decreased slightly to 18% and 22% respectively. The module production part still accounts for the largest share of the final price. The report emphasizes that prices will not compensate for additional costs, putting pressure on producers to cut costs. The report also states that the crystalline silicon technology market share is above 90%.   Daqo, a polysilicon manufacturer, expects to sell between 4,900 and 5,100 MT of polysilicon in the first quarter of this year. The company's focus is on reducing costs, and it has already achieved improved manufacturing efficiency. Daqo plans to further reduce costs in 2018 through technological improvements. The company also conducted annual maintenance at its manufacturing site and approved a project to increase its polysilicon annual capacity.   Another company, GCL-Poly, reported a rise in annual revenue and EBITDA. The company has significant production capacity for monocrystalline silicon ingots, wafers, solar cells, and PV modules. It plans to invest in additional production capacity for monocrystalline silicon ingots, wafers, and PV modules.   Wacker Chemie, a polysilicon producer, expects to restart production in the U.S. in the spring. However, the current production loss will result in lower sales volumes compared to the previous year. Wacker Polysilicon's 2018 sales are expected to be slightly below the previous year due to lower average prices./n

According to recent news, the polysilicon market is expected to see significant changes in the upcoming months. One important factor that will affect prices is the inventory of polysilicon. Chinese manufacturers have been making progress in increasing their polysilicon capacity, with the goal of achieving independence from imports. By the end of 2018, Chinese polysilicon capacity could reach 450,000 MT, compared to 319,000 MT at the end of 2017. This increase in capacity could potentially lead to a decrease in prices.  Another factor that could impact polysilicon prices is the price war between companies. As Chinese manufacturers expand their production, they may engage in price competition to gain market share. This could lead to a decrease in prices as companies try to undercut each other.  Government subsidies also play a role in the polysilicon market. For example, imports of polysilicon from South Korea and Germany have been significant for Chinese wafer producers. Any conflicts or trade disputes between countries could disrupt the supply chain and potentially lead to price fluctuations.  In addition to these factors, the quality of polysilicon is also important. This could potentially lead to increased demand for Chinese polysilicon and have an impact on prices.  Overall, the polysilicon market is expected to see changes in the upcoming months. Factors such as inventory levels, price competition, government subsidies, geopolitical conflicts, and quality improvements will all play a role in determining the future prices of polysilicon. As a strategic expert, it is important to closely monitor these factors and make informed decisions based on the latest news and developments in the market./n

According to recent news, the polysilicon market in China and the global PV market is expected to be significantly affected by several factors. One important factor is the increasing capacity of Chinese polysilicon manufacturers. Chinese polysilicon capacity is expected to reach 450,000 MT by the end of 2018, indicating significant progress in terms of quantity. This supports the goal of China to become independent from polysilicon imports.  However, despite the increase in capacity, Chinese wafer producers will continue to import large amounts of polysilicon. In 2017, China imported 159,000 MT of polysilicon, with South Korean producers accounting for 45% of these imports and Germany's Wacker accounting for 30%. This suggests that there is still a demand for high-purity polysilicon that Chinese manufacturers are unable to meet.  In terms of quality, Chinese manufacturers are making efforts to improve their production and reduce the quality gap between imported polysilicon and domestically produced polysilicon. This indicates that in the future, Chinese manufacturers may be able to produce polysilicon of comparable quality to imported polysilicon.  The expansion plans of companies like Longi and Zhonghuan Semiconductor, which exclusively produce monocrystalline products, have implications both upstream and downstream. These companies will need to secure a steady supply of polysilicon to meet their production needs. Longi has already signed a contract to buy around 64,600 metric tons of polysilicon from South Korea's OCI over the next three years. This indicates that there is a demand for high-quality polysilicon in the market.  The anticipated oversupply of polysilicon in the second half of the year is expected to depress prices further. This could potentially lead to a price war among companies as they try to maintain market share. Companies like Longi, with their economies of scale, may have an advantage in this situation.  Overall, the news suggests that the polysilicon market in China and the global PV market will be influenced by factors such as capacity expansion, import dependence, quality improvement, and potential price wars. These factors should be taken into consideration when making strategic decisions regarding the polysilicon market in China./n

According to recent news, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market. One important factor is the increasing capacity of Chinese polysilicon manufacturers. Chinese polysilicon capacity is expected to reach 450,000 MT by the end of 2018, indicating significant progress in terms of quantity. This supports the goal of China to become independent from polysilicon imports.  However, despite the increase in capacity, Chinese wafer producers will continue to import large amounts of polysilicon. In 2017, China imported 159,000 MT of polysilicon, with South Korean producers accounting for 45% of these imports and Germany's Wacker accounting for 30%. This suggests that there is still a demand for high-quality polysilicon that Chinese manufacturers are unable to meet.  In terms of specific companies, Longi, a major player in the PV market, has announced plans to invest in a 5 GW solar module assembly plant in China. To meet its polysilicon needs, Longi has signed a contract to buy around 64,600 metric tons of polysilicon from South Korea's OCI over the next three years. This indicates that Longi recognizes the importance of high-quality polysilicon for monoingot and wafer production.  Another company, Zhonghuan Semiconductor, is also sourcing polysilicon from OCI, Wacker, and GCL Poly. Zhonghuan has entered into a joint development agreement with GCL for the supply of polysilicon from a plant under construction in the Xinjiang Region. This suggests that multiple companies are relying on imports to meet their polysilicon needs.  Furthermore, the expansion plans of Longi and Zhonghuan have implications both upstream and downstream. The massive volumes of ingots and wafers that these companies plan to produce will require a steady supply of polysilicon. Longi's expansion plans alone involve a significant investment of CNY 1.95 billion (US$299.5 million) and a target of 45 GW of ingot and wafer capacity by 2020.  In terms of government subsidies, it is worth noting that while Wacker was able to negotiate a minimum price with the Chinese government for exports of its polysilicon to China, other large producers such as Hemlock Semiconductor and REC Silicon may be left out due to high Chinese duties on U.S. polysilicon. This suggests that government policies and subsidies can have a significant impact on the polysilicon market.  Overall, the news indicates that the future polysilicon prices will be influenced by factors such as the capacity of Chinese manufacturers, the reliance on imports by Chinese wafer producers, the expansion plans of major companies like Longi and Zhonghuan, and government subsidies and policies. It is important for strategic decision-makers to closely monitor these factors and their potential impact on the polysilicon market./n

Zhonghuan is also sourcing polysilicon from OCI, Wacker, and GCL Poly, and has entered into a joint development agreement with GCL for the supply of polysilicon from a plant under construction in the Xinjiang Region.  The geopolitical conflicts and trade wars between China and the United States have also affected the polysilicon market. Polysilicon spot prices inside China were estimated to be around $16 per kg at the end of the first quarter of 2018, which is $3 less than the same quarter in 2017. The solar trade war between China and the United States has caused supply constraints and higher prices for solar grade polysilicon within China.  Overall, the news suggests that the future polysilicon prices will be influenced by factors such as the capacity expansion of Chinese manufacturers, the demand for high-quality polysilicon, the need for stable supply for monocrystalline production, and geopolitical conflicts and trade wars. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon market to closely monitor these developments and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. One of the key factors is the supply of polysilicon. Longi, a Chinese solar company, has signed a contract to buy around 64,600 metric tons of polysilicon from South Korea's OCI over the next three years. This indicates a high demand for polysilicon, which could potentially drive up prices.  Another important factor is the quality of polysilicon. Longi's Xie notes that imported polysilicon, such as from OCI, is considered to be of higher quality compared to some Chinese manufacturers. However, Chinese manufacturers are working to improve the quality of their production, which could narrow the quality gap in the future. This suggests that the quality of polysilicon from Chinese manufacturers may improve, potentially impacting prices.  Furthermore, the news mentions that polysilicon prices grew in the first quarter of this year due to stronger demand. However, prices fell later in the quarter due to softer markets caused by uncertainty in polysilicon demand and the Chinese holiday season. Polysilicon spot prices inside China were estimated to be around $16 per kg at the end of the first quarter, which is $3 less than the same quarter in 2017. This indicates that polysilicon prices can be volatile and influenced by market conditions.  Additionally, the news highlights the potential for a price war in the second half of the year. Longi's decision to lower the prices of its mono wafers caused other wafer makers to cut their prices as well. This could potentially lead to a price war as companies compete for market share. An oversupply of mono wafers could further depress prices and potentially lead to negative margins for companies.  Overall, the news suggests that the supply and quality of polysilicon, market conditions, and potential price wars among companies will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon market, particularly in China, to closely monitor these factors and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

According to recent news, the Norway-based polysilicon manufacturer REC Silicon has reported improved revenues and profits in the first quarter of this year compared to the same period last year. The company attributes this improvement to stronger demand for polysilicon, which led to higher prices. However, the prices fell later in the quarter due to softer markets and uncertainty in polysilicon demand, as well as the Chinese holiday season. It is worth noting that solar grade polysilicon prices continue to be higher inside China due to supply constraints caused by the solar trade war between China and the United States.  In terms of production, REC Silicon expects to produce 2,660 MT of polysilicon in the second quarter of this year and 11,590 MT in the full fiscal year 2018. The company also predicts average production costs of $13.4 per kg for the current quarter and $11.6 per kg for the whole year.  In addition to REC Silicon's performance, the news highlights the expansion plans of major PV players in China. Companies such as GCL, Tongwei, and East Hope Group are adding significant new capacities of polysilicon production this year. Longi and Zhonghuan Semiconductor are also expanding their wafer production capacities. JinkoSolar, Longi, and other companies have announced plans to increase their module capacities. However, China's NEA is closely monitoring the situation to avoid potential overcapacity issues.  Furthermore, the news mentions the process of issuing shares on China's stock market for several PV companies previously listed on foreign stock exchanges. Trina Solar, JA Solar, and Canadian Solar are among the companies that have decided to float on China's stock market after being dissatisfied with their market prices on foreign exchanges.  Lastly, China's Sunpower Group has secured a contract to provide polysilicon manufacturing equipment to Xinte Energy, one of the world's largest polysilicon manufacturers. This contract further strengthens Sunpower Group's position in the polysilicon industry.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices have been influenced by factors such as demand, market conditions, supply constraints, and geopolitical conflicts. The expansion plans of major PV players in China and the process of issuing shares on China's stock market for PV companies could also have an impact on future polysilicon prices./n

According to recent news, the Norway-based polysilicon manufacturer REC Silicon has reported improved revenues and operating loss in the first quarter of this year compared to the same period last year. The company attributed the growth in polysilicon prices to stronger demand, although prices fell later in the quarter due to softer markets and uncertainty in demand. It also mentioned that solar grade polysilicon prices continue to be higher in China due to supply constraints caused by the solar trade war between China and the United States.  The news also highlights that the global polysilicon market is still dominated by long-term fixed sales contracts and high polysilicon inventory levels. REC Silicon expects to produce 2,660 MT of polysilicon in the second quarter of this year and 11,590 MW in the full fiscal year 2018. The company predicts an average production cost of $13.4 per kg for the current quarter and $11.6 per kg for the whole year.  In addition to REC Silicon's performance, the news mentions several major PV players in China expanding their production capabilities in the upstream and downstream segments. This includes significant increases in polysilicon production capacities by GCL, Tongwei, and East Hope Group, as well as expansions in wafer and module capacities by Longi, Zhonghuan Semiconductor, JinkoSolar, and others. However, China's NEA has issued an emergency notification to limit new expansion plans to avoid potential overcapacity issues.  Furthermore, the news highlights the process of PV companies listed on foreign stock exchanges, such as Trina Solar, JA Solar, and Canadian Solar, seeking to issue shares on China's stock market. This move is seen as a response to their undervalued market price on foreign exchanges.  Other news related to polysilicon production includes REC Silicon achieving 800MT of FBR granular polysilicon production at its JV plant in Yulin, China, Wacker Chemie planning to restart production at its Charleston US facility, and partnerships between Engie and sonnen to offer solar and energy storage packages in France, as well as Albioma building rooftop solar projects in Reunion Island.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices have been influenced by factors such as demand, market uncertainty, supply constraints, and geopolitical conflicts. The expansion of production capacities in China and the potential for overcapacity issues could also impact future polysilicon prices./n

According to recent news, Tongwei, a Chinese polysilicon maker, has entered into a supply agreement with monocrystalline PV module manufacturer Longi. Under this agreement, Tongwei will sell 4,000 metric tons of polysilicon to Longi this year, followed by 21,000 metric tons next year and 30,000 metric tons in 2020. Tongwei expects this deal to generate a net profit of CNY132 million ($20.6 million) this year, CNY694 million next year, and CNY992 million in 2020, subject to fluctuating polysilicon prices and production costs.  The agreement between Tongwei and Longi aims to ensure stable sales of polysilicon. It includes a pricing mechanism and minimum annual purchase levels. However, Tongwei acknowledges that market forces and policy changes could impact the ability of both parties to fulfill the contract on schedule. Tongwei will assess the profitability of the contract based on last year's polysilicon prices.  This deal follows Longi's announcement in February to triple its wafer production capacity to 45 GW by 2020. Longi also plans to have 28 GW of monocrystalline wafer capacity by the end of this year, 36 GW by the end of next year, and 45 GW by 2020. Additionally, Longi signed a $787 million, 39,600 metric tons polysilicon supply agreement with Daqo New Energy in April.  In November, Tongwei announced plans to invest $1.8 billion in the construction of two 10 GW solar cell factories in China, which will make it the world's largest PV manufacturer. Furthermore, in March 2017, Tongwei's subsidiary, Sichuan Yonxiang, unveiled a joint venture with Longi to open a polysilicon production facility in China's Sichuan province with a yearly output capacity of 50,000 metric tons.  Another significant development in the polysilicon market is the agreement between Tongwei and LONGi for the sale of 55,000 metric tons of polysilicon by 2020. This deal will be supplied in phases, with 4,000 metric tons scheduled for 2018, followed by 21,000 metric tons in 2019 and 30,000 metric tons in 2020. This agreement is part of the efforts by LONGi, Trina, and Tongwei to set up a 5 GW monocrystalline silicon ingot crystal growth facility in China.  Overall, these developments in the polysilicon market, including supply agreements, capacity expansions, and joint ventures, indicate a strong focus on increasing production and meeting the growing demand for polysilicon. However, market forces, policy changes, and potential oversupply of monocrystalline wafers could impact future polysilicon prices. It is important for industry players to closely monitor these factors and make strategic decisions accordingly./n

According to recent news, Tongwei, a Chinese polysilicon manufacturer, has entered into a supply agreement with monocrystalline PV module manufacturer Longi. Under this agreement, Tongwei will sell 4,000 metric tons of polysilicon to Longi this year, followed by 21,000 metric tons next year and 30,000 metric tons in 2020. Tongwei expects this deal to generate significant profits in the coming years, subject to fluctuating polysilicon prices and production costs.  This agreement is seen as a strategic move by Longi to secure a stable supply of polysilicon for its expanding wafer production capacity. Longi has announced plans to triple its wafer production capacity to 45 GW by 2020 and aims to have 28 GW of monocrystalline wafer capacity by the end of this year, 36 GW by the end of next year, and 45 GW by 2020. The supply agreement between Tongwei and Longi is significant as it ensures stable sales of polysilicon for Tongwei and secures a reliable supply for Longi's growing production capacity. However, it is important to note that market forces and policy changes could still impact the ability of the two parties to fulfill the contract on schedule.  Overall, this news suggests that the demand for polysilicon in China is expected to increase in the coming years due to the expansion plans of major PV manufacturers like Longi and Tongwei. This could potentially lead to a tightening of supply and an increase in polysilicon prices./n

According to recent news, the demand for polysilicon in China is expected to impact the global PV market by exacerbating over-supply. This will affect various aspects of the PV manufacturing industry, including polysilicon, ingots, wafers, cells, and modules. The Chinese government's policy changes are likely to accelerate consolidation among PV manufacturers, which aligns with their goal of fostering industry consolidation and building national champions. This consolidation will also help Chinese PV manufacturers excel both domestically and overseas.  In addition, there are reports of a potential price war between companies in the polysilicon market. Some companies are expected to exit the market in the next few months, leading to a clearance of inventories and a subsequent rationalization of prices. It is predicted that prices will eventually settle at around 10% less than they were at the start of 2018.  Furthermore, government subsidies and geopolitical conflicts are also expected to have an impact on polysilicon prices. The Chinese government's sudden halt on solar support has led to speculation on which markets could benefit from the inevitable slide in PV component prices. The cap on the domestic PV market in China has caused a significant disruption in the global industry. However, there were warning signs prior to this decision, such as the issuance of an amendment draft of the support policy for distributed generation systems in April. This draft aimed to control new PV installations, as the government realized that the previous year's deployment of 53 GW was not intended or planned.  As a result of the policy changes, it is expected that new PV installations in China will be significantly reduced. Industry experts predict installations of 30-35 GW this year, with even lower numbers in the following years. This reduction in demand, coupled with China's manufacturing overcapacity, is likely to lead to fierce competition in the polysilicon market. Bloomberg New Energy Finance estimates that solar module prices will fall by up to 34% by the end of the year, which will more than compensate for the 30% duty on imported solar cells and modules imposed by the US.  Overall, the future of polysilicon prices is uncertain, but it is expected that there will be a period of consolidation and price rationalization in the market. The impact of government policies, industry consolidation, and geopolitical conflicts will play a significant role in shaping the future of the polysilicon market in China and globally./n

Based on the news articles, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in China and the global PV market.   Firstly, the Chinese government's policy to reduce demand for polysilicon in China will lead to an oversupply in the global PV manufacturing marketplace. This will impact not only polysilicon, but also other components such as ingots, wafers, cells, and modules. The policy is aimed at accelerating consolidation among PV manufacturers, which aligns with Beijing's push for industry consolidation and the development of national champions.  Secondly, the ongoing trade war between the United States and China has caused uncertainty in polysilicon demand and has led to higher prices within China due to supply constraints. The trade dispute, initiated by SolarWorld in 2011, has resulted in anti-dumping import tariffs in China for U.S. and South Korean polysilicon manufacturers. This has had a negative impact on companies like REC Silicon, leading to layoffs and revenue losses.  Thirdly, the reduction in annual global installations and the slowdown of new expansion projects by Chinese manufacturers will affect the future market trends. Mono-Si products are expected to achieve a higher market share than previously expected, and upgrades to PERC and SE cells as well as the promotion of half-cut and bifacial modules are anticipated. These developments may limit the room for price decreases in mono-Si wafers in the future.  Overall, the combination of government policies, trade disputes, and market trends will play a crucial role in determining the future prices of polysilicon in China and the global PV market. It is important for strategic decision-makers to closely monitor these factors and their potential impact on the industry./n

Based on the news analysis, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market. One major factor is the ongoing trade war between China and the United States, which has resulted in anti-dumping import tariffs on U.S. and South Korean polysilicon manufacturers in China. This has led to supply constraints and higher prices for solar grade polysilicon within China.  Furthermore, the reduction in global installations and uncertainty in polysilicon demand have also contributed to softer markets and lower prices. The global polysilicon market is still dominated by long-term fixed sales contracts and high inventory levels, which have kept prices relatively stable.  Government subsidies and policies also play a role in shaping the future of polysilicon prices. For example, the Italian government is expected to approve a new policy by the end of the year that would create opportunities for self-consumption and large-scale plants, potentially boosting demand and prices.  In terms of market trends, mono-Si products are expected to achieve a market share of almost 50% this year, higher than previous expectations. Chinese manufacturers are focusing on upgrading current production lines rather than expanding, and there is a growing interest in PERC, SE, half-cut, and bifacial modules.  Overall, while there are some positive indicators for the polysilicon market, such as the potential for increased demand and market share for mono-Si products, the ongoing trade war and uncertainty in demand continue to pose challenges. It is important for companies to closely monitor these factors and make strategic decisions accordingly./n

Based on the news articles, there are several factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.   Firstly, Daqo New Energy, a major polysilicon manufacturer, announced that its shipments returned to normal levels in early July and that it is currently running at full production capacity with low levels of inventory. This suggests that there may be a stabilization in polysilicon prices in the near future.  However, there are concerns about the Chinese government's willingness to negotiate and the impact of the trade war between the US and China on the polysilicon market. Analysts believe that the recent announcement by the US administration could have a negative effect on PV demand in the US, indirectly reducing the total demand for polysilicon in 2018. This could potentially lead to a decrease in polysilicon prices.  Furthermore, REC Silicon, a US polysilicon manufacturer, has experienced layoffs and revenue losses due to the US-Sino trade dispute. The trade war has resulted in anti-dumping import tariffs in China for US and South Korean polysilicon manufacturers, which has affected the global polysilicon market. This suggests that geopolitical conflicts and trade disputes can have a significant impact on polysilicon prices.  In terms of market trends, mono-Si products are expected to achieve a market share of almost 50% this year, which is higher than previous expectations. Chinese manufacturers are planning to slow down new expansion projects and focus on upgrades of current production lines. This could potentially affect the supply and demand dynamics of polysilicon and influence future prices.  Overall, while there are some positive signs of stabilization in polysilicon prices, factors such as government policies, trade disputes, and market trends can still have a significant impact on the future prices of polysilicon in the China and global PV market./n

According to recent news, the polysilicon market in China and the global PV market is expected to be affected by several factors. One significant factor is the inventory levels of polysilicon. In early July, it was reported that polysilicon prices stabilized and shipments returned to normal levels. This indicates that there is currently low inventory and full production capacity, which could potentially impact future prices.  Another factor that could affect polysilicon prices is the price war between companies. With the increase in production capacity in China, there has been a decrease in the price of polysilicon. In the first half of 2018, over 140,000 tons of polysilicon were produced in China, leading to increased competition and lower prices. This trend is expected to continue, especially in areas with cheaper labor such as the Xinjiang Uygur autonomous region and Inner Mongolia.  Government subsidies also play a role in the polysilicon market. The sudden change in policy by the Beijing authorities at the end of May, calling time on solar incentives, has created uncertainty in the market. The timing and conditions for proceeding with potential disposals and acquisitions are now considered immature. This could lead to a slowdown in investments and further consolidation in the industry.  Geopolitical conflicts can also impact polysilicon prices. For example, the collapse of Shanghai Electric's deal to acquire a controlling stake in China's largest polysilicon maker, Jiangsu Zhongneng, could potentially trigger a round of consolidations in the solar industry. This uncertainty and potential oversupply of polysilicon could further impact prices.  Overall, the news suggests that the polysilicon market is facing challenges due to factors such as inventory levels, price wars, government subsidies, and geopolitical conflicts. These factors could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices, and strategic decisions need to be made to navigate the market effectively./n

Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices are expected to be influenced by factors such as supply and demand dynamics, competition among companies, government policies, and geopolitical conflicts. According to recent news, the polysilicon market is experiencing some significant changes that are expected to impact future prices. One major factor affecting prices is the movement of supply from domestic manufacturers to overseas markets. This has helped to stabilize price fluctuations, but analysts predict that this balance will not last long due to the volatility of the international market.  In Southeast Asia, prices have slightly increased as this region has taken over the slack created by the Taiwanese market. However, capacity control measures have been implemented in response to a cooling off of demand, leading to limited capacity allocation in China. As a result, supply is expected to remain tight.  In terms of pricing, multi-si polysilicon is currently priced at RMB 83-90/kg ($12.06-$13.07/kg) in China, while mono-si has reduced to RMB 90-98/kg ($13.07-$14.24/kg). Internationally, multi-si prices are said to be over $10.3/kg.  Another factor impacting the polysilicon market is the increase in lithium-ion battery prices. EnergyTrend predicts that Li-ion battery prices will increase between 5-15% in the third quarter of this year, primarily due to rising material costs and undersupply of certain cell types.  In terms of production capacity, Daqo, a major polysilicon manufacturer, plans to expand its capacity to 30,000 MT, which is expected to reduce production costs. However, planned maintenance and technology upgrades in the third quarter may result in slightly lower production forecasts.  The market dynamics are also affecting Chinese and Taiwanese companies differently. Chinese companies have several options to respond to the changes, such as upgrading to poly black silicon cells, producing quasi-mono-Si ingots, turning to mono-Si wafers, or exiting the business. However, these options are not attractive for Taiwanese makers due to tighter environmental protection standards or financial reasons.  GCL, a Chinese polysilicon maker, has issued a profit warning, expecting a significant decrease in profits for the first half of 2018. This decrease is primarily attributed to the decline in wafer prices and increased finance costs and exchange loss.  Overall, the polysilicon market is experiencing significant changes in supply, demand, and pricing. The movement of supply overseas, capacity control measures, and the increase in lithium-ion battery prices are all factors that will likely impact future polysilicon prices./n

According to recent news, the polysilicon market is experiencing some significant changes that are expected to impact future prices. One major development is the shift in supply from domestic manufacturers to overseas markets. This has helped stabilize price fluctuations, but analysts predict that this balance will not last long due to the volatility in the international market.  In Southeast Asia, prices have slightly increased as the region has taken over the slack created by the Taiwanese market. However, capacity control measures have been implemented in response to a cooling off of demand, leading to limited capacity allocation in China. The analysts estimate that around 4,000-15,000 tons of capacity have been affected by upgrades on current production lines.  In terms of prices, multi-si polysilicon is currently priced at RMB 83-90/kg ($12.06-$13.07/kg) in China, while mono-si has reduced to RMB 90-98/kg ($13.07-$14.24/kg). Internationally, multi-si prices are reported to be over $10.3/kg.  Another factor that could impact polysilicon prices is the increase in lithium-ion battery costs. EnergyTrend predicts a 5-15% price increase in the third quarter of this year, primarily due to rising material costs and undersupply of certain cell types.  Furthermore, a Chinese polysilicon and wafer manufacturer, Daqo, recently announced that it would halt wafer production due to challenging market conditions. This decision was made in response to abrupt changes in the Chinese government's solar PV policy. The production halt is expected to cost Daqo around US$21.6 million and will result in a focus solely on polysilicon production.  Overall, these developments suggest that the polysilicon market is facing uncertainties and challenges, which could potentially lead to price fluctuations in the future. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the industry to closely monitor these factors and adapt their strategies accordingly./n

According to recent news, GCL-Poly, a major polysilicon and wafer manufacturer, has claimed that polysilicon and wafer prices have rebounded from their lowest point two months ago. This rebound is attributed to the Chinese government's decision to reduce solar subsidies. The chairman of GCL-Poly, Zhu Gongshan, predicts that China will achieve grid parity in the second half of next year, which will be accelerated by the removal of subsidies. He also believes that this policy change will separate the stronger companies with better products from the weaker ones in the Chinese solar manufacturing industry.  Despite the challenging market conditions, GCL-Poly plans to continue expanding its polysilicon production volumes. The company aims to complete the first phase of production capacity at its new Xinjiang factory, with subsequent phases to be completed by the end of this year and by the end of 2020. However, the final stage of expansion is subject to prevailing market conditions.  In contrast, Daqo, another Chinese polysilicon and wafer manufacturer, has announced that it will stop wafer production due to increasingly challenging market conditions. This decision was made in response to the Chinese government's abrupt changes to its solar PV policy. Around 450 employees and 430 MW of production capacity will be affected by this decision. Daqo will now focus solely on polysilicon production and has plans to expand its capacity by 77,000 metric tons.  The news also highlights the different options available to Chinese companies in response to the new market dynamics, such as upgrading to enable poly black silicon cells, producing quasi-mono-Si ingots, turning to mono-Si wafers, or exiting the business. However, these options are not attractive for Taiwanese manufacturers due to stricter environmental standards or financial reasons.  Overall, these developments in the polysilicon market, including the rebound in prices, the removal of subsidies, and the challenges faced by manufacturers, will have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices. It is important for strategic decision-makers to closely monitor these news updates and consider the implications for the Chinese and global PV market./n

According to recent news, GCL-Poly, a major polysilicon and wafer manufacturer in China, has claimed that polysilicon and wafer prices have already rebounded from their lowest point following the Chinese government's decision to reduce solar subsidies. The company's CEO, Zhu Zhanjun, stated that prices hit their lowest point two months ago before recovering, contradicting the predictions of some industry analysts. The chairman of GCL-Poly, Zhu Gongshan, also predicted that China will achieve grid parity in the second half of next year, which will be accelerated by the government's decision to reduce subsidies.  The chairman further stated that the policy change will help differentiate between stronger and weaker companies in the Chinese solar manufacturing industry. He emphasized that the domestic market opportunities will not be eliminated due to the removal of subsidies, but will instead be captured by companies with stronger capabilities and better products. Despite the policy change, GCL-Poly plans to continue expanding its polysilicon production volumes. The company aims to complete the first phase of production capacity at its new Xinjiang factory, with subsequent phases to be completed by the end of this year and 2020.  In contrast, another Chinese polysilicon and wafer manufacturer, Daqo, announced that it will stop production of wafers due to challenging market conditions. This decision was made following the Chinese government's abrupt changes to its solar PV policy in May. Daqo will now focus solely on the production of polysilicon and is executing plans to expand its capacity by 77,000 metric tons. The company aims to complete these expansion plans by the end of 2019.  The news also highlights the impact of the current low season on polysilicon prices. The oversupply of polysilicon has led to a price war, with some manufacturers ceasing production due to uncompetitive costs. It is expected that some companies ceasing production during this period may permanently exit the PV industry. Non-Chinese polysilicon makers and those located in east coast China are likely to focus on increasing the production of mono-grade polysilicon or cease production altogether. The mono-Si wafer segment is expected to be dominated by a few top-tier manufacturers and vertically integrated companies. For multi-Si wafer, several manufacturers have been ruled out after industry reshuffling. It is anticipated that multi-Si ingot capacity will face difficulties surviving in non-Chinese regions from 2019, except for vertically integrated companies.  The concentration of the supply chain has led to Chinese demand being driven by the Top Runner Program and poverty alleviation initiatives, with mono-Si products accounting for 85% of the 5 GW General Top Runner demand. In China's domestic market, mono-Si products have the highest market share at 54%. The 25% safeguard duty in India has also significantly affected the demand for multi-Si products, leading to a shift towards mono-Si products. It is projected that global demand for mono-Si products will reach 47% this year and increase to 60% next year.  Due to the drop in domestic demand, Chinese module makers are exploring other markets. Adjustments to India's duties and the cancellation of Europe's minimum import price (MIP) are expected to impact the PV market. These trade barriers have influenced the market dynamics and will likely have an effect on polysilicon prices in the future./n

According to recent news, GCL-Poly, a major polysilicon and wafer manufacturer, has claimed that polysilicon and wafer prices have rebounded from their lowest point following the Chinese government's decision to reduce solar subsidies. The company's CEO, Zhu Zhanjun, stated that prices hit their lowest point two months ago before recovering, contradicting the predictions of some industry analysts. The chairman of GCL-Poly, Zhu Gongshan, also predicted that China will achieve grid parity in the second half of next year, which will be accelerated by the government's decision to reduce subsidies.  The chairman further stated that the policy change will help differentiate between stronger and weaker companies in the Chinese solar manufacturing industry. He emphasized that the domestic market opportunities will not be eliminated due to the removal of subsidies, but will instead be captured by companies with stronger capabilities and better products. Despite the policy change, GCL-Poly plans to continue expanding its polysilicon production volumes. The company aims to complete the first phase of production capacity at its new Xinjiang factory, with subsequent phases to be completed by the end of this year and 2020.  In contrast, another Chinese polysilicon and wafer manufacturer, Daqo, announced that it will halt wafer production due to challenging market conditions. This decision was made in response to the Chinese government's abrupt changes to its solar PV policy in May. Around 450 employees will be affected, and the production halt is expected to cost Daqo approximately $21.6 million. Daqo will now focus solely on polysilicon production and has plans to expand its capacity by 77,000 metric tons.  In terms of industry developments, Shunfeng International Clean Energy (SFCE) has expressed its intention to sell its manufacturing unit to one of its shareholders, Asia Pacific Resources Development Investment Ltd. Additionally, Shanghai Electric submitted a bid to acquire a controlling stake in GCL-Poly, but the agreement fell through due to timing and conditions. Prices across the PV supply chain are also falling, although they are expected to stabilize.  Overall, the news indicates that the Chinese government's decision to reduce solar subsidies has had a significant impact on polysilicon prices. While GCL-Poly claims that prices have already rebounded, Daqo's decision to halt wafer production suggests ongoing challenges in the market. The future of the polysilicon industry will likely be influenced by the ability of companies to adapt to the new policy environment and produce high-quality products./n

According to recent news, GCL-Poly, a major polysilicon manufacturer in China, has claimed that polysilicon prices have already rebounded from their lowest point following the Chinese government's decision to reduce solar subsidies. The company's CEO, Zhu Zhanjun, stated that prices hit their lowest point two months ago before recovering. This contradicts the predictions of some solar industry analysts who had anticipated a more negative impact on prices. GCL's chairman, Zhu Gongshan, also predicted that China will achieve grid parity in the second half of next year, which will be accelerated by the government's decision to reduce subsidies. He believes that this policy change will help to differentiate between stronger and weaker companies in the Chinese solar manufacturing industry.  Despite the policy change, GCL-Poly plans to continue expanding its polysilicon production capacity. The company aims to complete the first phase of its new Xinjiang factory, with a production capacity of 20,000 tonnes, by the end of this year. The second phase, also with a capacity of 20,000 tonnes, is expected to be completed by the end of 2019, and a final expansion phase of 20,000 tonnes is planned for completion by the end of 2020. GCL's chairman emphasized that the company's expansion plans are subject to prevailing market conditions.  In addition to GCL-Poly, other companies in the industry are also making strategic moves. Shunfeng International Clean Energy (SFCE) announced its intention to sell its manufacturing unit to one of its shareholders, Asia Pacific Resources Development Investment Ltd. Shanghai Electric submitted a bid to acquire a controlling stake in GCL-Poly, but the agreement fell through due to timing and conditions not being mature enough.  Furthermore, the expiration of minimum import prices imposed by the EU on crystalline photovoltaic products imported from China may have an impact on the polysilicon market. However, the sanctions imposed by the Chinese government on imports of polysilicon in 2013, as a retaliation against anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures in Europe, are still in force. Wacker Chemie, a German company, negotiated a minimum import price regulation with the Chinese Ministry of Commerce in 2013, which is still in effect. The company expects the ministry to make a decision in late October regarding action against polysilicon imports from the EU.  Daqo New Energy Corp, another Chinese polysilicon manufacturer, aims to reduce the cost of producing polysilicon to $6.80/kg by early 2020. The company plans to achieve this through economies of scale, a deal for cheaper electricity supply, and a modernization program. Daqo has completed the latest phase of its production capacity expansion plan, with pilot production already underway. The company expects its expanded facility to reach its full 30,000 MT production capacity by April. The local power supplier will reduce the cost of electricity by around 18%, enabling Daqo to produce polysilicon at a lower cost.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices have rebounded from their lowest point and are expected to stabilize. The Chinese government's decision to reduce solar subsidies is seen as an opportunity for stronger companies to capture the domestic market. Companies like GCL-Poly and Daqo are continuing their expansion plans, indicating confidence in the future of the polysilicon market. The expiration of minimum import prices in the EU and the ongoing sanctions on polysilicon imports from China may also have an impact on prices./n

According to recent reports from EnergyTrend and PV Infolink, the global PV market has seen mixed developments in recent days. Polysilicon prices have declined, while prices for wafers have been divergent. Demand for high efficiency monocrystalline products remains strong in both China and foreign markets. However, demand for multicrystalline products remains weak in all areas.  The weak demand for polysilicon has put pressure on producers, leading to a decline in prices. The price of foreign silicon has followed the trend of Chinese products and continued to fall. Further price reductions are expected if demand does not pick up. Some polysilicon producers have responded by adjusting their capacity or postponing the construction of new factories to slow down the fall in prices.  For wafers, the price of monocrystalline wafers remains stable and could even increase with a growth in demand in the coming weeks. On the other hand, a further drop in prices for multicrystalline wafers is expected, especially as the order backlogs of the biggest manufacturers increase. It will take some time for the stocks to be reduced.  In terms of market conditions, the United States and China are currently in a trade war, which has affected the polysilicon market. Chinese solar PV manufacturer, Shunfeng International Clean Energy, is looking to sell its manufacturing unit, while Shanghai Electric's bid to take a controlling stake in China's largest polysilicon maker, GCL-Poly, fell through. The expiration of the minimum import prices imposed by the EU on crystalline photovoltaic products imported from China has also had an impact on the market.  Overall, the future prices of polysilicon will depend on factors such as demand, government subsidies, and geopolitical conflicts. Weak demand and the trade war between the US and China have led to a decline in prices. However, the stability of monocrystalline wafer prices and the potential for increased demand in the coming weeks could have a positive effect. It remains to be seen how government subsidies and geopolitical conflicts will further impact the market./n

According to recent reports from EnergyTrend and PV Infolink, the global PV market has seen mixed developments in recent days. Polysilicon prices have declined, while prices for wafers have been divergent. Demand for high efficiency monocrystalline products remains strong in both China and foreign markets. However, demand for multicrystalline products remains weak in all areas.  Weak demand has put pressure on polysilicon producers, leading to a decline in prices. The price of foreign silicon has followed the trend of Chinese products and continued to fall. Further price reductions are expected if demand does not pick up. Some polysilicon producers have responded by adjusting their capacity or postponing the construction of new factories to slow down the fall in prices.  For wafers, the price of monocrystalline wafers remains stable and could even increase with a growth in demand in the coming weeks. On the other hand, a further drop in prices for multicrystalline wafers is expected, especially because the order backlogs of the biggest manufacturers are increasing.  In terms of government policies, the recent policy change by the China central government to limit subsidy support for PV installations has caused short-term issues for most companies. However, Longi Solar, the world's largest producer of monocrystalline ingots and wafers, believes that this policy change will not significantly change their position in the industry in the long term.  The European Commission's intention to discontinue the Minimum Import Price (MIP) for imported modules is expected to have a positive impact on Longi's business in Europe. The removal of the MIP allows Longi to better serve the EU market by providing high-performance new generation products. It will also allow renewable energy costs to reduce dramatically.  Wacker, a German company, has experienced a decline in sales and earnings due to the "substantially reduced volumes and lower average prices" of solar grade polysilicon resulting from China's policy change. The company's polysilicon division saw a significant decrease in sales and EBITDA. The policy change, along with ramp-up costs at its Charleston site in the US, has affected Wacker's financial performance.  Despite the challenges faced by some polysilicon producers, GCL-Poly has announced a second capacity expansion for its new facility in Xinjiang, China. The company plans to increase the capacity from 40,000 MT to 60,000 MT, with an investment cost of over $45 million. GCL-Poly expects the project to reach full capacity by the end of 2020, increasing the company's total capacity to 115,000 MT.  Overall, the news suggests that weak demand and government policies have put pressure on polysilicon prices. While monocrystalline wafers remain stable, prices for multicrystalline wafers are expected to decline further. The long-term outlook for polysilicon producers remains positive, with some companies adjusting their capacity to mitigate the fall in prices./n
