According to recent news, the price of polysilicon has dropped below $8/kg for the first time, but it is expected to rebound in the upcoming months. This rebound is anticipated due to the rush in China to complete PV projects in order to qualify for state subsidies. As a result, wafer manufacturers and module makers are not bowing to price pressure and are refusing to lower prices.   Furthermore, it is predicted that polysilicon prices may rise again in the second half of this year, driven by increasing solar demand in the Chinese PV market. However, it is unlikely that the prices will go beyond $11 per kilogram.   In terms of supply and demand, it is expected that new Chinese capacity will supply the market, resulting in supply-demand equilibrium. Non-Chinese polysilicon manufacturers may exit the market, leading to flat prices for mono polysilicon.   The trend of localized production equipment and materials supply in China is expected to deliver cost reductions, with increased throughput resulting in savings. Additionally, there is an increasing emphasis on research and development to boost power output.   The analysts also note that mono polysilicon is surpassing multi polysilicon in terms of market share, with an expected market share of 60-62% in 2019. This is due to higher power output at equivalent costs. However, the switch to mono polysilicon requires considerable effort and does not happen overnight.   In terms of price reductions, weak demand in the first half of 2020 may force multicrystalline cell and module makers to make some reductions. On the other hand, the wafer and cell segment of the mono polysilicon market is currently the most profitable and is likely to see price reductions in the low seasons over the next two years.   Overall, while there may not be dramatic declines in polysilicon prices, falling prices are expected to be a major cost reduction driver in the short to mid-term. New polysilicon capacities coming online in China have the potential to reach similar levels of quality with a lower cost structure. Polysilicon costs are also expected to fall in the multicrystalline segment as cell producers continue to switch to mono./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.   Firstly, it is expected that there will be a boom in Chinese PV demand in the upcoming months, which will drive a rebound in cell prices. This is due to China rushing to complete PV projects in order to qualify for state subsidies this year. As a result, the price of polysilicon, which dropped below $8/kg for the first time this month, is expected to recover.  Secondly, wafer manufacturers and module makers are not bowing to price pressure from cell makers and are refusing to lower prices. They are anticipating a solar gold rush in the near future and are holding their prices in anticipation of increased demand.  Additionally, it is predicted that polysilicon prices may rise again in the second half of this year, driven by increasing solar demand in the Chinese PV market. However, it is unlikely that prices will go beyond $11 per kilogram.  Furthermore, Daqo New Energy, a polysilicon producer, has completed the construction and installation of Phase 4A ahead of schedule. They expect to ramp up production to full capacity by the end of this year, increasing their total annual polysilicon production capacity to 70,000 MT. With greater economies of scale and higher manufacturing efficiency, they anticipate the total cost of polysilicon production at their Xinjiang facilities to decrease to approximately $6.80/kg in the first quarter of 2020.  Moreover, there is a growing demand for mono-crystalline solar technology, which is expected to account for over 80% of the global PV market by the end of 2020. However, the supply of ultra-high-quality mono-grade polysilicon lags behind the demand, resulting in a significant premium for mono-grade polysilicon compared to multi-grade polysilicon.  Lastly, Daqo is also working on producing even higher grade polysilicon for use in n-type cells. They aim to be market-ready and produce approximately 40% of their total polysilicon products for potential n-type applications in 2020.  Overall, the anticipated boom in Chinese PV demand, refusal to lower prices by wafer manufacturers and module makers, and the expansion of polysilicon production capacity by Daqo New Energy are all factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices./n

The news article highlights the completion of Phase 4A of Daqo New Energy's polysilicon production facility in Xinjiang, China, ahead of schedule. The CEO, Longgen Zhang, expresses excitement and gratitude towards the team for their hard work. The company has already started pilot production at Phase 4A and aims to reach full capacity by the end of the year, increasing their total annual polysilicon production capacity to 70,000 MT.  Zhang also discusses the growing market share of mono-crystalline solar technology, which is expected to account for over 80% of the global PV market by the end of 2020. However, the supply of ultra-high-quality mono-grade polysilicon is still lagging behind the increasing demand, resulting in a significant premium for mono-grade polysilicon compared to multi-grade polysilicon.  Daqo is focused on maintaining product quality, as it believes it is just as important as cost structure for a polysilicon producer's profitability. The company aims to produce approximately 40% of its total polysilicon products for potential n-type applications in 2020, which require even higher quality polysilicon compared to standard p-type applications.  The completion of Phase 4A will provide Daqo with added high-quality polysilicon capacity, allowing them to benefit from the sustainable growth of the global solar PV market. The CEO emphasizes the company's commitment to addressing climate change and making solar PV one of the cleanest, most sustainable, and cost-effective sources of energy.  Overall, the news highlights the increasing demand for high-grade polysilicon for mono wafers and the need for greater supply to meet this demand. This could potentially lead to higher prices for polysilicon in the future, especially for mono-grade polysilicon. Daqo's expansion and focus on quality position them well to capitalize on the growing market./n

Based on the news provided, there are several key factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices.   Firstly, the CEO of Daqo New Energy, Mr. Longgen Zhang, stated that mono-crystalline solar technology is rapidly expanding its market share and is expected to account for over 80% of the global PV market by the end of 2020. This increase in demand for mono-grade polysilicon is causing a supply shortage, leading to higher prices for this type of polysilicon compared to multi-grade polysilicon.  Furthermore, Daqo New Energy has completed the construction and installation of Phase 4A of its polysilicon production facility in Xinjiang ahead of schedule. This expansion will double the company's annual production capacity to 70,000 MT. With greater economies of scale and higher manufacturing efficiency, Daqo expects the total cost of polysilicon production at its Xinjiang facilities to decrease to approximately US$6.80/kg in the first quarter of 2020. This decrease in production costs could potentially lead to a decrease in polysilicon prices.  Additionally, Daqo is also working on producing even higher grade polysilicon for use in n-type cells, which require higher quality polysilicon compared to standard p-type cells. The company aims to produce approximately 40% of its total polysilicon products for potential n-type applications in 2020. This focus on producing higher quality polysilicon could potentially lead to an increase in prices for these specialized products.  It is also worth noting that the CEO of Chinese polysilicon manufacturer Daqo New Energy predicts that monosilicon products will account for 80% of the global solar market by 2021. This further emphasizes the increasing demand for high-grade polysilicon and the potential impact on prices.  Overall, the news suggests that the increasing demand for mono-grade polysilicon, the expansion of production capacity, and the focus on producing higher quality polysilicon for specialized applications could all have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices./n

According to Longgen Zhang, the CEO of Chinese polysilicon manufacturer Daqo New Energy, monosilicon products are expected to account for 80% of the global solar market by 2021. This prediction was made in a press release announcing the start of pilot production at Daqo's expanded polysilicon production facility in Xinjiang, China. Zhang also stated that the demand for high-grade polysilicon for use in mono wafers continues to outstrip supply.  Daqo's expansion project in Xinjiang, which started pilot production ahead of schedule, is expected to double the company's annual production capacity to 70,000 MT. The availability of cheaper electricity in the region has helped Daqo reduce production costs, with the CEO predicting manufacturing expenses of around $6.80/kg in the first quarter of 2020. Additionally, Daqo claims that 85% of its polysilicon output is pure enough for use in high-efficiency mono wafers, and this figure is expected to rise to 90% once the expanded facilities are fully operational.  Zhang emphasized the importance of product quality in addition to cost structure for a polysilicon producer's profitability. As a result, mono-grade polysilicon is being sold at a significant premium over multi-grade polysilicon. Daqo currently sells approximately 85% of its products to mono customers, and this percentage is expected to increase to 90% after the expansion project is completed. The company is also working with key customers to test its products for potential N-type mono wafer applications, which require even higher quality polysilicon.  The CEO's prediction of monosilicon's increasing market share aligns with the industry's expectation that mono technology will account for over 80% of the global PV market by the end of 2020. However, the supply of ultra-high-quality mono-grade polysilicon still lags behind the growing demand. Daqo's strategic decision to expand its production capacity and focus on high-quality polysilicon positions the company to benefit from the sustainable growth of the global solar PV market./n

The news regarding polysilicon prices in the upcoming months suggests that there has been a delay in the expected increase in prices due to increased demand from China. Wacker Chemie, a German chemicals giant, has revised its earnings forecast for 2019, stating that the prices for polysilicon remain extremely low. This is primarily due to overcapacity created by Chinese competitors, resulting in a price war between companies.  According to PV InfoLink, polysilicon prices are expected to remain the same in October, with monocrystalline prices in China at around RMB 75/kg and multicrystalline prices at RMB 60/kg. The analysts also predict that Chinese producers undergoing maintenance may resume production in November, further pushing down the price for multicrystalline grade polysilicon. However, they expect to see slight price increases for monocrystalline polysilicon outside of China for the rest of 2019.  The slow materialization of an installation rally from China, along with the increased polysilicon output in the country, has contributed to the low prices. Companies like Daqo New Energy and Tongwei have brought manufacturing facilities online in western China, where low electricity prices result in lower production costs. Daqo New Energy's CEO, Longgen Zhang, expects the total cost of polysilicon production at their Xinjiang facilities to decrease to approximately US$6.80/kg in the first quarter of 2020.  Zhang also highlights the growing market share of monocrystalline solar technology and predicts that it will account for over 80% of the global PV market by the end of 2020. The supply of high-quality monocrystalline-grade polysilicon is still lagging behind the demand, resulting in a significant premium for this type of polysilicon. Daqo New Energy aims to produce approximately 40% of their total polysilicon products for potential n-type applications in 2020.  Overall, the news suggests that the current low prices for polysilicon are due to overcapacity and a price war between Chinese competitors. The slow demand from China and the increased polysilicon output in the country have also contributed to the low prices. However, there is an expectation of slight price increases for monocrystalline polysilicon outside of China. The growing market share of monocrystalline solar technology and the lagging supply of high-quality monocrystalline-grade polysilicon indicate a potential increase in demand and prices in the future./n

According to recent news, Wacker Chemie, a German chemicals giant, has revised its earnings forecast for 2019 due to the low prices of polysilicon. The company had expected an increase in the price of solar-grade polysilicon in the second half of the year, driven by increased demand from China, but this has not materialized. As a result, Wacker Chemie now expects its full-year group sales to remain at the same level as in 2018 and its EBITDA to be around 30% lower than the previous year.  The low prices of polysilicon are attributed to overcapacity created by Chinese competitors, which has led to a decline in average prices for the material. Polysilicon prices are expected to remain the same throughout October, with monocrystalline prices in China at around RMB 75 ($10.57)/kg and multicrystalline prices at RMB 60/kg. Chinese producers undergoing maintenance may resume production in November, further pushing down the price for multicrystalline grade poly.  Many industry players had anticipated an installation rally from China to boost demand in the second half of the year, but this has been slow to materialize. Additionally, China's polysilicon output has greatly increased this year, with new manufacturing facilities coming online. This has resulted in a surplus of polysilicon in the market, contributing to the low prices.  In another news, REC Silicon, a Norwegian manufacturer, has announced that it is considering selling its polysilicon production line in Butte, Montana, due to the ongoing trade war between the US and China. China has imposed trade measures on US-made solar grade polysilicon, leaving REC Silicon locked out of the Chinese market. The company had already halted polysilicon production at its Moses Lake facility in Washington earlier this year.  If REC Silicon sells its Butte facility, it would be left without any operating wholly-owned production facilities and would be dependent on its stake in a polysilicon plant in China for revenue. The company stated that the proceeds from the sale would be used to retire its debts and prepare to restart production in Washington when the trade dispute with China is resolved.  These developments in the polysilicon market indicate that the prices of polysilicon are likely to remain low in the near future due to overcapacity and the trade war between the US and China. The increase in Chinese polysilicon output and the lack of demand from China have contributed to the current situation. As a strategic expert, it would be advisable to closely monitor the developments in the trade war and the Chinese polysilicon market to make informed decisions regarding the polysilicon market in China./n

The news regarding polysilicon prices in the upcoming months suggests that there are several factors impacting the market. Wacker Chemie, a German chemicals giant, has revised its earnings forecast for 2019 due to the low prices of polysilicon. The company had expected an increase in prices driven by increased demand from China, but this has not materialized. The overcapacity created by Chinese competitors has led to a further decline in prices.  PV InfoLink, an analyst firm, predicts that polysilicon prices will remain the same in October, with monocrystalline prices at around RMB 75/kg and multicrystalline prices at RMB 60/kg in China. The firm also expects Chinese producers to resume production in November, which may further push down the price for multicrystalline grade polysilicon. Outside of China, prices for monocrystalline polysilicon are expected to increase slightly for the rest of 2019.  The news also highlights the impact of tariffs imposed by China on US-made polysilicon since 2014. US polysilicon exports to China have decreased by 90% during this period, causing significant harm to the US polysilicon industry. The three largest US-based manufacturers of polysilicon, REC Silicon, Hemlock Semiconductor Operations, and Wacker Chemie AG, have called for an end to these tariffs. They argue that the tariffs are putting the US polysilicon industry at risk, as polysilicon is a key ingredient for various sectors, including solar cells, smartphones, autonomous vehicles, and electronics.  The US manufacturers have requested the inclusion of polysilicon in ongoing trade talks with China and the extension of the federal solar tax credit. They also propose the introduction of programs and investment incentives to strengthen the US solar value and supply chains. The impact of the tariffs is evident, with REC Silicon and HSC having to shut down their polysilicon plants and Wacker Chemie lowering its sales guidance for 2019.  In summary, the news suggests that the low prices of polysilicon, driven by overcapacity and Chinese competition, are impacting the market. The lack of a price recovery in the second half of the year has led to revised earnings forecasts for companies like Wacker Chemie. Additionally, the tariffs imposed by China on US-made polysilicon have significantly reduced US exports and put the US polysilicon industry at risk. The industry is calling for the inclusion of polysilicon in trade talks and the extension of the federal solar tax credit to support its growth and competitiveness./n

The news article discusses the impact of tariffs imposed by China on US-made polysilicon since 2014. The tariffs have resulted in a significant decrease in US polysilicon exports to China, causing a decline in the US polysilicon industry. The three largest US-based manufacturers of polysilicon have requested the government to include polysilicon in ongoing trade talks with China and extend the federal solar tax credit. They argue that the tariffs are putting the US polysilicon industry at risk, as polysilicon is a key ingredient for various industries, including solar cells, smartphones, autonomous vehicles, and electronics.  The article also highlights the negative consequences faced by the US polysilicon manufacturers. REC Silicon had to shut down its polysilicon plant, Hemlock Semiconductor Operations had to close its Tennessee plant, and Wacker Chemie had to lower its sales guidance due to lower prices for polysilicon caused by overcapacity created by Chinese competitors. The US manufacturers claim that China's actions are attempting to dominate the global market for polysilicon.  On the other hand, Chinese polysilicon manufacturer Daqo New Energy has reported its most productive quarter ever, producing 9,437 metric tons of polysilicon in the third quarter. The company has completed construction of a new facility and expects it to be operating at full capacity this year. Daqo aims to produce 14-15,000 metric tons of polysilicon in the current quarter and has shifted towards producing high-quality monocrystalline silicon output to maintain a higher average selling price. The company expects an increase in demand for mono-grade polysilicon due to the expansion of downstream mono-wafer customers.  Overall, the news highlights the ongoing trade war between the US and China and its impact on the polysilicon industry. The tariffs imposed by China have significantly affected US polysilicon exports and put the US industry at risk. Based on the news articles, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices.   Firstly, there is an increase in demand for mono-grade polysilicon, which is expected to improve the price of mono-grade polysilicon in the coming year. This is due to the ramp-up in manufacturing capacity across the supply chain, particularly in the mono-Si wafer and cell sectors. However, this increase in capacity may also lead to excess capacity in the midstream sector, resulting in the elimination of older capacity with no cost advantage.  Secondly, there is a price war between companies in the polysilicon market. Chinese PV manufacturer Longi Solar, for example, has announced plans to build a 5 GW solar module production line for its high-efficiency products. This expansion of production capacity is part of Longi's strategy to dominate the market and increase its annual production capacity. Other companies may also engage in similar expansion plans, which could lead to increased competition and potentially lower prices.  Thirdly, government subsidies play a role in the polysilicon market. The announcement of Policy 5/31 in China, which scaled back the central subsidy system for photovoltaic projects, has led to a decline in domestic market demand and overall installed capacity in 2019. As a result, companies are focusing on cost reduction, production efficiency increases, and technological advancements to achieve grid parity. This shift in focus may impact polysilicon prices as companies seek to save costs through intelligent operation and maintenance systems.  Lastly, geopolitical conflicts can also affect polysilicon prices. While not explicitly mentioned in the news articles provided, conflicts between countries can disrupt the supply chain and impact the availability and prices of raw materials such as polysilicon.  In summary, the future prices of polysilicon will be influenced by factors such as the increase in demand for mono-grade polysilicon, the price war between companies, government subsidies, and geopolitical conflicts. These factors will shape the market dynamics and determine the direction of polysilicon prices in the coming months./n

According to recent news, Chinese polysilicon manufacturer Daqo New Energy has reported its most productive quarter ever, producing 9,437 metric tons of polysilicon in the third quarter. The company also achieved a new record in manufacturing cost, which fell to $6.97/kg. Daqo expects to continue improving its cost structure with the help of its new factory, which is expected to be operating at full capacity this year.  In terms of pricing, the average selling price for polysilicon fell to $8.99/kg in the third quarter, compared to $9.10/kg in the previous quarter. However, the company noted that prices in China were slightly higher during this period and the decrease was mainly due to the depreciation of the renminbi against the dollar. To counter this, Daqo has shifted its production towards high-quality monocrystalline silicon output, which it expects will maintain a higher average selling price. The company anticipates an increase in demand for mono-grade polysilicon, especially from its downstream mono-wafer customers.  Furthermore, Daqo remains optimistic about the future of the PV market, despite the delayed installation rush in China. The company expects global PV demand to reach 85 GW this year, compared to 60 GW in 2018. Looking ahead, Daqo's CEO, Longgen Zhang, predicts that many of the projects planned for the current quarter in China will roll over into next year, potentially driving global PV demand to 140 GW. Zhang believes that the market is on the cusp of major changes, which will create significant opportunities for the company in the coming years.  In terms of partnerships, Daqo has received the 2019 Strategic Partner Award from LONGi, a leading mono-wafer producer. This award reflects the trust LONGi has in Daqo's ability to consistently deliver ultra-high-purity polysilicon. Daqo sees this recognition as a testament to its high-quality products, leading cost structure, and growing production capacity.  Overall, the news suggests that while polysilicon prices have experienced a slight decline, there are positive indicators for the future. The shift towards high-quality monocrystalline silicon output and the anticipation of increased demand from both China and global markets could lead to an improvement in polysilicon prices. Daqo New Energy remains confident in its ability to navigate the current market challenges and take advantage of the recovery expected in the PV market next year./n

According to news from pv magazine Germany, Wacker Chemie AG, a German chemical company and major polysilicon producer, has announced that it will need to make an extraordinary write-down of around ‚Ç¨750 million on the balance sheet value of its polysilicon production assets. This write-down is primarily due to China's construction of new solar installations falling short of initial expectations and the high polysilicon overcapacity in China. The exact amount of the write-down will be determined during the preparation of full-year results. This setback has caused Wacker's polysilicon division to shift from a slightly positive result to a loss before interest and tax of around ‚Ç¨750 million.  Wacker Chemie AG had already adjusted its full-year expectations in October due to the lack of a solar-market recovery and low prices for polysilicon used in photovoltaic applications. The company attributes the oversupply of polysilicon to the Chinese government's subsidies and support for expansion, including providing favorable electricity prices to polysilicon producers. Wacker has adjusted its projections for the coming year accordingly.  In another news, Daqo New Energy, a Chinese polysilicon manufacturer, has reported its most productive quarter ever, producing 9,437 metric tons of polysilicon in the third quarter. The company has completed construction of its new facility and expects it to be operating at full capacity this year. Daqo is forecasting production of 14-15,000 metric tons of polysilicon in the current quarter, with sales of up to 13,500 metric tons. The company has also shifted its focus towards producing high-quality monocrystalline silicon output, which it expects will maintain a higher average selling price.  These news articles highlight the significant impact of China's polysilicon production and market on global prices. The oversupply of polysilicon in China, supported by government subsidies and favorable electricity prices, has led to low prices and a challenging market environment. This oversupply has also affected major polysilicon producers like Wacker Chemie AG, leading to write-downs and losses. On the other hand, Chinese polysilicon manufacturers like Daqo New Energy are adapting their strategies to focus on higher-quality products and anticipate an increase in demand for monocrystalline silicon.  These developments suggest that the future prices of polysilicon will continue to be influenced by China's production capacity, government support, and market conditions. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon industry, particularly in China, to closely monitor these factors and adjust their projections and strategies accordingly./n

According to a news article from pv magazine Germany, Wacker Chemie AG, a major polysilicon producer, has announced that it will need to make an extraordinary write-down of approximately ‚Ç¨750 million on the balance sheet value of its polysilicon production assets. The company attributes this write-down to China's construction of new solar installations falling short of initial expectations and the high polysilicon overcapacity in China. This write-down has resulted in Wacker's polysilicon division going from a slightly positive result to a loss before interest and tax of around ‚Ç¨750 million. However, the company will receive insurance payment receipts of ‚Ç¨113 million related to a closure in 2017, which will help to dampen the impact of the loss.  Wacker Chemie had already adjusted its full-year expectations in October due to the lack of a solar-market recovery and low prices for polysilicon used in photovoltaic applications. The company's chief financial officer, Tobias Ohler, pointed to the Chinese government's subsidies and favorable electricity prices for polysilicon producers as the main reasons for the oversupply of polysilicon. He also mentioned that the company has limited visibility on how the market will develop.  This news indicates that the Chinese government's support of domestic polysilicon manufacturers has led to significant capacity expansions and reduced manufacturing costs, resulting in oversupply and low prices for polysilicon. This oversupply and low pricing environment have negatively impacted Wacker Chemie's polysilicon division, leading to the need for a major write-down. It suggests that the Chinese government's policies and actions will continue to have a significant effect on the future prices of polysilicon in the global market, particularly in China./n

The Ministry of Commerce in China has announced that anti-dumping duties on U.S. and South Korean-made polysilicon will remain in place for another five years. This decision is expected to have a significant impact on the future prices of polysilicon in the global market, particularly in China. Norwegian poly producer REC Silicon, which manufactures most of its polysilicon in the U.S., has stated that the extension of duties was expected and is part of a pre-planned tariff review. Despite this, REC Silicon believes that the Phase 1 trade agreement between the U.S. and China, which includes a commitment from China to purchase solar-grade polysilicon from the U.S., will not be affected by the duties. The company expects the trade deal to include polysilicon, regardless of the anti-dumping duties. REC Silicon, along with other U.S. polysilicon manufacturers, has been heavily impacted by China's imposition of tariffs on U.S. polysilicon while subsidizing its own domestic industry. This has led to overcapacity of polysilicon in China and has negatively affected the global industry. The inclusion of polysilicon in the Phase 1 trade agreement is seen as a recognition by U.S. government officials of the strategic significance of the U.S. polysilicon industry. The three remaining U.S. polysilicon manufacturers, REC Silicon, Wacker Polysilicon, and Hemlock Semiconductor Operations, have expressed hope that the partial restoration of access to China's polysilicon market will improve the outlook for U.S. polysilicon producers. However, they emphasize the need for the U.S. to continue developing and strengthening critical links in the solar value and supply chains to support the industry./n

China has decided to extend tariffs on solar-grade polysilicon sourced from the US and South Korea for another five years, starting from January 20, 2020. This decision comes after an investigation by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) to determine whether to continue the anti-dumping and countervailing duties that have been in place since 2014. The MOFCOM ruled that if the countervailing measures are terminated, subsidies for imported solar-grade polysilicon from the US may continue, causing damage to the domestic polysilicon industry. This decision is seen as a blow to US polysilicon makers, especially as it comes shortly after the signing of Phase I of the US-China trade agreement, which includes a commitment from China to purchase more US goods and services, including polysilicon. However, Norwegian polysilicon manufacturer REC Silicon remains optimistic that the trade agreement will still include polysilicon, despite the extended tariffs. The company expects China to fulfill its commitment to purchase solar-grade polysilicon from the US under the trade agreement. REC Silicon also mentioned that it will assess the market for solar-grade polysilicon before making a decision on whether to restart production at its Moses Lake facility in the US./n

According to recent news, China has decided to extend tariffs on solar-grade polysilicon sourced from the US and South Korea for another five years. This decision comes into effect immediately, starting from January 20, 2020. The Chinese Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) stated that the countervailing measures will continue to prevent damage to the domestic solar-grade polysilicon industry. This move is seen as a blow to US polysilicon makers who were hoping for a resolution in the ongoing trade conflict between the US and China.  The extension of tariffs on US and South Korean polysilicon comes after the signing of Phase I of a bilateral Trade Agreement between the US and China. Under this agreement, China has committed to purchasing at least $200 billion more in goods and services from the US over the next two years, including polysilicon. However, the MOFCOM decision indicates that the countervailing measures will remain in place despite the trade agreement.  Norwegian polysilicon manufacturer REC Silicon, which has been affected by the tariffs, expressed anticipation of the MOFCOM decision and stated its commitment to working closely with the US Trade Representative (USTR) to fulfill China's solar-grade polysilicon purchase commitment. REC Silicon also mentioned that it will assess the market for solar-grade polysilicon in light of the Phase I trade agreement.  The extension of tariffs on US and South Korean polysilicon is expected to have a significant impact on the future prices of polysilicon. The tariffs will increase the cost of importing polysilicon into China, which could lead to higher prices for polysilicon in the Chinese and global PV markets. This could also result in a price war between companies as they try to maintain their competitiveness in the market.  Furthermore, the MOFCOM decision reflects China's determination to establish a strong and self-sufficient domestic polysilicon industry. China has been focused on protecting and promoting its domestic polysilicon industry for years, and this decision reaffirms its commitment to this goal. The decision also highlights the geopolitical conflicts surrounding polysilicon, as it is a key raw material for PV modules and a crucial component in the solar industry.  In addition to the tariffs, the news also mentions the capacity loss of 52,000 MT in Gunsan, South Korea, and the expansion of a second polysilicon plant in Malaysia by a Chinese competitor, Tongwei. These developments further indicate the competitive landscape and the ambitions of the Chinese polysilicon industry.  Overall, the extension of tariffs on US and South Korean polysilicon, along with other factors such as capacity loss and expansion plans, will have a significant impact on the future prices of polysilicon in the Chinese and global PV markets. Companies operating in the polysilicon industry will need to carefully analyze these developments and make strategic decisions to navigate the changing market dynamics./n

Tongwei has issued a mid-term development plan outlining its production capacity targets for high-purity crystalline silicon and solar cell businesses. According to the plan, Tongwei aims to achieve an accumulated production capacity of 80,000 tons in 2020 for high-purity crystalline silicon, with a focus on mono-crystalline materials accounting for over 85% and N-type materials accounting for 40%-80%. The production cost and cash cost are expected to be in the range of 30,000-40,000 yuan/ton and 20,000-30,000 yuan/ton respectively, indicating a sharp decrease in production capacity cost.  In addition, Tongwei aims to achieve an accumulated production capacity of 30 GW-40 GW in 2020 for the solar cell business, with a focus on new products such as Perc+, Topcon, and HJT. The strategy layout should be compatible with all specifications of Series 210 and below, and the non-silicon cost for Perc should be lower than 0.18 yuan/w.  This news is significant because Tongwei is a major player in the polysilicon industry in China, and its production capacity targets and cost reduction plans indicate a potential increase in supply of polysilicon in the market. This increase in supply could potentially lead to a decrease in polysilicon prices in the future.  Another news that has a significant effect on future polysilicon prices is the achievement by Daqo New Energy, a major China-based polysilicon producer, of an industry record low average total production cost of primarily monocrystalline-grade polysilicon. In the fourth quarter of 2019, Daqo achieved a production cost of US$6.38/kg, and it expects even lower costs of approximately US$6.10/kg for the first quarter of 2020. Daqo plans to operate its factories at full capacity and aims to produce approximately 18,000MT to 19,000MT of polysilicon in the first quarter of 2020.  This news is significant because Daqo's achievement of record low production costs indicates its ability to produce polysilicon at a lower cost, which could potentially lead to a decrease in polysilicon prices in the market. Additionally, Daqo's plan to operate at full capacity and increase production further suggests an increase in supply, which could also contribute to a decrease in prices.  Overall, these news articles suggest that there may be an increase in the supply of polysilicon in the market due to the production capacity targets and cost reduction plans of major players like Tongwei and Daqo. This increase in supply could potentially lead to a decrease in polysilicon prices in the future./n

Based on the news articles, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.   Firstly, Tongwei Co., Ltd., a listed PV company in China, has announced its mid-term development plan, which includes targets for high-purity crystalline silicon production capacity. The company aims to reach production capacities of 80,000 tons in 2020, 115,000-150,000 tons in 2021, 150,000-220,000 tons in 2022, and 220,000-290,000 tons in 2023. This indicates a significant increase in production capacity, which could potentially lead to a decrease in polysilicon prices due to higher supply.  Secondly, Wacker Chemie, a major polysilicon producer, has stated that it expects further losses from its polysilicon division due to continued pricing pressure. While the company expects a slight increase in polysilicon sales in 2020, it also anticipates high average selling prices (ASPs) due to a focus on higher grade polysilicon production. This suggests that there may be a price war between companies, with some focusing on higher grade polysilicon to maintain higher ASPs.  Thirdly, Daqo New Energy, another major China-based polysilicon producer, has achieved record low production costs for monocrystalline-grade polysilicon. In the fourth quarter of 2019, the company's average total production cost was $6.38/kg, and it expects even lower costs of approximately $6.10/kg in the first quarter of 2020. This indicates that Daqo New Energy is able to produce polysilicon at a lower cost, which could potentially lead to lower prices in the market.  Lastly, the COVID-19 crisis and geopolitical conflicts may also have an impact on polysilicon prices. The crisis has prompted companies to set up crisis response task forces to ensure business continuity, including assessing supply chains and logistics. This suggests that disruptions in the supply chain could potentially affect polysilicon prices. Additionally, the crash of oil prices due to the crisis may challenge the plans of oil and gas giants to finance a shift to renewables. This could potentially impact the demand for polysilicon and subsequently affect prices.  In summary, the news indicates that there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. These include the increase in production capacity by Tongwei Co., Ltd., the pricing pressure faced by Wacker Chemie, the record low production costs achieved by Daqo New Energy, and the potential impact of the COVID-19 crisis and geopolitical conflicts. These factors suggest that there may be a price war between companies, with some focusing on higher grade polysilicon, and that disruptions in the supply chain and changes in demand could affect prices./n

According to recent news, Longi Green Energy Technology, a leading monocrystalline module manufacturer, has reported solid financial results for fiscal 2019 and the first quarter of 2020. The company recorded a significant increase in revenue and net profit compared to the previous year. In 2019, Longi's revenue reached RMB32.9 billion, a 49.6% increase from 2018, and its net profit increased by 106.4% to reach RMB5.28 billion. The positive trend continued in the first quarter of 2020, with revenue reaching RMB8.6 billion, a 50.6% increase year on year, and net profit reaching RMB1.86 billion, a 204.9% increase compared to the previous year.  Longi's wafer business also performed well, with sales revenue reaching RMB12.91 billion in 2019, a significant increase of 111.1% compared to the previous year. However, the average selling prices for wafers decreased by 11.7% in 2019. The company's PV module business achieved a turnover of RMB14.57 billion, an 11.3% increase year on year, with total shipments reaching 8.36 GW. Longi sold around 67% of its modules in overseas markets, increasing its global market share to 7% in 2019. The company expects shipments to reach 17 GW in 2020.  In terms of capacity, Longi's total wafer and module capacity reached 42 GW and 14 GW, respectively, at the end of 2019. The company expects these capacities to grow to 75 GW and 30 GW by the end of this year.  Additionally, Longi recently entered into a global, non-exclusive, cross-licensing agreement with Shin-Etsu Chemical Co, Ltd. This agreement allows Longi to legally apply Gallium-doped technology in its products on a global basis. Gallium-doped silicon can effectively solve Light Induced Degradation (LID) in P-type PERC modules. Longi has already addressed the high cost of Gallium-doped silicon through its own technological efforts and commits to offering it at the same price as Boron-doped silicon. This development is expected to make PV the most cost-effective method of power generation.  In terms of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, Li Wenxue, Vice President of Longi Group, believes that while the global photovoltaic market may experience a drop in installations by 10 GW, the overall impact is still controllable. Longi remains optimistic about China's photovoltaic market in 2020 and expects it to gradually overcome the pandemic's impact. However, Li also notes that the pandemic is likely to intensify competition in the industry and may lead to the elimination of companies with poor production and operational infrastructure. In the long run, this competition and the pandemic's impact are expected to accelerate the process of "survival of the fittest" and drive companies to improve their risk mitigation capabilities, ultimately benefiting the healthy and sustainable development of the industry.  Overall, the news suggests that Longi's strong financial performance, expansion plans, and technological advancements in Gallium-doped silicon could have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices. The company's success and commitment to cost-effective PV generation may influence market dynamics and potentially lead to increased competition among polysilicon manufacturers./n

According to recent news, Longi Green Energy Technology, a leading monocrystalline module manufacturer, has reported solid financial results for fiscal 2019 and the first quarter of 2020. The company recorded a revenue of RMB32.9 billion (US$4.65 billion) in 2019, a 49.6% increase from the previous year. Net profit also increased by 106.4% year on year to reach RMB5.28 billion. The company's gross margins for 2019 and the first quarter of 2020 were 31.7% and 31.9%, respectively. Longi's wafer business achieved sales revenue of RMB12.91 billion in 2019, with average selling prices of about RMB2.75 per piece. Its PV module business achieved a turnover of RMB14.57 billion in 2019, with total shipments of 8.36 GW. The company expects shipments to reach 17 GW in 2020. Longi's total wafer and module capacity is expected to grow to 75 GW and 30 GW, respectively, by the end of this year.  In addition, Aurinka Photovoltaic Group, a Spanish firm, has announced its intention to start upgraded metallurgical grade silicon (UMG-Si) production in Spain this year. This development brings hopes of a revival of PV manufacturing in Europe's unsubsidized solar market. Aurinka has developed a low-cost, novel metallurgical-grade-silicon purification process, which has a significantly lower carbon footprint compared to Asian rivals. This could potentially impact the polysilicon market as it offers a more sustainable and cost-effective alternative.  Furthermore, Longi Green Energy Technology has entered into a global, non-exclusive, cross-licensing agreement with Shin-Etsu Chemical Co, Ltd. This agreement allows LONGi to legally apply Gallium-doped technology in its products on a global basis. Gallium-doped silicon can effectively solve Light Induced Degradation (LID) in a P-type PERC module. LONGi has already addressed the high cost of Gallium-doped silicon through its own technological efforts and commits to offering it at the same price as Boron-doped silicon. This development could have an impact on the future pricing of polysilicon, as it provides a more cost-effective solution for the PV industry.  Overall, these developments in the PV industry, including the strong financial performance of Longi Green Energy Technology, the potential revival of PV manufacturing in Spain, and the cross-licensing agreement for Gallium-doped silicon, could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. It is important to closely monitor these developments and their potential impact on the polysilicon market, particularly in China and the global PV market./n

Recent news reports have highlighted a series of flash explosions at a GCL Silicon polysilicon plant in Xinjiang, China. These explosions have resulted in the plant taking more than 10% of the global supply of polysilicon out of production. The explosions are believed to have been caused by overpressure in the rectification and boron removal filter, leading to leakage of trichlorosilane gas which can react explosively with moisture in the air. As a result of the incident, the GCL facility is expected to be offline for a minimum of 3-6 months, with the investigation and repair work taking several months to complete.  This incident is expected to have a significant impact on the global polysilicon price, particularly as supplies of mono-grade material are already low. The reduced supply from the GCL facility, combined with the recent setback at Daqo's facility due to a small fire, is expected to result in a further 1-2% of global polysilicon capacity being offline. Daqo is estimated to lose around 1% of its expected annual output as a result of the fire.  In addition to these incidents, there have been other developments in the polysilicon market. Suntech has signed an agreement with the Wuxi municipal government in Jiangsu province for a new module capacity expansion plan. This includes the deployment of 1.5 GW of new module production lines and the construction of a new factory with a total capacity of 5 GW. Longi has also announced its new wafer prices, which do not significantly differ from previous prices.  Furthermore, TCL Tech has announced its plans to purchase 100% of Zhonghuan Semiconductor, while JinkoSolar and six other solar manufacturers have signed up to establish a new standard size for silicon wafers. These developments may have implications for the polysilicon market in the future.  Overall, the incidents at the GCL and Daqo facilities, combined with other developments in the market, are likely to have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices. The reduced supply and potential disruptions in production capacity are expected to drive prices higher in the coming months. It will be important for industry players to closely monitor these developments and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.   Firstly, the decline in the prices of PV products, including polysilicon, is expected to continue as the industry focuses on reducing costs and increasing efficiency. This is due to more supply expected in the market as manufacturers accelerate their product expansion. The industry is optimistic about overseas demand picking up in the second half of 2020, which could lead to a rebound in polysilicon prices.  Secondly, there have been reports of flash explosions at a GCL Silicon polysilicon plant in Xinjiang, China. These explosions have taken more than 10% of the global supply of polysilicon out of production. The investigation into the incident is expected to take at least four months, and the facility could be offline for 3-6 months. This disruption in supply could further impact polysilicon prices, especially considering that supplies of mono-grade material are already low.  Additionally, another Chinese polysilicon producer, Daqo, has also experienced setbacks. A small fire at one of its sites is expected to halt production for a month or two, resulting in a loss of around 1% of its expected annual output. This further reduction in supply could contribute to the increase in polysilicon prices.  Furthermore, the localized demand and supply of polysilicon in China is expected to improve in the coming months, especially from the fourth quarter of 2020 onward. Technological innovations, such as n-type silicon material, large-size silicon wafer, and thickness reduction, are contributing factors to the improvement of polysilicon quality. As demand improves, polysilicon prices are expected to stabilize and potentially increase.  Overall, the decline in prices, supply disruptions, and localized demand and supply dynamics in China will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon market to closely monitor these factors and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

The news related to polysilicon prices in the upcoming months suggests several significant factors that will impact the China and global PV market. One major factor is the weak demand and lower utilization rates, leading to losses for polysilicon producers such as Wacker Chemie. China's efforts to become self-sufficient in polysilicon production and the historically low average selling prices have further affected the market.  On the other hand, a major US residential installer, Sunnova, has reported a surge in revenues and earnings during Q2 2020, indicating that it is thriving despite the COVID-19 pandemic. This positive performance in the US residential solar industry suggests a potential recovery and positive figures for the remainder of the year.  In terms of government policies, the Indian government has extended its safeguard duty on solar equipment, specifically solar cells and modules from China, for one more year. This duty will impact the import of these products and may have implications for the polysilicon market.  Furthermore, the news highlights the decline in prices of PV products, including polysilicon, due to factors such as cost reduction efforts and increased efficiency in the industry. However, there is optimism that overseas demand will pick up in the second half of 2020, leading to a rebound in polysilicon prices.  The news also mentions the structural overcapacity for solar-grade polysilicon among Chinese competitors, which has contributed to lower prices and volume decline in sales for companies like Wacker Chemie. This overcapacity issue needs to be addressed to stabilize the market and improve profitability for polysilicon producers.  Additionally, the news mentions the challenges faced by REC Silicon, a Norwegian polysilicon and silane gas company, due to import duties imposed by China on U.S.-made polysilicon. This has led to the closure of REC's plant in Moses Lake, Washington, and a shift in focus towards the semiconductor industry and the sale of silane gas.  Overall, the news suggests that the future polysilicon prices will be influenced by factors such as demand and utilization rates, government policies, industry dynamics, and geopolitical conflicts. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon market, particularly in China, to closely monitor these developments and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

According to EnergyTrend, polysilicon prices in the PV industry supply chain have been rising since July due to supply disruptions caused by incidents at factories owned by Daqo and GCL-Poly. This has led to a sharp increase in prices, with monocrystalline silicon reaching RMB83 ($11.90)/kg and multicrystalline silicon reaching RMB55 ($0.79)/kg. Wafer giant Longi has also raised its wafer prices by 15% and increased the prices of G1 and M6 cells. The outlook for module prices is uncertain, but several major players have indicated that price increases are likely after the SNEC exhibition in Shanghai. These price increases could result in higher costs for balance of system and levelized cost of energy, potentially leading to project delays.  In addition to supply disruptions, the news also highlights the plans of State Power Investment Corp. (SPIC) to build a 4 GW renewable energy complex in China's Xinjiang region. This project will include solar PV, wind, concentrated solar power, and large-scale storage. Furthermore, Wuxi Suntech has completed the first phase of a 10 GW capacity expansion plan, with the company aiming to reach 10 GW by the end of the year. These developments indicate a growing demand for polysilicon in China.  However, the news also mentions a decline in the prices of PV products, which could further impact polysilicon prices. Zhang Sen, Secretary-General of the branch, attributes this decline to the industry's efforts to reduce costs and increase efficiency, as well as the expected increase in supply as manufacturers expand their production. Despite this decline, analysts believe that polysilicon demand will improve in the future, leading to a rebound in prices.  The news also highlights the challenges faced by German chemicals company Wacker Chemie, which attributes the decline in polysilicon prices to structural overcapacity among Chinese competitors. This has resulted in lower sales and earnings for Wacker Polysilicon. Similarly, Norwegian company REC Silicon ASA has faced challenges in the solar market due to import duties imposed by China on U.S.-made polysilicon. As a result, REC Silicon has sold off its remaining PV-grade polysilicon and is now focusing on the semiconductor industry and the sale of silane gas.  Overall, the news indicates that supply disruptions, government plans for renewable energy projects, and market dynamics in China and the global PV market are significant factors affecting polysilicon prices. While there are challenges and uncertainties, such as declining prices and trade tensions, there are also opportunities for growth and increased demand in the future./n

According to EnergyTrend, polysilicon prices in the PV industry supply chain have been rising since mid-July due to supply disruptions caused by incidents at factories owned by Daqo and GCL-Poly. This supply issue has now spread to solar cell and panel production, leading to a sharp increase in polysilicon prices. The price of silicon for monocrystalline products has risen to RMB83 ($11.90)/kg, while multicrystalline products are priced at RMB55 ($0.79)/kg. Wafer giant Longi has also increased its wafer prices by 15% and raised the prices of G1 and M6 cells. The outlook for module prices is uncertain, but several major players have confirmed that price increases are inevitable after the SNEC exhibition in Shanghai. These price increases could result in significant cost increases for balance of system and levelized cost of energy, leading some developers to postpone their projects to next year.  In addition to supply disruptions, the news also highlights the impact of government subsidies and geopolitical conflicts on polysilicon prices. State Power Investment Corp. (SPIC) plans to build a 4 GW renewable energy complex in China's Xinjiang region, which will include solar PV. This indicates continued government support for the PV market, which could affect polysilicon prices. Furthermore, the article mentions that China now hosts 85% of global polysilicon capacity, indicating the country's dominance in the market. Geopolitical conflicts, such as the tariff rate on polysilicon imports from Korea, have also affected prices, with Korean manufacturers losing their competitive edge due to higher costs and falling polysilicon prices.  The article also discusses the downward price trends in the polysilicon segment, which have led to reduced profits for manufacturers. Producers have expanded capacity into regions of western China with lower electricity prices to reduce production costs. However, only a few producers are able to run the business at low profit margins. The reduction in output and equipment maintenance planned by manufacturers to stabilize prices was halted after the closure of domestic solar-grade polysilicon plants by OCI and Wacker. This has resulted in continued downward trends in polysilicon prices.  The news also highlights the increasing demand for monocrystalline products, which account for over 80% of the market. Tier-1 manufacturers in China have been increasing mono-grade polysilicon production to align with this demand, while Tier-2 producers are modifying production lines to increase mono-grade output. However, there are technical barriers and limitations to these upgrades. PV InfoLink projects that mono-grade polysilicon prices will reach RMB66 ($9.45)/kg, while multi-grade prices will reach RMB39 ($5.58)/kg by the end of the year. With low inventories and increasing demand, prices for both mono- and multi-Si grade polysilicon are expected to rise.  Overall, the news highlights the significant impact of supply disruptions, government subsidies, geopolitical conflicts, and increasing demand on polysilicon prices. These factors indicate that polysilicon prices are likely to continue rising in the future./n

The recent events in the polysilicon industry have caused supply shortages and are expected to have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices. One of the major incidents was the halt in production at Tongwei's polysilicon facility in Sichuan, China, due to flood warnings. This temporary shutdown is expected to raise the potential for a price hike in polysilicon. Another incident occurred at GCL-Poly's production facility in Xinjiang, where explosions took 50,000 tons of production offline for an estimated three to nine months. Additionally, Daqo New Energy experienced a temporary production capacity shutdown due to minor fires from a gas leak.  These events are expected to have significant impacts on both pricing and supply in the short term, with the effects culminating in the third and fourth quarters of 2020 and lasting into the first half of 2021. The polysilicon industry has become a multi-billion-dollar industry, with the world consuming nearly half a million metric tons of solar-grade polysilicon annually. The price of polysilicon is affected by supply and demand, and any incremental demand can have a big impact on price.  Polysilicon producers are avoiding long-term fixed pricing deals and instead opting for spot pricing. This trend is expected to continue in the short term, with pricing remaining at elevated levels for at least six months as suppliers adjust to downstream production capacities. Module prices in China are expected to increase in the medium term due to recovering demand and temporary supply disruptions.  Despite the recent supply disruptions, there is still an ample supply of solar-grade polysilicon available for the sector. However, some non-China supply will need to be imported, leading to higher pricing until production capacity recovers. The demand for high-power panels, especially in China, is expected to increase towards the end of the year, further contributing to price increases.  Overall, the recent events in the polysilicon industry, including supply shortages and disruptions, are expected to have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices. The industry is likely to experience price hikes due to the unfortunate timing of these events and suppliers' efforts to recover margins following record lows in pricing./n

Recent events in the polysilicon industry have caused supply shortages and are expected to have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices. Tongwei, a major polysilicon producer in China, halted production at its facility in Sichuan due to flood warnings. This, along with previous incidents such as explosions at GCL-Poly's production facility and fires at Daqo New Energy, has led to disruptions in production and is expected to result in supply constraints in the short term.  Polysilicon is a critical component of solar cells, and the industry consumes nearly half a million metric tons of solar-grade polysilicon annually. The reduction in consumption over the years has led to a decrease in price, but recent events are likely to cause price fluctuations. Supply and demand play a significant role in determining the price of polysilicon, and any incremental demand can have a substantial impact on price.  Polysilicon producers are avoiding long-term fixed pricing deals and instead opting for spot pricing. This trend is expected to continue as producers adjust to downstream production capacities. Pricing is projected to remain elevated for at least six months as suppliers adapt to the disruptions and demand recovers. Module prices in China are expected to increase in the medium term due to recovering demand and temporary supply disruptions.  Despite the recent supply disruptions, there is still an ample supply of solar-grade polysilicon available. However, some non-China supply will need to be imported, leading to higher pricing until production capacity is restored. The demand for high-power panels, especially in China, is driving the increase in prices. Once the demand stabilizes, the technology is expected to remain in the market.  Buyers of polysilicon are facing short-term premiums or project delays due to the current pricing levels. Chinese projects are being pushed out several months until pricing becomes competitive again. International markets, such as Europe and India, can also expect significant short-term price increases. The impact of the recent explosions at GCL-Poly is not expected to significantly affect module makers, as many have diversified supply sources. However, bottlenecks may emerge due to high prices, leading some companies to defer projects.  In conclusion, the recent events in the polysilicon industry, including supply shortages and disruptions in production, are expected to have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices. Supply constraints and increased demand are likely to result in price fluctuations and elevated pricing for at least the next six months. Buyers may face short-term premiums or project delays, and the industry will need to absorb some of the cost increase to avoid stalling project pipelines./n

Recent events in the polysilicon industry have caused supply shortages and are expected to have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices. The price of polysilicon is affected by supply and demand, and any incremental demand can have a significant impact on price. Pricing is projected to remain elevated for at least six months as suppliers adapt to the disruptions and recover margins.  Despite the recent supply disruptions, there is still an ample supply of solar-grade polysilicon available. However, some non-China supply will need to be imported, leading to higher pricing until production recovers and buying activity subsides. The demand for high-power panels, especially in China, is driving the increase in prices. The industry expects stabilization once the demand for these panels is met.  Buyers of polysilicon are currently facing higher prices, which may result in project delays or the need to pay short-term premiums. Chinese projects are already being pushed out several months until pricing becomes competitive again. International markets, such as Europe and India, can also expect significant short-term price increases.  Overall, the recent events in the polysilicon industry, including supply disruptions and increased demand, are expected to have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices. Buyers will need to navigate higher prices and potential project delays, while suppliers adjust to the disruptions and recover margins./n

Recent events in the polysilicon industry have caused disruptions in supply, leading to potential shortages and price increases. In August, Tongwei halted production at its polysilicon facility in China due to flood warnings, adding to the already offline production caused by explosions at GCL-Poly's facility in Xinjiang. These incidents are expected to have significant impacts on pricing and supply in the short term, with the effects lasting into the first half of 2021. The pricing of polysilicon is affected by supply and demand, as well as incremental demand. In response to the recent supply disruptions, polysilicon producers are avoiding long-term fixed pricing and instead opting for spot pricing. This trend is expected to continue, with pricing remaining elevated for at least six months as suppliers adjust to downstream production capacities.  Despite the disruptions, there is still an ample supply of solar-grade polysilicon available in both domestic and international markets. However, some non-China supply will need to be imported, leading to higher pricing until production recovers and buying activity subsides. Price hikes in polysilicon can have ripple effects throughout the supply chain, potentially causing project delays or increased costs for buyers.  The impact of the supply disruptions is not expected to significantly affect any single module maker, as many have diversified supply sources. However, larger suppliers with significant ingoting and wafer cutting capacities may face bottlenecks due to high prices. Overall, the industry has adjusted to lower-priced modules, and sustained price increases above $10/kg would be unsustainable for many players.  In conclusion, the recent events in the polysilicon industry, including supply disruptions and increased demand, are expected to lead to potential shortages and price increases in the short term. While there is still an ample supply of polysilicon available, the industry will need to adjust to higher pricing until production recovers. Buyers may face short-term premiums or project delays, and the overall pricing impacts will depend on how soon expansions come online and market trends./n

According to the update provided by Xinte Energy, global polysilicon production capacity increased by 10% in the first half of 2020 compared to the same period in 2019. However, demand only rose by 11%, resulting in an 8,000-ton surplus. China, in particular, saw a significant increase in polysilicon production, manufacturing almost a third more than in the previous year. The country also imported 55,000 tons of polysilicon, indicating a glut in the market.  The oversupply of polysilicon was mainly attributed to the materials used to manufacture polysilicon ingots, with higher-efficiency monocrystalline silicon outpacing other feedstocks. Xinte Energy reported a 41% year-on-year decrease in the price of clean silicon materials and a 14% decrease in the price of monocrystalline-dense materials. However, the company noted that prices have rebounded recently due to incidents that affected global production capacity.  Despite the decrease in prices, Xinte Energy was able to turn a profit, with gross first-half profits of RMB626 million. However, this was a 27% decrease compared to the same period last year. Revenue from polysilicon manufacture increased, but revenue from solar and wind project development decreased due to the pandemic.  In terms of future supply, Tongwei Solar adjusted its monocrystalline silicon supply contract with LONGi Green Energy, increasing the number of wafers to be supplied from 1.6 billion to 2.6 billion pieces for 2021. This adjustment aligns with Tongwei's goal of expanding its solar cell production capacity to over 60GW by the end of 2022.  In terms of pricing, Longi and Tongwei released solar wafer and cell prices that remained almost unchanged from the previous announcement. Risen also began construction of a 15 GW cell and module factory, indicating further expansion in the industry.  Additionally, Xinte Energy announced that it will need more coal to fuel its operations due to an 11% increase in coal prices and a 7% increase in transport costs. The company also increased the maximum amount it can pay for coal from its controlling shareholder, TBEA.  Furthermore, Yingli, a major Chinese solar manufacturer, has applied for liquidation of its U.S.-listed parent company, Yingli Green Energy Holding Co Ltd, citing insolvency.  Overall, the news indicates an oversupply of polysilicon in the market, leading to a decrease in prices. However, there are signs of recovery and expansion in the industry, with companies adjusting supply contracts and investing in new production capacity. The increase in coal prices may also have an impact on the cost of polysilicon production./n
