Based on the news provided, there are several key factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.  1. Polysilicon Inventory: Major polysilicon producer Daqo New Energy has revised down its guided polysilicon sales volumes in the third quarter of 2020 due to customers postponing purchasing orders as market prices hit US$12.5/kg. This suggests that there may be a surplus of polysilicon in the market, which could potentially lead to a decrease in prices if demand does not catch up.  2. Price War Between Companies: Chinese solar manufacturers Longi and Tongwei have announced that their wafer and solar cell prices for November will remain unchanged. This indicates that there may not be a price war between these companies at the moment, which could stabilize polysilicon prices in the near future.  3. Government Subsidies: Power company China Huadian Corporation is planning to invest RMB8.52 billion (US$1.27 billion) in a 2.2 GW solar power station linked to a 220 MW/440 MWh storage system. This suggests that there is government support for renewable energy development, which could increase the demand for polysilicon and potentially drive up prices.  4. Geopolitical Conflicts: There is no specific news related to geopolitical conflicts on polysilicon in the provided information. However, it is important to note that any geopolitical conflicts, such as trade disputes or sanctions, could disrupt the supply chain and have a significant impact on polysilicon prices.  Overall, the current news suggests that there may be a surplus of polysilicon in the market, which could put downward pressure on prices. However, government support for renewable energy development and the absence of a price war between major Chinese solar manufacturers could help stabilize prices in the near future. It is important to closely monitor market dynamics and any potential geopolitical conflicts that could impact polysilicon prices./n

In recent news, major polysilicon producer Daqo New Energy has revised down its guided polysilicon sales volumes for the third quarter of 2020. This is due to customers postponing purchasing orders as market prices hit US$12.5/kg. The company had previously expected sales volumes of approximately 17,000MT to 17,500MT, but the actual sales were around 13,643MT. This decrease in sales volume can be attributed to the increase in polysilicon prices from US$7-7.50 per kilogram in the second quarter to the current US$11.50-12.50. However, Daqo expects the surplus stock to be cleared in the current quarter due to strong demand.  Another significant development in the polysilicon market is the deal struck by Scatec Solar to acquire leading hydropower developer SN Power for US$1.1 billion. This acquisition is seen as an important part of Scatec Solar's strategy to become a global, large-scale player across multiple renewable energy technologies. The potential for floating solar on hydro reservoirs is also being touted, which could have implications for the polysilicon market.  In terms of government policies, US President Donald Trump's plan to repeal the exemption for bifacial panels within Section 201 trade tariffs is facing opposition. Judge Katzmann of the US Court of International Trade is expected to rule against the government within the 15-day deadline and continue to allow the 201 bifacial exemption. This ruling could have an impact on the pricing and demand for polysilicon in the US market.  Furthermore, there have been developments in the production and supply chain of polysilicon. REC Silicon, a Norwegian polysilicon producer, has signed agreements to supply solar-grade polysilicon to a US customer and establish a production line for silicon anodes for lithium-ion batteries. This move is part of REC Silicon's efforts to be part of a non-Chinese silicon solar supply chain. The company has also signed cooperation agreements with solar manufacturing start-up Violet Power and Group 14 Technologies to establish commercial silicon anode production facilities. These developments could potentially affect the supply and demand dynamics of polysilicon.  Lastly, Changzhou Fusion New Material Co., Ltd. has invested CNY 500 million in a project to develop semiconductor and crystalline silicon conductive materials. This investment will increase the company's production capacity of silver paste products and enhance its core competitiveness. The company is a global leader in the sales and technological level of conductive materials, and its sales for 2020 are expected to exceed CNY 2 billion.  Overall, these news developments in the polysilicon market, including changes in sales volumes, acquisitions, government policies, and production and supply chain developments, could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon market, particularly in China, to closely monitor these developments and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

In recent news, major polysilicon producer Daqo New Energy has revised down its guided polysilicon sales volumes for the third quarter of 2020. This is due to customers postponing purchasing orders as market prices hit US$12.5/kg. The company had previously expected sales volumes of approximately 17,000MT to 17,500MT, but the actual sales were around 13,643MT. This decrease in sales volume can be attributed to the increase in polysilicon prices from US$7-7.50 per kilogram in the second quarter to the current US$11.50-12.50. However, Daqo expects the surplus stock to be cleared in the current quarter due to strong demand.  Another significant development in the polysilicon market is the deal struck by Scatec Solar to acquire leading hydropower developer SN Power for US$1.1 billion. This acquisition is seen as an important part of Scatec Solar's strategy to become a global, large-scale player across multiple renewable energy technologies. The potential for floating solar on hydro reservoirs is also being touted, which could have implications for the polysilicon market.  In terms of government policies, US President Donald Trump's plan to repeal the exemption for bifacial panels within Section 201 trade tariffs is facing opposition. Judge Katzmann of the US Court of International Trade is expected to rule against the government within the 15-day deadline and continue to allow the 201 bifacial exemption. This ruling could have an impact on the demand and pricing of polysilicon.  Furthermore, there have been developments in the production and supply chain of polysilicon. REC Silicon, a Norwegian polysilicon producer, has signed agreements to supply solar-grade polysilicon to a US customer and establish a production line for silicon anodes for lithium-ion batteries. This move is part of REC Silicon's efforts to be part of a non-Chinese silicon solar supply chain. The company has also signed cooperation agreements with solar manufacturing start-up Violet Power and Group 14 Technologies to establish commercial silicon anode production facilities. These developments could potentially affect the supply and demand dynamics of polysilicon.  Lastly, Changzhou Fusion New Material Co., Ltd. has invested CNY 500 million in a project to develop semiconductor and crystalline silicon conductive materials. This investment will increase the company's production capacity of silver paste products and enhance its core competitiveness. The company is a global leader in the sales and technological level of conductive materials, and its sales for 2020 are expected to exceed CNY 2 billion.  Overall, these news developments in the polysilicon market, including changes in sales volumes, acquisitions, government policies, and production and supply chain developments, could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon market, particularly in China, to closely monitor these developments and assess their potential impact on the market./n

Based on the news articles, there are several factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.  Firstly, there is a strong demand for polysilicon, which has led to an increase in prices. Daqo, a polysilicon producer, has upgraded its annual production forecast due to the strong demand. This suggests that the current surplus stock of polysilicon is expected to be cleared in the current quarter.  Secondly, there is a price war between companies in the polysilicon market. GCL-Poly Energy Holdings, another polysilicon producer, has taken steps to clear up speculation about its plans for a new facility. This indicates that competition among companies in the market is intense, which could potentially lead to price fluctuations.  Thirdly, government subsidies play a role in the polysilicon market. The news articles mention a tax settlement for Norwegian polysilicon producer REC Silicon, which could have a positive impact on the company's fortunes. Government support and incentives can influence the production and pricing of polysilicon.  Lastly, geopolitical conflicts can also affect polysilicon prices. The trade tariffs imposed by China on U.S. polysilicon in the past have had a significant impact on the business of REC Silicon. However, the company has recently signed agreements to establish non-Chinese supply chains, which could help mitigate the effects of such conflicts in the future.  In conclusion, the news suggests that the strong demand for polysilicon, price wars between companies, government subsidies, and geopolitical conflicts are all factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. As a strategic expert, it would be important to closely monitor these factors and their potential impact on the China and global PV market./n

In recent news, Norwegian polysilicon producer REC Silicon has signed agreements to supply solar-grade polysilicon to a U.S. customer and establish a production line for silicon anodes for lithium-ion batteries at its Moses Lake site. This is a significant development for the company, as it has been struggling due to trade tariffs imposed by China on U.S. polysilicon. The agreements with the U.S. customer and the establishment of a non-Chinese supply chain could potentially turn around REC Silicon's fortunes.  Additionally, REC Silicon has signed a cooperation agreement with solar manufacturing start-up Violet Power and Washington state-based Group 14 Technologies to establish commercial silicon anode production facilities at its Moses Lake site. This deal would require fresh capital, and REC Silicon has completed the first round of a private shares issue to raise funds.  In another development, Changzhou Fusion New Material Co., Ltd. has invested CNY 500 million to increase its production capacity of silver paste products. This investment will enhance the company's ability to leverage economies of scale and strengthen its core competitiveness. The company's R&D center will focus on cutting-edge research and development of silver pastes and semiconductor materials.  Furthermore, Tongwei Group, a Chinese polysilicon and solar cell manufacturer, has begun construction on a high-purity crystalline silicon plant. The plant, worth RMB 20.5 billion, is expected to have an annual production capacity of 40,000 tons and be operational in 2021. Tongwei Group is also working on a polysilicon project with a capacity of 35,000 tons, which is scheduled to come online by the end of September 2021. These projects will significantly increase Tongwei's polysilicon production capacity, making it the world's largest silicon manufacturer.  Lastly, China Glass Holdings Limited has decided to expand its production lines to include ultra-white float glass for the production of photovoltaic modules. This expansion is in response to the short supply of solar glass, a key component in PV module production.  These developments in the polysilicon industry, including supply agreements, production expansions, and investments, are likely to have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. The establishment of non-Chinese supply chains and the increase in production capacity could potentially lead to increased competition and lower prices in the market. Additionally, the expansion of production lines for solar glass indicates a growing demand for photovoltaic modules, which could also impact polysilicon prices./n

Based on the news articles, there are several factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.   Firstly, Trina Solar has recently signed a deal to buy 30,000-37,600 tons of mono-grade polysilicon from Daqo New Energy, with the contract running until December 2023. This comes after Trina signed a 72,000-ton supply deal with Tongwei. These large-scale purchases by Trina indicate a strong demand for polysilicon, which could potentially drive up prices in the future.  Additionally, Tongwei Group, a Chinese polysilicon and solar cell manufacturer, has begun construction on a high-purity crystalline silicon plant with an annual production capacity of 40,000 tons. This plant, along with another polysilicon project with a capacity of 35,000 tons, will increase Tongwei's annual polysilicon production capacity to 155,000 tons, making it the world's largest silicon manufacturer. This increase in production capacity could potentially lead to a surplus of polysilicon in the market, which may put downward pressure on prices.  Furthermore, China Glass Holdings Limited, a major glass manufacturer, has decided to expand its production lines to include ultra-white float glass for the production of photovoltaic modules. This expansion is in response to the shortage of solar glass, a key component in the production of PV modules. The increased supply of solar glass could potentially lower the production costs of PV modules, which may indirectly impact the demand and prices of polysilicon.  Lastly, the news articles mention the sales figures of electric vehicles in China. While the sales of electric vehicles have increased compared to the previous year, they have not yet fully recovered to pre-Covid-19 levels. The demand for electric vehicles is closely tied to the demand for PV modules, as they are often used in conjunction with solar energy systems. Therefore, the recovery of the electric vehicle market could potentially drive up the demand for PV modules and subsequently the demand for polysilicon.  In summary, the news articles suggest that the demand for polysilicon is strong, with major companies like Trina Solar and Tongwei Group making large-scale purchases and expanding their production capacities. However, the potential surplus of polysilicon from Tongwei's increased production capacity and the increased supply of solar glass could put downward pressure on prices. The recovery of the electric vehicle market could also impact the demand for polysilicon. Overall, the future prices of polysilicon will depend on the balance between supply and demand in the market./n

In recent news, Trina Solar, a major solar manufacturing company, has secured another 30,000-ton slice of the global polysilicon market. This comes shortly after signing a 72,000-ton supply deal with Tongwei. Trina has also signed a contract with Daqo New Energy to purchase 30,000-37,600 tons of mono-grade polysilicon until December 2023. The price of the polysilicon supplied will be set monthly. These deals indicate Trina's efforts to secure a stable supply of polysilicon for its solar manufacturing operations.  Additionally, Trina Solar has entered into other significant agreements in the industry. They have invested $314 million in Tongwei, which includes a minority stake in a new polysilicon fab. This fab will produce solar ingots, wafers, and cells. Trina has also signed a contract worth RMB2.1 billion ($319 million) to acquire photovoltaic glass from Changzhou Almaden. This deal will run from January until December 2023. These agreements highlight Trina's commitment to expanding its solar manufacturing capabilities and securing the necessary materials for production.  In other news, JinkoSolar, another leading solar module manufacturer, has signed a long-term purchase agreement with Tongwei for nearly 100,000 metric tons of solar polysilicon and cells. This agreement allows JinkoSolar to ensure a stable supply of polycrystalline silicon for its operations. The price for any additional orders will be negotiated based on market conditions at the time. This partnership with Tongwei is seen as a strategic move to enhance JinkoSolar's competitive edge in the solar industry.  These developments in the polysilicon market indicate a growing demand for the material in the solar industry. Companies like Trina Solar and JinkoSolar are actively securing long-term supply agreements to ensure a stable supply of polysilicon for their manufacturing operations. This increased demand, coupled with the strategic partnerships between manufacturers and suppliers, may have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. It is important for industry players to closely monitor these developments and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

According to a report by Bernreuter Research, the expansion of Chinese polysilicon manufacturers is leading to a reorganization of the solar-grade poly industry. The report predicts that the world will need a significant increase in the volume of solar power generation capacity deployed to avoid a glut of polysilicon as early as 2022. The analyst suggests that 270 GW of new PV will need to be deployed in 2023 to avoid oversupply, with China being the largest supplier of semiconductor and solar-grade material.  The demand for monocrystalline polysilicon, particularly from companies like Longi Solar and Zhonghuan Semiconductor, is expected to drive supply constraints next year and potentially lead to oversupply. Tongwei, a Chinese poly maker, has already surpassed German manufacturer Wacker as the world's largest polysilicon supplier. Additionally, GCL-Poly has plans for significant expansion in fluidized bed reactor production.  The shift towards higher-grade, monocrystalline polysilicon production has resulted in the closure of 14 small and medium-sized Chinese rivals between 2017 and last year. South Korean producers have halted production, REC Silicon has mothballed its Moses Lake fab in the U.S., and Hemlock Semiconductor has halved production. This industry consolidation has removed 275,000 metric tons of annual poly production capacity.  Bernreuter predicts that Chinese polysilicon producers will drive the price of the raw material below $8/kg in 2022, and possibly below $7/kg. This suggests that polysilicon prices will continue to decrease in the coming years.  In terms of government policies, China aims to make progress in building an ecological civilization and achieving green transformation in production and lifestyle. These goals may have implications for the development and protection of territorial space, which could impact the polysilicon market.  In terms of recent news, LONGi, a major solar company, has signed a five-year polysilicon material purchase agreement with Xinte New Energy. The agreement ensures a stable supply of polysilicon raw materials for LONGi and accounts for a significant portion of their operating costs.  Overall, the expansion of Chinese polysilicon manufacturers, the demand for monocrystalline polysilicon, industry consolidation, and government policies on green transformation are all factors that will significantly impact future polysilicon prices. The market is expected to see increased supply, potential oversupply, and decreasing prices in the coming years./n

According to a report by Bernreuter Research, the expansion of Chinese polysilicon manufacturers is leading to a reorganization of the solar-grade poly industry. The report predicts that the world will need to deploy 270 GW of new PV in 2023 to avoid polysilicon oversupply. This is a significant increase from the analyst's prediction of 127 GW for this year. The report also highlights the dominance of Chinese companies in the polysilicon market, with almost 75% of the world's semiconductor and solar-grade material coming from China.   The demand for monocrystalline polysilicon, particularly from companies like Longi Solar and Zhonghuan Semiconductor, is expected to drive supply constraints next year and potentially lead to oversupply in the future. Tongwei, a Chinese poly maker, has already surpassed German manufacturer Wacker as the world's largest polysilicon supplier. GCL-Poly, another Chinese company, has also announced plans for significant expansion in polysilicon production.  The report also notes that the rush towards higher-grade, monocrystalline polysilicon production has forced several small and medium-sized Chinese rivals out of business. Additionally, all three South Korean polysilicon producers have halted production, and Norwegian business REC Silicon has mothballed its Moses Lake fab in the U.S. Hemlock Semiconductor, owned by Corning Inc, has also halved production. These factors, along with the consolidation in the industry, have resulted in the removal of 275,000 metric tons of annual poly production capacity.  Bernreuter predicts that Chinese polysilicon producers will drive the price of the raw material below $8/kg in 2022, and possibly below $7/kg. This indicates a potential price war between companies as they compete for market share.  In terms of government subsidies and policies, China's proposed development targets for the 14th Five-Year Plan period (2021-2025) include a focus on building an ecological civilization and achieving notable results in the green transformation of production and lifestyle. This suggests that there may be increased support for the development and deployment of solar power, which could impact the demand for polysilicon.  Overall, the news indicates that the expansion of Chinese polysilicon manufacturers, the demand for monocrystalline polysilicon, the consolidation in the industry, and government policies will all have significant effects on future polysilicon prices. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon market, particularly in China, to closely monitor these developments and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

According to a report by Bernreuter Research, the expansion of Chinese polysilicon manufacturers is leading to a reorganization of the solar-grade poly industry. These developments indicate the strong demand for polysilicon in the solar industry, particularly for higher-grade, monocrystalline polysilicon. The expansion of Chinese polysilicon manufacturers and the consolidation of the industry have resulted in supply constraints and the closure of smaller producers. This, in turn, is expected to drive down the price of polysilicon in the coming years. The long-term purchase agreements signed by LONGi and Trina Solar aim to secure a stable supply of polysilicon raw materials and ensure their competitiveness in the market./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. One important factor is the increasing demand for non-Xinjiang-produced polysilicon. Due to concerns over labor issues and trace of origin, wafer makers and vertically integrated companies are opting to source polysilicon from regions outside of Xinjiang. This has led to manufacturers signing long-term contracts to ensure a certain ratio of non-Xinjiang-produced polysilicon. It is predicted that more than 70% of the world's polysilicon has already been booked this year, and the share of long-term contracts may increase. This trend has also prompted big manufacturers to form partnerships, such as the project signed by Tongwei and Trina.  Another factor that will impact polysilicon prices is the expected growth in capacity across the supply chain in the second half of 2021. This growth in capacity may lead to a transition period after the June 30 installation rush, causing module prices to slowly decrease. Unsubsidized projects are also likely to increase during this period. In response to this market situation, large module manufacturers are expected to initiate price wars, forcing wafer, cell, and even polysilicon manufacturers to react promptly.  In addition to these market dynamics, government subsidies and geopolitical conflicts can also affect polysilicon prices. Government subsidies can incentivize the production and consumption of polysilicon, leading to changes in supply and demand dynamics. Geopolitical conflicts, such as the situation in Xinjiang, can disrupt the supply chain and impact the availability and cost of polysilicon.  Overall, the news suggests that the future prices of polysilicon will be influenced by factors such as the demand for non-Xinjiang-produced polysilicon, capacity growth in the supply chain, government subsidies, and geopolitical conflicts. It is important for stakeholders in the polysilicon market to closely monitor these developments and make strategic decisions accordingly./n

The news related to polysilicon that has a significant effect on future polysilicon prices includes several key points. Overall, the news suggests that the polysilicon market is undergoing significant changes, with partnerships between major players, shifts in sourcing, and potential price wars. The news related to polysilicon that has a significant effect on future polysilicon prices includes several key points.   Firstly, major polysilicon producer GCL-Poly Energy Holdings has signed a supply deal with LONGi, one of the largest enterprises in the solar industry. This deal marks the first time that these two rivals have entered into a major business agreement together. GCL-Poly Energy Holdings will supply LONGi's subsidiaries with a total of 91,400MT of polysilicon from March 2021 to the end of 2023. This indicates a strong demand for polysilicon in the market.  Secondly, there is a trend among manufacturers to source polysilicon from non-Xinjiang regions due to concerns over labor and trace of origin. This has led to an increase in long-term contracts for non-Xinjiang-produced polysilicon, with more than 70% of the world's polysilicon already booked this year. This trend has also prompted major manufacturers to form partnerships, such as the project signed by Tongwei and Trina. Suppliers outside of Xinjiang are expected to have an advantage in sales due to these factors.  Thirdly, PV InfoLink predicts that mono-grade and multi-grade polysilicon prices will reach CNY 65/kg and CNY 38/kg respectively by the end of 2021. The estimated module price based on the mono-grade polysilicon price is CNY 1.5/W. However, as capacity grows across the supply chain in the second half of 2021, the market situation may experience a transition period after the June 30 installation rush, leading to a gradual decrease in module prices. This could also lead to the initiation of price wars by large module manufacturers, forcing wafer, cell, and even polysilicon manufacturers to react promptly.  Additionally, Xinte Energy, a major China-based polysilicon producer, is planning to develop the world's single largest polysilicon production complex near the city of Baotou, Inner Mongolia. This facility is expected to produce 200,000MT of polysilicon per annum. With global solar demand forecasted to increase significantly in 2021, there is limited polysilicon supply in China. Market forecasters expect only around 150,000MT of new polysilicon capacity to come on-stream in 2021, with larger amounts not expected until later in 2022 and beyond. This indicates a potential supply-demand imbalance in the market, which could further impact polysilicon prices.  Furthermore, leading monocrystalline wafer producer LONGi Green Energy has signed a three-year high-purity polysilicon supply deal from OCI Malaysia. This is another example of a company securing key polysilicon supply contracts due to capacity constraints in China and the increasing demand for p-type mono wafers. LONGi Solar, a subsidiary of LONGi, has set targets to ship around 45GW of PV modules in 2021. LONGi Solar has also secured a solar flat glass procurement contract with Flat Glass Group, ensuring the availability of glass for its module assembly plants.  Overall, these news developments indicate a strong demand for polysilicon in the market, with limited supply capacity in China. The sourcing of polysilicon from non-Xinjiang regions, the potential for price wars among manufacturers, and the expansion of polysilicon production facilities all contribute to the future polysilicon prices./n

Suppliers outside of Xinjiang are expected to have an advantage in sales due to the labor concerns and trace of origin. Based on the estimated mono-grade polysilicon price, the module price is expected to be around CNY 1.5/W. However, as capacity grows in the second half of 2021, the market situation may experience a transition period after the June 30 installation rush, leading to a gradual decrease in module prices. This could also lead to the initiation of price wars by large module manufacturers, forcing wafer, cell, and even polysilicon manufacturers to react promptly.  In addition to these market dynamics, there are also significant developments in polysilicon production capacity. Xinte Energy, a major polysilicon producer in China, is planning to build the world's largest polysilicon production complex in Inner Mongolia. The facility is expected to produce 200,000MT of polysilicon per annum. This expansion is necessary to meet the increasing global solar demand, which is forecasted to reach between 150GW to 200GW in 2021. However, new polysilicon capacity is limited in China, and major producers are capacity-constrained until new plants are built and ramped up. It is estimated that only around 150,000MT of new polysilicon capacity will come online in 2021, with larger amounts expected in 2022 and beyond.  Overall, these developments in the polysilicon market, including supply deals, the focus on non-Xinjiang-produced polysilicon, and capacity expansions, will have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices. Manufacturers will need to carefully consider their sourcing strategies and partnerships to ensure a stable supply of polysilicon and competitive pricing in the evolving market./n

According to recent news, major polysilicon producers in China, GCL and LONGi, have signed a significant supply deal. GCL-Poly Energy Holdings will supply LONGi's subsidiaries with a total of 91,400MT of polysilicon from March 2021 to the end of 2023. This collaboration between rivals is a notable development in the industry.  Furthermore, there is a growing trend among manufacturers to source polysilicon from non-Xinjiang regions due to concerns over labor and trace of origin. This has led to an increase in long-term contracts, with more than 70% of the world's polysilicon already booked. Suppliers outside of Xinjiang are expected to have an advantage in sales due to these factors.  PV InfoLink predicts that mono-grade and multi-grade polysilicon prices will reach CNY 65/kg and CNY 38/kg, respectively, by the end of 2021. With the increase in capacity across the supply chain in the second half of 2021, there may be a transition period after the June 30 installation rush, leading to a gradual decrease in module prices. This could also result in the initiation of price wars by large module manufacturers, forcing wafer, cell, and polysilicon manufacturers to react promptly.  In terms of capacity expansion, Xinte Energy, a major polysilicon producer in China, is planning to develop the world's largest polysilicon production complex. The facility, located in Inner Mongolia, is expected to produce 200,000MT of polysilicon per annum. This expansion is necessary to meet the increasing global solar demand, which is forecasted to reach between 150GW to 200GW in 2021. However, new polysilicon capacity is limited in China, with only around 150,000MT expected to come online this year. Larger capacity expansions are not expected until later in 2022 and beyond.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices are likely to remain high due to capacity constraints and increasing demand. The collaboration between GCL and LONGi, as well as the expansion plans of Xinte Energy, indicate the efforts being made to address these challenges. However, the market situation may experience fluctuations, especially after the installation rush in June, leading to potential price decreases. It is important for manufacturers to adapt and respond to these changes in order to remain competitive in the polysilicon market./n

In recent news, major players in the solar industry, GCL and LONGi, have entered into a significant polysilicon supply deal. This marks the first time that these rivals have collaborated on a major business deal. GCL-Poly Energy Holdings, a major polysilicon producer, will supply LONGi's seven monocrystalline ingot/wafer subsidiaries with a total of 91,400 metric tons of polysilicon from March 2021 to the end of 2023.  Another polysilicon manufacturer, Daqo New Energy Corp, has also announced a three-year supply agreement with Zhonghuan Semiconductor. Under this agreement, Daqo will supply 41,000 metric tons of polysilicon to Zhonghuan for its monocrystalline wafer production. The prices of polysilicon will be determined on a monthly basis, and Zhonghuan will make an upfront payment as part of the contract.  Furthermore, TBEA-owned poly peer Xinte Energy is planning to expand its annual production capacity by 100,000 metric tons with a new factory in Inner Mongolia, China. The company's shareholders will vote on whether to proceed with the construction of the facility. This expansion is expected to contribute to the overall supply of polysilicon in the market.  In addition, panel maker JA Solar has approved a plan to invest RMB5 billion in new wafer manufacturing capacity in Inner Mongolia. The planned factory will have a capacity of 20 GW and will be built within 24 months. This investment aims to enhance JA Solar's vertical integration by including ingot production.  The PV glass supplier Almaden has achieved a turnover of RMB1.8 billion in 2020, with a net profit of RMB137 million. The strong market demand for PV glass, especially for use in bifacial modules, has contributed to this performance. Almaden estimates that it will sell more than 100,000,000 square meters of super thin glass this year.  Shareholders in Flat Glass will vote on plans to issue 76 million H shares to refill company coffers after extensive spending on new PV-panel-glass production capacity. The company has raised funds for the construction of a production facility with a 750,000-ton annual production capacity. This investment reflects the growing demand for PV-panel glass.  Furthermore, Xinte Energy, a major polysilicon producer in China, is planning to develop the world's largest polysilicon production complex. The facility, located in Inner Mongolia, is expected to produce 200,000 metric tons of polysilicon per annum. The project is still awaiting site selection and approval, but if ratified, construction could start within a month. This expansion is crucial to meet the increasing global solar demand, which is forecasted to reach between 150GW to 200GW in 2021.  The limited supply of polysilicon in China has led to a significant increase in average polysilicon prices since the second half of 2020. Polysilicon producer Daqo New Energy reported an increase in average selling prices from US$7.04/kg in Q2 2020 to US$9.13/kg in Q3 2020. Spot market prices have reached as high as US$14/kg to US$15/kg in 2021. This price increase is driven by capacity constraints in the market.  To address the supply constraints, major purchasers have secured long-term supply contracts with polysilicon producers. Daqo New Energy has signed supply deals with JA Solar, LONGi Green Energy Technology, and Trina Solar, all of which are major players in the solar industry. These deals ensure a stable supply of polysilicon for these companies.  Overall, the news highlights the increasing demand for polysilicon in the solar industry and the efforts of manufacturers to expand their production capacity. The limited supply and capacity constraints have led to a significant increase in polysilicon prices. As the global solar demand continues to grow, it is crucial for the industry to invest in new production facilities to meet the future demand and stabilize polysilicon prices./n

Last week, there was a significant increase in polysilicon and wafer prices in China. The average polysilicon price rose by 9% compared to the previous week, with high-quality polysilicon priced at RMB 105 per kg. Polysilicon for multi-crystalline modules was priced at RMB 63 per kg. Both Longi and Zhonghuan raised the prices of their wafer products by 9.5% and 10% respectively.  In terms of supply agreements, Wuxi Shangji Automation secured a long-term order for 52,700 metric tons of polysilicon from July 2021 to June 2024. Daqo New Energy Corp also announced a three-year, 41,000 metric ton supply agreement with Zhonghuan Semiconductor. These supply agreements indicate a strong demand for polysilicon in the future.  There are also plans for expansion in polysilicon production capacity. TBEA-owned Xinte Energy is planning to expand its annual production capacity by 100,000 metric tons with a new factory in Inner Mongolia. JA Solar also announced plans to invest RMB 5 billion in new wafer manufacturing capacity in Baotou city, Inner Mongolia.  In terms of other related industries, solar glass provider China Glass issued a profit warning despite posting rises in revenue and gross profit for 2020. PV glass supplier Almaden achieved a turnover of RMB 1.8 billion in 2020, with strong market demand for PV glass. Shareholders in Flat Glass will vote on plans to issue H shares to refill company coffers after extensive spending on new PV-panel-glass production capacity.  In terms of technological advancements, GCL-Poly reported that its new production line for granular silicon is using 30% less hydrogen and has reduced the metal and carbon content of the polysilicon. Battery company CATL and inverter maker Kstar completed construction of a 1 GW annual production capacity fab. Xinte Energy also announced plans to build a 100,000-ton-per-year-production-capacity factory.  In terms of government policies, power provider China Huadian Corporation announced plans to decommission 3 GW of thermal power plants and increase the share of renewables in its power generation fleet to 50% by 2026. This indicates a shift towards renewable energy sources, which could drive the demand for polysilicon.  Overall, the news indicates a strong demand for polysilicon in the future, with increasing prices and expansion plans in production capacity. The shift towards renewable energy sources and government policies supporting renewable energy also contribute to the positive outlook for polysilicon prices./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.   Firstly, the average polysilicon price in China increased by 9% over the previous week, with high-quality polysilicon priced at RMB 105 per kg. This indicates a growing demand for polysilicon in the market, which could potentially drive up prices in the future.  Secondly, there is a price war between companies in the polysilicon market. Both Longi and Zhonghuan raised the prices of their wafer products by 9.5% and 10% respectively. This competition among companies could lead to further price increases in the future.  Thirdly, government subsidies play a role in the polysilicon market. Solar glass provider China Glass issued a profit warning despite posting rises in revenue and gross profit for 2020. This indicates that the removal of state compensation has affected the company's profitability. Changes in government subsidies could impact the overall demand and prices of polysilicon.  Lastly, geopolitical conflicts can also have an effect on polysilicon prices. Several companies have signed contracts and established partnerships with their material vendors, indicating a need for secure supply chains. Additionally, Longi has turned to overseas suppliers to secure polysilicon supply, suggesting that geopolitical tensions could disrupt the supply and prices of polysilicon.  In summary, the increase in polysilicon prices, price wars between companies, changes in government subsidies, and geopolitical conflicts are all factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market. It is important for strategic decision-makers to closely monitor these developments and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

According to recent news, polysilicon and wafer prices in China have seen a significant increase. The average price of polysilicon has risen by 9% compared to the previous week, with high-quality polysilicon priced at RMB 105 per kg. Polysilicon for multi-crystalline modules is priced at RMB 63 per kg. Additionally, both Longi and Zhonghuan have raised the prices of their wafer products by 9.5%.   In terms of long-term orders, Wuxi Shangji Automation has secured an order for 52,700 metric tons of polysilicon from July 2021 to June 2024. The price for this supply agreement will be based on monthly negotiation. Goodwe, an inverter maker, has also announced a deal to provide 100 MW of inverters to Korean energy developer GS Global.  There have been several contracts and partnerships signed between companies in the polysilicon industry. Longi has signed contracts with Asia Silicon for polysilicon supply and with South Glass for PV glass. Tongwei has signed contracts with Jinko for cell production and established joint venture vehicles with Longi and Trina Solar for wafer supply and cell production. Trina Solar is also buying polysilicon from Tongwei and has signed contracts with Zhonghuan and Shangji Automation for wafer supply. JA Solar has signed with Xinte for polysilicon purchases and Rainbow for PV glass supplies.  The supply of polysilicon appears to be tight, with more than 90% of China's polysilicon output already locked in for this year. As a result, wafer makers have signed large orders with polysilicon suppliers. This tight supply and demand balance is expected to cause fluctuations in polysilicon prices.  The Silicon Industry Branch of China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association (CMRA) originally forecasted an oversupply in the silicon materials market for the first half of 2021, with prices expected to rise rapidly in the second half due to a short supply. PVInfoLink data shows that the price of polysilicon for mono has already risen by 32% in the past two months. The increase in silicon materials prices has also driven up the prices of silicon wafers and cells along the supply chain.  In terms of expansion plans, Daqo New Energy Corp has announced a three-year supply agreement with Zhonghuan Semiconductor, and TBEA-owned Xinte Energy is planning to expand its annual production capacity by 100,000 MT. JA Solar has also approved a plan to invest RMB 5 billion in new wafer manufacturing capacity.  Overall, the news suggests that the tight supply and demand balance in the polysilicon market, along with increasing demand and expansion plans, will likely lead to further price fluctuations in the future./n

According to the latest report from CEA's PV Supplier Market Intelligence Program, there is expected to be a continuing material supply shortage and undersupply of polysilicon throughout 2021. This shortage is expected to have a significant impact on the prices of polysilicon in the future. The report also highlights the expansion of module and cell capacity, as well as the increasing market share of leading suppliers in global production.  In terms of contracts and partnerships, several companies have signed long-term purchasing contracts and partnerships with their material vendors. For example, Longi has signed contracts with Asia Silicon for polysilicon supply and with South Glass for PV glass. Tongwei has signed contracts with Jinko for cell production and established joint venture vehicles with Longi and Trina Solar for wafer supply. Trina Solar is also buying polysilicon from Tongwei and has signed contracts with Zhonghuan and Shangji Automation for wafer supply. JA Solar has signed contracts with Xinte for polysilicon purchases and Rainbow for PV glass supplies. These contracts and partnerships indicate the tight supply capacities in the polysilicon market.  The report also mentions the historical expansion of the solar industry and the renewed confidence in the industry due to solar grid parity in many countries, including China, and the increasing interest in PV as an investment class. The embrace of renewables, driven by China's commitment to reach carbon neutrality by 2060, is also a significant factor in the industry's expansion.  In terms of market predictions, the Silicon Industry Branch of China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association (CMRA) originally forecasted an oversupply in the silicon materials market for the first half of 2021, with demand reaching its low point in the second quarter. However, given the current market situation, the CMRA now predicts that the price of polysilicon materials will continue to fluctuate due to the tight supply and demand balance. PVInfoLink data shows that the price of polysilicon has already risen by 32% in two months, reaching 122,000 yuan/MT.  Overall, the news indicates that the polysilicon market is facing a tight supply and demand balance, leading to price fluctuations. The expansion of the solar industry, increasing investments, and government commitments to renewable energy are driving the demand for polysilicon. The contracts and partnerships between companies and their material vendors further highlight the tight supply capacities in the market. These factors suggest that the prices of polysilicon are likely to continue rising in the future./n

According to the latest report from CEA's PV Supplier Market Intelligence Program, there is a continuing material supply shortage and an expected undersupply of polysilicon in 2021. This indicates that polysilicon prices are likely to remain high throughout the year. The report also highlights the expansion of module and cell capacity, as well as the increased market share of leading suppliers in global production.  Recent actions by companies in the industry suggest a battle between upstream and downstream enterprises. LONGi and Tongwei have released product quotations, with the price of solar cells dropping significantly while silicon wafer prices remain stable. GCL, on the other hand, has stated that the price of its silicon materials will not rise. This indicates a potential price war between companies in the industry.  There are predictions that in 2021, with downstream enterprises being pushed to the limit, the prices of silicon materials and silicon wafers will rise to place pressure on upstream enterprises. This could lead to production reductions by module producers, increasing the inventory of photovoltaic glass and reducing its price.  The political environment in major markets, such as the United States and Europe, is increasingly supportive of diversification of the solar supply chain and localized solar manufacturing. Buyers of solar energy are also focused on social and sustainability issues, as well as the embodied carbon within the solar supply chain. This could lead to additional policy support for alternative supply chains and sustainably made solar materials, which may impact the demand and prices of polysilicon.  In terms of specific market developments, Shanghai-listed Shangji Automation will buy 50,000 metric tons of polysilicon from module manufacturer Risen. Chinese wafer maker Zhonghuan Semiconductor has also announced price increases for its wafers. Additionally, the China Development Bank has launched a carbon neutrality bond, which will be used to finance clean energy facilities and urban rail projects.  The CMRA initially forecasted an oversupply in the silicon materials market for the first half of 2021, with demand reaching its low point in the second quarter. However, given the current market situation, the CMRA predicts that the price of polysilicon materials will continue to fluctuate due to the tight supply and demand balance. PVInfoLink data shows that the price of polysilicon has already risen by 32% in the past two months.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices are likely to remain high due to the ongoing supply shortage. The price war between companies, government subsidies for alternative supply chains, and geopolitical conflicts may also impact the future prices of polysilicon. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon market, particularly in China, to closely monitor these developments and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.   Firstly, there is a mismatch between supply and demand in the polysilicon market, which has been driving volatility upstream and downstream. Secondly, more polysilicon supply is expected to come onstream later this year, with facilities owned by companies such as Xinte, GCL-Poly, and Risen slated to start production. Additionally, formerly shuttered plants, including those owned by REC Silicon, are expected to be brought back online. This increase in supply may help to stabilize polysilicon prices in the future.  Thirdly, there is a price war between companies in the PV market, particularly between upstream and downstream enterprises. This battle between upstream and downstream enterprises may lead to price fluctuations in the polysilicon market.  Furthermore, government subsidies and policies play a role in the polysilicon market. The political environment in major markets, such as the United States and Europe, is increasingly supportive of diversification of the solar supply chain and development of localized solar manufacturing. There is also anticipation of additional policy support for alternative supply chains and sustainably made solar materials. These policies may impact the demand and pricing of polysilicon.  Lastly, geopolitical conflicts can also affect the polysilicon market. For instance, the industry predicts that downstream enterprises being pushed to the limit in 2021 may lead to rising prices of silicon materials and silicon wafers, which will place pressure on upstream enterprises. In response, module producers may reduce production, leading to increased inventory of photovoltaic glass and reduced prices.  Overall, the tight supply and demand balance, the increase in polysilicon prices, the price war between companies, government subsidies, and geopolitical conflicts are all factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market./n

The news related to polysilicon prices in the upcoming months suggests that there are several factors that will have a significant effect on the China and global PV market. Solar wafer and cell manufacturers in China have recently increased their prices due to a jump in spot prices for polysilicon in the country. This increase in prices has been further complicated by earthquakes that disrupted production at facilities owned by LONGi and Zhonghuan Semiconductor, two of the industry's largest wafer suppliers.  LONGi, one of the leading solar module and wafer producers, announced a further price increase of around 9% for its wafers. Tongwei, a solar cell manufacturer, also increased its prices by 8-9%. These price increases follow a jump in the average spot market price for polysilicon in China, which has been steadily rising since the beginning of the year. Last week, prices jumped by more than 9%.  In addition to the price increases, there have been several long-term supply deals signed between polysilicon manufacturers and module manufacturers. Daqo New Energy and JA Solar signed a deal for high-purity polysilicon supply, and Xinte Energy signed a deal to supply poly to JA Solar. These deals indicate that manufacturers are looking to lock in polysilicon supply due to the volatility in prices and the high demand for the material.  The volatility in polysilicon supply and pricing is expected to continue into 2022, when new capacity is expected to come online. Daqo is bringing new capacity online next year with its Phase 4B project, which will add 35,000 MT to its total capacity. However, until new capacity comes online, shortages are expected to persist.  Another factor that could impact polysilicon prices is the international moves against forced labor in China's Xinjiang region, which accounts for more than 40% of global polysilicon production. If a ban on import of modules using Xinjiang-made polysilicon takes effect, there could be a tight supply of polysilicon in non-Xinjiang regions, leading to a price gap between polysilicon in Xinjiang and non-Xinjiang regions.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices will continue to be volatile in the coming months due to factors such as supply shortages, price increases, and geopolitical conflicts. Manufacturers are taking strategic actions to secure polysilicon supply and mitigate the impact of these factors on their operations./n

Firstly, solar wafer and cell manufacturers in China have increased their prices due to a jump in spot prices for polysilicon in the country. This indicates that the demand for polysilicon is high, leading to price hikes.  Furthermore, the production of solar manufacturing in China has been disrupted by earthquakes that occurred over the weekend. This has affected facilities owned by LONGi and Zhonghuan Semiconductor, two of the largest wafer suppliers in the industry. LONGi has announced a further price increase for its wafers, following a similar move by solar cell manufacturer Tongwei. These price increases suggest that the supply of polysilicon may be limited, leading to higher prices.  In addition, there have been long-term supply deals signed between companies for high-purity polysilicon. Daqo New Energy and JA Solar have entered into an agreement for the supply of high-purity mono-grade polysilicon for three-and-a-half years. This indicates that manufacturers are looking to secure their supply of polysilicon amidst the volatile market conditions.  The volatility in polysilicon supply and pricing has been a major concern, with prices escalating in recent months. Poly spot prices have reached levels exceeding RMB150/kg (US$23.28/kg), leading to an increase in module prices. This volatility is expected to continue into 2022 when new capacity is expected to come online.  Overall, the news suggests that the demand for polysilicon is high, leading to price increases. The disruptions in production and the need for long-term supply deals indicate that the supply of polysilicon may be limited. This, coupled with the volatility in pricing, will have a significant effect on the future prices of polysilicon in the China and global PV market./n

According to recent news, there have been several factors that are expected to have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in China and the global PV market. One of the key factors is the increase in spot prices for polysilicon in China, which has led to solar wafer and cell manufacturers in the country hiking their prices. This increase in prices has been driven by a jump in the average spot market price for polysilicon, which rose by more than 9% last week.  In addition to the increase in prices, there have been disruptions in polysilicon production due to earthquakes in China. Facilities owned by LONGi and Zhonghuan Semiconductor, two of the industry's largest wafer suppliers, were affected by the earthquakes, leading to a disruption in production. LONGi announced a further price increase for its wafers, following a similar move by solar cell manufacturer Tongwei. These price increases are expected to further impact polysilicon prices.  Furthermore, there are concerns about the supply of polysilicon in the future. While 11 Chinese polysilicon manufacturers maintained a high operating rate in May 2021 to respond to excess demand, the production output of three companies is restricted due to maintenance and energy consumption policies. This has led to a marginal decrease in domestic production of polysilicon. The tightening of long-term orders by major polysilicon businesses and the overhaul of production from three producers in June are expected to continue affecting the supply of polysilicon in the country.  However, there is some relief in sight as several manufacturers have announced plans to increase polysilicon production capacity within the next year or two. This is expected to ease the supply situation and potentially result in lower prices again. The timing of this increase in supply and the possibility of a new oversupply situation leading to a price collapse are still uncertain.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices have been on the rise due to various factors such as increased demand, disruptions in production, and tightening supply. The price increases have had an impact on solar wafer and cell manufacturers, who have had to pass on the higher costs to their customers. However, there are expectations that the price rally may stabilize as the threshold of pain has been reached for many end customers and large utility-scale projects are being pushed out into 2022. The future of polysilicon prices will depend on factors such as global demand, supply capacity, and any potential disruptions or geopolitical conflicts that may arise./n

According to recent news, there are several factors that are expected to have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in China and the global PV market. One important factor is the impact of the recent increase in spot prices for polysilicon in China. Solar wafer and cell manufacturers in China have responded to this increase by hiking their prices, which has led to a decrease in demand. As a result, cell manufacturers and vertically integrated companies have reduced their utilization rates, leading to lower acceptability for the wafer price hike and smaller trading volumes.  On the production side, 11 Chinese polysilicon manufacturers have maintained a high operating rate in response to excess demand. However, the production output of three companies has been restricted due to maintenance overhauls on production lines for Xinjiang businesses and reduced production load for Inner Mongolia businesses under the energy consumption policy. This has resulted in a marginal decrease in domestic production of polysilicon. Energy Trend analysts predict that the tight provision of polysilicon in the country may be further aggravated by the support in inflation provided by the upstream and downstream sectors.  Furthermore, several manufacturers have announced plans to increase their polysilicon production capacity, which is expected to come online within a year or two. This increase in supply is likely to ease the supply situation and potentially result in lower prices. However, the timing of when this will happen and whether it will lead to a new oversupply situation and price collapse remains uncertain.  In addition to these factors, the recent earthquakes in China have disrupted production at facilities owned by major wafer suppliers, further complicating solar manufacturing in the country. For example, LONGi Green Energy has reported that around 10% of its silicon wafer production output for this month has been disrupted. The company is working on restoring production, which is expected to resume next week.  Overall, while polysilicon prices have stabilized in recent weeks, concerns remain about the industry's ability to meet future demand for the raw material. The market is closely watching for any potential fluctuations in supply and demand, as well as the impact of government subsidies and geopolitical conflicts on polysilicon prices./n

According to recent news, the polysilicon market has experienced a five-month rally in prices, with the price of the raw material rising by around 160% from the beginning of the year. However, it appears that the price increase may have reached a threshold, as the price of polysilicon rose just 1% on June 9. This suggests that many end customers are reaching their limit in terms of accepting higher prices, and large utility-scale projects are being pushed out into 2022.  The price hike for polysilicon was also driven by panic buying from manufacturers of wafers, cells, and modules, who sought to hedge against further price increases by purchasing as much polysilicon as possible. This hoarding impulse contributed to the rapid acceleration of the price rally in April and May. While wafer manufacturers were initially able to pass on the price increase to cell producers, they eventually had to give up some of their margins due to the rapid price escalation. Solar cell producers, on the other hand, experienced a decrease in prices in the first quarter but were able to catch up by raising their prices in April and May.  In addition to the price rally, there are concerns about the industry's ability to meet the mid-term demand for polysilicon. While the price of polysilicon has stabilized in recent weeks, there are worries about potential supply disruptions due to maintenance overhauls in the third quarter. This could lead to a new round of price increases if fears of lower polysilicon supply resurface.  Furthermore, there are plans to increase polysilicon production capacity, which could ease the supply situation and potentially result in lower prices. Several manufacturers have announced plans to build new polysilicon production facilities within the next year or two. However, the timing of when these new capacities will come online and whether they will lead to an oversupply situation and price collapse remains uncertain.  Overall, the future prices of polysilicon will be influenced by factors such as demand, supply disruptions, and the expansion of production capacity. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon market to closely monitor these developments and assess their potential impact on prices and market dynamics./n

Based on the news articles, there are several key factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.  Firstly, Tongwei, a polysilicon supplier and solar cell maker, has signed an agreement with the government of Leshan City and the Wuhua district to build a new polysilicon manufacturing site with a capacity of 200,000 metric tons. This expansion plan, along with Tongwei's existing capacity and ongoing construction, will result in a total polysilicon capacity of 330,000 metric tons by the end of 2022. This increased supply may potentially lead to lower polysilicon prices in the future.  Additionally, G-Crystal, a Chinese glass group, has completed the construction of its glass production lines for thin-film PV panel products. The company has signed a supplement agreement with First Solar for the next 10 years. This indicates a stable demand for PV glass, which is a key component in the production of solar panels. The stability in demand for PV glass may have a positive impact on the overall demand for polysilicon.  Furthermore, the price of polysilicon has remained stable in recent weeks, with the main deal price around RMB 200 ($30.90) per kilo. However, there has been a decrease in wafer orders due to high inventory and lower capacity utilization. This has led to wafer makers cutting prices, especially for large-sized wafers. The drop in wafer prices may put downward pressure on polysilicon prices as well.  In terms of production, there has been a marginal decrease in domestic production of polysilicon due to maintenance overhauls and reduced production load for certain businesses in Xinjiang and Inner Mongolia. This restricted production output may contribute to a tight supply of polysilicon in the country. However, several manufacturers have announced plans to increase polysilicon production capacity within the next year or two, which could potentially ease the supply situation and result in lower prices.  Overall, while there are factors that may contribute to lower polysilicon prices, such as increased production capacity and reduced wafer prices, there are also concerns about the industry's ability to meet future demand for the raw material. The market will need to closely monitor the balance between supply and demand to determine the future direction of polysilicon prices./n

Based on the news related to polysilicon, there are several factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices.   Firstly, Tongwei, a polysilicon supplier and solar cell maker, has signed an agreement with the government of Leshan City and the Wuhua district to establish a new polysilicon manufacturing site with a capacity of 200,000 metric tons. This expansion plan, along with Tongwei's existing capacity and ongoing construction, will result in a total polysilicon capacity of 330,000 metric tons by the end of 2022. This indicates a potential increase in supply, which could impact future prices.  Additionally, G-Crystal, a Chinese glass group, has completed the construction of its glass production lines for thin-film PV panel products. In terms of current prices, PV InfoLink reports that the price of polysilicon has remained stable at around RMB 200 ($30.90) per kilo. However, there are concerns about the industry's ability to meet future demand for the raw material. To address this, Xinte plans to raise funds through share sales to accelerate the development of a polysilicon production facility in Inner Mongolia. Daqo New Energy, another polysilicon producer, is also aiming to complete new production facilities in the next 18 months.  Furthermore, the expansion of polysilicon capacity is primarily happening outside of Xinjiang, with facilities being established in provinces such as Sichuan, Yunnan, and Inner Mongolia. This expansion is driven by factors such as low-cost electricity, particularly from hydro sources. The market growth in these regions could potentially impact the overall supply and demand dynamics of polysilicon.  Overall, while there is currently a surplus of polysilicon supply that can meet the needs of the US market, the expansion plans and potential increase in demand indicate that future polysilicon prices may be influenced by factors such as capacity expansion, government subsidies, and geopolitical conflicts. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon market to closely monitor these developments and assess their potential impact on prices./n

According to recent news, Tongwei, a polysilicon supplier and solar cell maker, has signed an agreement with the government of Leshan City and the Wuhua district to establish a new polysilicon manufacturing site with a capacity of 200,000 metric tons. The total investment for this project is estimated to be around $2.1 billion. The facility will be constructed in two phases, with the first phase expected to be completed by the end of 2022. Tongwei currently has a total polysilicon capacity of 80,000 metric tons, with an additional 150,000 metric tons under construction. With the new expansion plan, the company's total polysilicon capacity will reach 330,000 metric tons by the end of 2022 and 430,000 metric tons when phase II of the project is finished.  In addition, Chinese glass group G-Crystal has announced the completion of its glass production lines for thin-film PV panel products in Malaysia. The facility has a planned capacity of 500 metric tons of PV glass per day and has signed a supplement agreement with First Solar for the next 10 years.  In terms of polysilicon prices, a market observation by Taiwan-based research company PV InfoLink states that the price of polysilicon has remained stable at around $30.90 per kilo. However, due to lower capacity utilization on the wafer side, downstream users have rejected high quotes for polysilicon. This has led to cost pressure spreading from downstream modules and cells to wafers, resulting in price reductions of around 10% for large-sized wafers. Cell prices have also dropped slightly.  There are concerns about the industry's ability to meet the mid-term demand for polysilicon, despite recent price stabilizations. Xinte, a polysilicon producer, has unveiled plans to raise funds for the development of a new polysilicon production facility in Inner Mongolia. The construction of this facility is expected to start this quarter and take 18 months to complete.  The supply and demand of polysilicon remain unbalanced, and module prices may remain at $0.24-0.25/W. However, if the price level is accepted in China and most projects connect to the grid this year, a new price balance point may be set. It is expected that module prices may be turbulent in July and August when demand slackens.  Overall, the expansion plans of Tongwei and other manufacturers, along with the supply and demand dynamics, will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. The industry's ability to meet demand and any fluctuations in the market could impact the construction and completion of these projects, potentially leading to fundraising issues and delays./n
