According to recent news, polysilicon prices in China have experienced a decline of about 1.4% to RMB207 (US$32.1) per kg. This marks the third consecutive drop since July 7. The decrease in prices can be attributed to several silicon factories resuming production after yearly maintenance, resulting in increased output compared to June. Additionally, the import of 9,000 MW of the raw material has contributed to a total polysilicon supply of 50,000 MT, which is expected to meet market demand.  In terms of capacity expansion, Gaoce Technology, a Shanghai-listed diamond wire cutting equipment supplier, has announced plans to increase its PV wafer capacity by 20 GW. This follows their previous intent to invest in monocrystalline PV wafer production in Yancheng City. The company will invest approximately RMB1.65 billion (US$256 million) in this project. Similarly, Tongwei, a Chinese polysilicon supplier, has signed an agreement with Leshan City to establish a 200,000 MT polysilicon manufacturing plant. The facility will be completed in two phases, with the first phase expected to be finished by the end of 2022. Tongwei is investing around RMB14 billion (US$2.17 billion) in this project, which could potentially increase their production capacity to 430,000 MT.  However, it is important to note that market fluctuations could pose challenges to these expansion plans, potentially resulting in fundraising issues and construction delays. The supply chain for solar-grade polysilicon remains constrained, with spot market prices in China having more than doubled since the beginning of the year. This increase in polysilicon prices has also led to a spike in prices for solar wafers, cells, and modules.  In other news, PV module manufacturer Hareon Solar has filed for bankruptcy, citing an inability to pay off debts. This development may have implications for the overall PV market.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices in China may continue to be influenced by factors such as production output, import levels, capacity expansion plans, and market fluctuations. It is important for industry players to closely monitor these developments and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

According to recent news, polysilicon prices in China and the global PV market are showing signs of a rise. The China Nonferrous Metals Association (CNMA) and wafer producer Zhonghuan Semiconductor have reported that after a continuous slight price drop over the past five weeks, polysilicon prices have started to increase again. The CNMA revealed that the current price for polysilicon is CNY 205 (US$31.6) per kg, which is 0.54% higher than the previous week. Additionally, Zhonghuan Semiconductor announced that the prices for its M6 and G12 sized wafers have also risen by the same percentage.  In other news, Trina Solar, a solar module manufacturer, has announced plans to issue convertible bonds worth RMB5.25 billion ($809.8 million). The net proceeds from this bond issuance will be invested in expanding the company's PV cell and module production capacity. Trina Solar plans to establish a 16 GW PV cell factory in Yancheng city, two cell factories with a combined capacity of 18 GW in Suqian city, and a 10 GW PV panel manufacturing facility in Yancheng.  On the other hand, the China Nonferrous Metals Association reported that polysilicon prices declined by about 1.4% to RMB207 (US$32.1) per kg last week. This marks the third consecutive drop since July 7. The trade body attributes this decline to several silicon factories resuming production after yearly maintenance, resulting in increased output compared to June. The association also mentioned that 9,000 MW of polysilicon was imported, and the total supply for the period reached up to 50,000 MT, which should meet the market demand.  Furthermore, Gaoce Technology, a Shanghai-listed diamond wire cutting equipment supplier, has announced plans to increase its PV wafer capacity by another 20 GW. The company will invest around RMB1.65 billion (US$256 million) in this project. Hareon Solar, a PV module manufacturer, has filed for bankruptcy, and Luoyang Glass, a state-controlled manufacturer, has acquired 60% of glassmaker Qinhuangdao North Glass Co Ltd to expand its PV glass business.  In terms of future polysilicon prices, it is expected that the new polysilicon production facilities will not come online in significant capacity until late 2021 or even 2022 after the Chinese New Year. The balance between supply and demand will play a crucial role in determining the price levels, and module prices may remain around $0.24-0.25/W. However, there may be some turbulence in module prices in July and August when demand slackens.  Overall, the news suggests a mixed outlook for polysilicon prices. While there are indications of a rise in prices, factors such as increased production and market demand will continue to influence the future prices of polysilicon in China and the global PV market./n

According to recent news, polysilicon prices in China and the global PV market have experienced fluctuations. The China Nonferrous Metals Association (CNMA) and wafer producer Zhonghuan Semiconductor reported that after a continuous slight price drop, polysilicon prices have started to rise again. The CNMA revealed that the current price of polysilicon is CNY 205 (US$31.6) per kg, which is 0.54% higher than the previous week. Additionally, Zhonghuan Semiconductor announced that the prices for its M6 and G12 sized wafers also increased by the same percentage.  On the other hand, there have been reports of polysilicon prices declining. The CNMA stated that polysilicon prices dropped by about 1.4% to RMB207 (US$32.1) per kg last week. This is the third consecutive drop since July 7. The trade body attributed this decline to increased output from silicon factories that resumed production after yearly maintenance. It was also reported that 9,000 MW of polysilicon was imported, resulting in a total supply of 50,000 MT, which is expected to meet market demand.  In terms of company developments, Trina Solar, a solar module manufacturer, announced plans to issue convertible bonds worth RMB5.25 billion ($809.8 million) to expand its PV cell and module production capacity. The investments will include the construction of a 16 GW PV cell factory in Yancheng city, two cell factories with a combined capacity of 18 GW in Suqian city, and a 10 GW PV panel manufacturing facility in Yancheng.  Other significant news includes the bankruptcy filing of PV module manufacturer Hareon Solar, the acquisition of glassmaker Qinhuangdao North Glass Co Ltd by Luoyang Glass, and the plans of Gaoce Technology to increase its PV wafer capacity by 20 GW.  The news also highlights the impact of polysilicon prices on related industries. Xinyi, a solar glass manufacturer, reported that the price of mainstream solar glass fell more than 45% in the first half of the year due to the soaring polysilicon price. This has put pressure on solar glass pricing and could potentially delay or halt glass production capacity expansion plans for Xinyi's competitors.  In terms of future predictions, SolarPower Europe expects the scarcity of polysilicon to continue this year, despite describing it as a "brief incidence" that is being resolved. The trade body believes that the upward pressure on prices has peaked and attributes this to the rising volume of corporate-driven solar projects worldwide. If panel prices become too expensive, private businesses may choose not to build unsubsidized solar parks, which solar manufacturers are aware of.  Overall, the news indicates that polysilicon prices have experienced fluctuations, with both increases and decreases observed. Factors such as production output, imports, company investments, bankruptcies, and market demand have influenced these price changes. The impact of polysilicon prices on related industries, such as solar glass, has also been significant. Looking ahead, the scarcity of polysilicon is expected to continue, but the upward pressure on prices may have peaked due to corporate-driven solar projects./n

According to recent news, there are several factors that are expected to have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market. One important development is the increase in prices of silicon wafers by companies like LONGi and Tongwei Solar. LONGi has increased the prices of its p-type wafers, while Tongwei Solar has raised the prices of its polycrystalline and monocrystalline cells. This indicates a trend of rising prices in the polysilicon market.  Additionally, there have been reports of a potential increase in polysilicon prices in the coming months. The China Nonferrous Metals Association (CNMA) and wafer producer Zhonghuan Semiconductor have revealed that polysilicon prices have resumed an upward trend after a slight drop. This suggests that the supply of polysilicon may become tighter, leading to higher prices.  Furthermore, the CEO of Chinese polysilicon manufacturer Daqo New Energy has stated that market conditions remain strong for the polysilicon sector. Daqo expects an increase in polysilicon production lines next year, which will contribute to the rising demand for solar modules. The CEO also predicts that the polysilicon price will continue to rise in the second half of this year due to the strong global demand for PV.  These developments indicate that polysilicon prices are likely to increase in the future. The rising prices of silicon wafers and the tightening supply of polysilicon suggest a potential price hike in the coming months. The strong market conditions and increasing demand for PV also support the expectation of higher polysilicon prices. As a strategic expert, it would be advisable to closely monitor these developments and consider their potential impact on the polysilicon market in China and globally./n

According to recent news, polysilicon prices have continued to rise slightly, with the average transaction price of mono-grade polysilicon increasing by less than 1%. The transaction price for long-term orders is around 211,000-213,000 yuan/MT, while the transaction range for individual orders is 214,000-217,000 yuan/MT. The low transaction range for mono-grade polysilicon from other enterprises is 206,000-208,000 yuan/MT.  The shortage of silicon wafers due to early production reduction and raw material shortages has also contributed to the increase in polysilicon prices. Cell producers are choosing to directly purchase silicon materials and carry out silicon wafer OEM due to the insufficient supply of silicon wafers. This periodic increase in demand for silicon materials has led to a slight rise in prices.  Currently, there are 12 domestic polysilicon enterprises in production, with no enterprise maintenance. The price of silicon material started to rise in mid-August but at a significantly slower rate compared to the first half of the year. This can be attributed to the slight increase in the supply of silicon material as downstream demand continues to rise. Additionally, the enthusiasm for purchasing and hoarding goods has returned to a relatively rational state, resulting in a more stable rise in silicon material prices.  In terms of market dynamics, new players such as Xinjiang Jingnuo, Lihao Semiconductor, Baofeng Energy, and Runergy are entering the market to take advantage of the high profitability. These new players plan to expand capacity outside of the Xinjiang region to hedge political risks. However, if these new furnaces come into operation as scheduled, total polysilicon capacity may exceed demand, leading to fierce price competition. Tier-1 polysilicon makers that bring capacity online earlier may cause prices to decline due to surplus, which may make new players or Tier-2 manufacturers more conservative about their capacity expansion plans.  Furthermore, it is worth noting that LONGi, a major player in the industry, has increased its wafer prices for the first time in nearly two months. This follows Tongwei's price hike for its cells in August. These price increases indicate that the industry is bracing for continued high prices throughout the rest of the year.  Overall, while there has been a slight improvement in the short supply of silicon material compared to the first half of the year, polysilicon prices are expected to remain stable or continue to rise due to factors such as increased downstream demand, limited supply of silicon wafers, and potential price competition in the market./n

Geopolitical conflicts and government subsidies also play a role in shaping the polysilicon market./n

According to recent news, the price of silicon material, including polysilicon, has been steadily rising. This is primarily due to the increasing demand from downstream industries, such as cell and silicon wafer enterprises, which has led to a shortage of supply. As a result, the price of polysilicon has slightly increased, with the average transaction price of mono-grade polysilicon rising by less than 1%. The transaction price for long-term orders is around 211,000-213,000 yuan/MT, while individual orders range from 214,000-217,000 yuan/MT. Other enterprises have reported a lower transaction range of 206,000-208,000 yuan/MT for mono-grade polysilicon.  Furthermore, there is also a shortage of silicon wafers due to early production reductions and raw material shortages. This has led cell producers to directly purchase silicon materials and carry out silicon wafer OEM, further increasing the demand for certain silicon materials and causing a slight rise in prices.  However, the entry of new players into the market, such as Xinjiang Jingnuo, Lihao Semiconductor, Baofeng Energy, and Runergy, may lead to fierce price competition. These new players plan to expand their capacity outside of the Xinjiang region to mitigate political risks. If these new furnaces become operational as scheduled, the total polysilicon capacity may exceed demand, resulting in a decline in prices. This could potentially impact Tier-2 manufacturers or those planning to reopen lines, causing them to reconsider their capacity expansion plans.  Additionally, geopolitical conflicts and government subsidies can also have an impact on polysilicon prices. For instance, if there are delays in projects or trace silica-based products, companies may seek alternative non-China options to source more polysilicon. This could further affect the supply and demand dynamics of the market.  Looking ahead, it is expected that the price of polysilicon may vary, with possibilities ranging from around US$26.5/kg moving into the new year. The expected increase in polysilicon supply could support crystalline silicon module production, but it may still fall short of the expected demand. This suggests that polysilicon average selling prices (ASPs) could potentially decrease in the coming years.  It is worth noting that the location of new factories being constructed by existing polysilicon makers in China, outside of Xinjiang, could potentially be insulated from US import bans. This is significant for the US solar market and may have implications for the global polysilicon industry.  Overall, the current rise in polysilicon prices is driven by increasing demand and supply shortages. However, the entry of new players and potential geopolitical conflicts may introduce price competition and impact future prices. It is important for industry players to closely monitor these factors and make strategic decisions accordingly./n

According to recent news, the price of polysilicon has been steadily rising due to the increase in downstream demand and the shortage of supply. The average transaction price of mono-grade polysilicon has increased by less than 1%, with long-term orders ranging from 211,000-213,000 yuan/MT and individual orders ranging from 214,000-217,000 yuan/MT. Other enterprises have seen a low transaction range of 206,000-208,000 yuan/MT for mono-grade polysilicon.  The rise in polysilicon prices can be attributed to the shortage of silicon wafers, which has led cell producers to directly purchase silicon materials and carry out silicon wafer OEM. This periodic increase in demand has caused the price of silicon materials to rise slightly.  Furthermore, the average price of polysilicon rose by 11% last week to CNY 238.4 ($36.98)/kg. This increase was mainly due to a 100% jump in silicon costs caused by power shortages that affected China. Two major polysilicon manufacturers are currently undergoing annual overhauls and will not return to normal production until late October. The total output of China's polysilicon in September was slightly higher than August, but it is expected that the output in October will not surpass the figures of the previous two months, leading to further price increases.  In addition, new players are entering the market, such as Xinjiang Jingnuo, Lihao Semiconductor, Baofeng Energy, and Runergy, all of which plan to expand capacity outside of the Xinjiang region to hedge political risk. However, if these new players and Tier-2 manufacturers bring capacity online earlier, it may lead to a surplus of polysilicon and fierce price competition.  Overall, the news suggests that the future prices of polysilicon are likely to continue rising due to the shortage of supply, power shortages affecting production, and the potential for increased competition in the market. Companies may need to consider alternative non-China options to source polysilicon if delays in projects occur./n

The recent news regarding polysilicon prices indicates a significant impact on the future prices of polysilicon. The average price of polysilicon has risen by 11% in the past week, primarily due to a 100% increase in silicon costs. This increase in costs is a result of power shortages that have affected China, leading to stalling production. Two major polysilicon manufacturers are currently undergoing annual overhauls and are not expected to return to normal production until late October. As a result, the total output of China's polysilicon in October is not expected to surpass the figures of the previous two months, leading to further price increases.  In addition to the production issues, there are other factors that will impact polysilicon prices. Wind developer Mingyang Smart Energy has signed an agreement with the government of Yancheng, Jiangsu province, to build a 5 GW heterojunction solar cell factory. This investment of CNY 5 billion will contribute to the demand for polysilicon. Polysilicon manufacturer Xinte Energy has also raised CNY 2.29 billion through stock issuance to its controlling shareholder TBEA. This investment will be used for the construction of 100,000 tons of annual poly fab capacity. Furthermore, GCL-Poly, another polysilicon manufacturer, is expected to publish the findings of an investigation into a CNY 510 million pre-payment made in 2019 for a silicon project that was never built.  The entry of new players into the polysilicon market, such as Xinjiang Jingnuo, Lihao Semiconductor, Baofeng Energy, and Runergy, will also impact prices. These new players plan to expand capacity outside of the Xinjiang region to mitigate political risks. However, if these new furnaces come into operation as scheduled, the total polysilicon capacity will exceed demand, leading to intense price competition. This competition may cause prices to decline, which could affect the expansion plans of Tier-2 manufacturers and new players entering the market.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices will continue to rise in the upcoming months due to production issues and increased demand. However, the entry of new players and potential surplus capacity may lead to price competition and a decline in prices in the future. It is important for companies to monitor these developments and consider alternative options for sourcing polysilicon to mitigate risks./n

The news related to polysilicon prices indicates that there are several factors contributing to the increase in prices. One of the main reasons for the price increase is the jump in silicon costs, which has led to stalling production due to power shortages in China. Two major polysilicon manufacturers are currently undergoing annual overhauls and will not return to normal production until late October. This has resulted in a decrease in polysilicon output, and it is expected that the output in October will not surpass the figures of the previous months.  Additionally, there are concerns about the shortage of silicon powder caused by industrial power rationing in China. This shortage is expected to further impact polycrystalline silicon companies based in Xinjiang, leading to concerns about reduced output in the coming weeks. As a result of these factors, the average price of polysilicon has risen sharply, and subsequent orders are being arranged at higher prices. It is anticipated that average market prices will continue to rise into November.  Furthermore, there are geopolitical conflicts and government subsidies that are also affecting the polysilicon market. Wind developer Mingyang Smart Energy has signed an agreement with the government of Yancheng, Jiangsu province, to build a 5 GW heterojunction solar cell factory. This indicates government support and investment in the PV market. Polysilicon manufacturer Xinte Energy has raised funds for the construction of additional polysilicon production capacity, indicating the company's confidence in the future demand for polysilicon.  On the other hand, there are concerns about the financial sustainability of PV projects due to the rising prices of modules. Developers are delaying projects and re-negotiating supply contracts. This uncertainty in the sector is impacting the demand for PV modules, and PV InfoLink is revising down its forecast for global demand due to supply shortages and project deferrals.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices are expected to continue rising in the upcoming months due to various factors such as production disruptions, supply shortages, and geopolitical conflicts. These factors are impacting the entire PV market, including module prices and the financial viability of PV projects. Strategic decisions in the polysilicon market should take into account these factors and the potential impact on future prices./n

The news related to polysilicon prices in the upcoming months suggests that there are several factors that will have a significant effect on the future prices of polysilicon. One of the main reasons for the recent price increase is the 100% jump in silicon costs, which is attributed to the stalling production caused by power shortages in China. This has led to two major polysilicon manufacturers experiencing annual overhauls and not returning to normal production until late October. As a result, the total output of China's polysilicon in September was slightly higher than August, but it is expected that the output in October will not surpass the figures of the last two months, leading to further price increases.  In addition to the production issues, there are other factors that will impact polysilicon prices. One such factor is the price war between companies. The China Silicon Industry has warned that pricing for polysilicon chips has soared 13.2% to highs of RMB273/kg ($42.42/kg), putting further pricing pressure on the solar industry. The average transaction price for monocrystalline chips has increased by 13.2% compared to the last pricing update. This price increase is expected to continue into November as subsequent orders are arranged at higher prices.  Government subsidies also play a role in the future prices of polysilicon. Wind developer Mingyang Smart Energy has signed an agreement with the government of Yancheng, Jiangsu province, to build a 5 GW heterojunction solar cell factory. This indicates that the government is investing in the solar industry, which could potentially lead to increased demand for polysilicon and higher prices.  Furthermore, there are geopolitical conflicts that can impact polysilicon prices. Polysilicon manufacturer GCL-Poly is currently investigating a CNY 510 million pre-payment made in 2019 for a silicon project that was never built. This investigation has led to the resignation of Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu as its auditor and the suspension of trading in GCL-Poly shares. Such conflicts and uncertainties can create instability in the market and affect the prices of polysilicon.  Overall, based on the news, it can be concluded that polysilicon prices are expected to continue rising in the upcoming months. The production issues caused by power shortages, the price war between companies, government subsidies, and geopolitical conflicts all contribute to the increase in prices. As a strategic expert, it is important to closely monitor these factors and make informed decisions to navigate the polysilicon market in China./n

According to recent news, polysilicon prices in China have been on the rise, with a significant increase of 13.2% in the average transaction price. The price of monocrystalline chips ranged from RMB260 ‚Äì 273/kg (US$40.4 ‚Äì 42.42/kg), with an average transaction price of RMB269.9/kg (US$41.93/kg). The price range for mono dense poly stood at RMB258 ‚Äì 271/kg (US$39.31 ‚Äì 42.11/kg) with an average transaction price of RMB268/kg (US$41.65/kg). This increase in prices is expected to continue into November, as subsequent orders are being arranged at higher prices.  The rise in polysilicon prices is driven by several factors. Firstly, there is an ongoing shortage of silicon powder caused by industrial power rationing in China. This shortage is expected to further impact polycrystalline silicon companies based in Xinjiang, as they will be affected by the "double control" over energy consumption, potentially leading to reduced output in the coming weeks.  Additionally, the increase in prices of silicon materials, solar wafers, and cells is also contributing to the rise in polysilicon prices. As a result, module prices are beginning to reflect these increases, with leading brands selling 450W modules at a price of RMB2.1/W (US$0.32/c) this week.  The rise in polysilicon prices is expected to have a significant effect on the PV market, particularly in China. With the average market prices expected to continue rising, it is likely that there will be a shift in the supply-demand balance in favor of polysilicon purchasers. This is good news for those downstream in the PV industry, as it indicates a long-term outlook of low polysilicon prices.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices in China are on the rise due to factors such as the shortage of silicon powder and increasing prices of related materials. This is expected to have a significant impact on the PV market, with a shift in the supply-demand balance and potential long-term low prices for polysilicon./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that are likely to have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.   Firstly, there is a rise in polysilicon prices, with an average transaction price increase of 13-14% for various qualities of polysilicon. This indicates a growing demand for polysilicon in the market.  Secondly, there is a construction of a 600 MW PV power project in Gansu Province, which will contribute to the demand for polysilicon. This project is expected to be grid-connected by the end of June 2022 and will provide clean energy power annually.  Thirdly, EAST Group, a power supply manufacturer, has forecasted a growth in its performance for the first three quarters of 2021. This growth is mainly attributed to the steady growth of the company's high-end power supply equipment and photovoltaic power generation business.  Additionally, South Korea's OCI has reported a significant increase in polysilicon sales in the third quarter of this year, despite rising raw material prices and logistical issues. The company expects tight supply and demand conditions for raw materials and polysilicon to continue until the first half of 2022.  Overall, these factors suggest a growing demand for polysilicon in the market, which may lead to an increase in prices. However, the long-term outlook for polysilicon prices is expected to be low due to overcapacity and low manufacturing costs. This is likely to benefit downstream players in the PV industry./n

According to recent news, the polysilicon market is experiencing significant growth, with sales increasing by 90% year on year in the third quarter of this year. Despite rising raw material prices, delayed shipments, and logistical issues, the net result for the quarter was up 2,830% year on year. The operating result also saw a significant increase of 977% compared to the same period last year.  The manufacturer, OCI, reported that the sales price of polysilicon rose by around 29% quarter on quarter, while sales volume dropped by 15%. However, the company stated that the short-term impact of the surge in metallurgical silicon prices would not be significant due to diversified purchasers and existing raw material inventories. OCI's Malaysian unit has also ramped up production capacity in its polysilicon factory, which is expected to contribute to the tight supply and demand conditions for raw materials and polysilicon until the first half of 2022.  In terms of the overall market, there is currently an overcapacity of polysilicon, with manufacturing costs at industry leaders being below $6/kg in 2020. This overcapacity, combined with the increasing capacity of ingot and wafer production, has led to a major shift in the supply-demand balance in favor of polysilicon purchasers. As a result, the long-term outlook for polysilicon prices is expected to be low, providing relief to downstream players in the PV industry.  Looking ahead, several polysilicon capacity expansions are expected to come online in early 2022, which should help bring balance back to the market. These expansions include capacity from Daqo, Tongwei, Asia Silicon, East Hope, and GCL-Poly. The exact timing and extent of price reductions in 2022 will depend on the ramp-up of these new capacities and their ability to produce mono-quality material.  Overall, the news suggests that the polysilicon market is experiencing growth and oversupply, leading to low prices in the long term. However, the exact impact on prices will depend on various factors such as capacity expansions and the ability of new entrants to meet their production plans./n

Based on the news articles, there are several factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.  1. Polysilicon Sales and Price Increase: South Korea's OCI reported a 90% year-on-year growth in polysilicon sales in the third quarter of this year, despite rising raw material prices and logistical issues. The company also mentioned that the sales price of polysilicon rose by around 29% quarter on quarter. This indicates a strong demand for polysilicon, which could potentially lead to higher prices in the future.  2. Tight Supply and Demand Conditions: OCI stated that tight supply and demand conditions for raw materials and polysilicon are expected to continue until the first half of 2022. This suggests that the market will continue to face supply constraints, which could further drive up prices.  3. Manufacturing Curtailment in China: Daqo New Energy acknowledged that the measures taken by the Chinese government to address electricity shortages and reduce emissions are affecting the solar industry. The company's CEO mentioned the difficulties of finding new production sites due to emissions reduction regulations. This could potentially lead to a decrease in polysilicon supply, resulting in higher prices.  4. Global Solar Boom: Despite the challenges in securing permits for new manufacturing facilities, Daqo is benefiting from a global solar boom. Rising solar equipment costs have not yet impacted demand, and the company has been able to pass on the increased production costs to solar manufacturers. This indicates a strong market demand, which could contribute to higher polysilicon prices.  5. Supply Contracts and Investments: LONGi Solar signed a two-year wafer supply deal with DAS Solar, which could be worth up to $1.1 billion. This indicates a significant investment in the solar industry, which could drive up demand for polysilicon. Additionally, TBEA announced plans to build a metal silicon factory and develop renewable energy projects, further indicating potential growth in the industry.  Overall, the news suggests that there is a strong demand for polysilicon, with tight supply and demand conditions expected to continue. Factors such as manufacturing curtailment in China, global solar boom, supply contracts, and investments in the industry could contribute to higher polysilicon prices in the future./n

The news regarding polysilicon production and capacity expansion has significant implications for future polysilicon prices. Daqo New Energy, a Chinese polysilicon producer, has completed its Phase 4B polysilicon production facility ahead of schedule and has begun pilot production. The company expects to ramp up production to a full capacity of 105,000 metric tons per year by the end of Q1 2022. This expansion comes as Daqo posted record profits in Q3 2021 due to polysilicon price hikes. However, the company's CEO, Longgen Zhang, warned of a challenging environment for future capacity expansions due to quotas on energy consumption in China. Despite this, Daqo aims to achieve a total annual production capacity of 270,000 metric tons by the end of 2024.  The high price of polysilicon has been a major driver behind the soaring cost of modules in the past 18 months, leading to project delays and supply chain uncertainty. PV Tech Premium reported that module prices are expected to remain above US$0.27c/W until well into next year. This indicates that the high polysilicon prices are likely to continue in the near future.  In addition to Daqo's capacity expansion, there have been significant supply deals in the polysilicon market. Solar manufacturing leader LONGi Solar has signed a two-year wafer supply deal with Chinese PV manufacturer DAS Solar, which could be worth up to US$1.1 billion. This deal involves LONGi supplying DAS Solar with around 1.2 billion M10 182mm solar wafers between 2022 and 2023. Another newcomer to solar wafer manufacturing, Shuangliang Ecoenergy, has announced a polysilicon supply contract with Asia Silicon to procure over 25,000 metric tons of polysilicon over the next five years. These supply deals indicate a strong demand for polysilicon in the market.  Furthermore, Daqo's focus on research and development, production, and sales of high-purity polysilicon used in the photovoltaic industry positions the company as a leading silicon material company. The company has raised significant funds for its polysilicon projects, including the 35,000 metric ton polysilicon project. Daqo has decided to use over-raised funds to make additional investments in the project to ensure its implementation. The increase in construction costs is attributed to the rising prices of raw materials and changes in project measurements based on actual construction.  Overall, the news highlights the expansion of polysilicon production capacity, strong demand for polysilicon, and the challenges faced by companies in meeting capacity expansion targets. The high polysilicon prices are expected to continue, impacting the cost of modules and the overall PV market./n

The news highlights several key factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. Firstly, Daqo New Energy has completed its Phase 4B polysilicon production facility ahead of schedule and expects to ramp up production to a full capacity of 105,000MT per year by the end of Q1 2022. This increased production capacity could potentially lead to a decrease in polysilicon prices in the future.  However, the company's CEO, Longgen Zhang, has warned that the pace of polysilicon capacity expansion could slow due to quotas concerning energy consumption in China. This suggests that government regulations and policies could impact the future supply and demand dynamics of polysilicon, which in turn could affect prices.  Furthermore, the news mentions that polysilicon prices have been on the rise throughout 2021, reaching a high of $37/kg by the end of the year. This increase in prices is attributed to a combination of factors, including panic buying, long-term contracts between wafer makers and polysilicon producers, and the incentive for polysilicon makers to drive up spot prices.  Analysts predict that polysilicon prices will remain high throughout much of 2022, with a potential decrease starting in the third quarter of that year. However, the consensus is that downward price trends are likely to continue into 2023. This projection is based on the expectation of increased polysilicon production capacity outside of China, as well as the potential restart of higher-cost production facilities in other regions.  The news also mentions the impact of geopolitical factors on polysilicon prices. The ongoing trade tensions between China and the US have resulted in import tariffs on US polysilicon, making it an unattractive supply option for Chinese manufacturers. However, REC Silicon plans to bring US capacity back into the market in 2023 despite the import tariffs.  Additionally, the news highlights the impact of global commodity price increases on the solar industry, including polysilicon. Rising prices of silver, copper, aluminum, glass, and steel, which are key inputs in solar module production, have contributed to the overall increase in module manufacturing costs. This suggests that the cost of polysilicon is not the only factor driving the rising prices of solar modules.  Overall, the news indicates that the future prices of polysilicon will be influenced by factors such as increased production capacity, government regulations, geopolitical conflicts, and global commodity price trends. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon market to closely monitor these developments and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

The news regarding polysilicon prices in the upcoming months suggests several significant factors that will impact the China and global PV market. Daqo New Energy, a major polysilicon producer, has completed its Phase 4B polysilicon production facility ahead of schedule and expects to ramp up production to a full capacity of 105,000MT per year by the end of Q1 2022. However, the company warns of a challenging environment for future capacity expansions due to quotas concerning energy consumption in China. This could potentially slow down the pace of polysilicon capacity expansion in the future.  The high price of polysilicon has been a major driver behind the soaring cost of modules over the past 18 months, causing delays to projects and uncertainty throughout the supply chain. Polysilicon spot prices have increased significantly from an all-time low of $6.3/kg in 2020 to $37/kg as 2021 comes to a close. This increase is attributed to panic buying and the locking of polysilicon into long-term contracts by wafer makers. Polysilicon makers have a strong incentive to make the spot price rise, which has been the case.  Analysts predict that polysilicon prices will remain high at least through much of 2022, with a potential decrease starting in the third quarter of 2022 and continuing into 2023. Chinese polysilicon producers are adding capacity primarily outside of the problematic Xinjiang region, but building and ramping up poly facilities is a time-consuming process. Outside of China, there is available polysilicon production capacity, but higher-cost producers need longer-term price signals to restart facilities. Duties on U.S. polysilicon from China also make this supply option unattractive.  The supply of metal silicon, a feedstock for polysilicon, has been a concern due to shortages and price fluctuations. However, analysts believe that the shortage in metal silicon is not a structural issue and that the situation has become more reasonable with a decrease in prices. Global commodity price increases, including silver, copper, aluminum, glass, and steel, are also impacting the solar industry and module costs.  In terms of recent deals, LONGi Solar has signed a two-year wafer supply deal with DAS Solar worth up to US$1.1 billion. This contract highlights the demand for solar wafers and the potential impact on polysilicon prices. Additionally, Shuangliang Ecoenergy has secured a polysilicon supply contract with Asia Silicon, further emphasizing the importance of polysilicon in the market.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices will remain high in the near future, with potential decreases starting in 2022. The pace of capacity expansion in China may be affected by energy consumption quotas, and the availability of polysilicon from sources outside of China is dependent on longer-term price signals. The supply of metal silicon is not seen as a major issue, and global commodity price increases are impacting module costs. The recent deals in the industry highlight the demand for polysilicon and its significant role in the PV market./n

According to the news from pv magazine, China's PV demand is expected to reach 70 GW next year, while global module demand is projected to range between 196 GW and 212 GW, up more than 20% from this year. The rising deployment of solar+storage is also expected to accelerate steady solar growth. However, there are major threats to 2022 deployments, including the international trade situation and China's power rationing. If China relaxes power rationing, the pace of PV module price decreases will be subject to polysilicon prices.  Polysilicon manufacturers are expected to bring new capacity online as scheduled, leading to an annual polysilicon production of 700,000 MT, which is enough to supply approximately 255 GW of end-user demand. However, the supply of polysilicon is expected to remain tight in the first half of 2022 due to the ramping up of in-house wafer capacity by vertically integrated companies and the expansion of new wafer players. This increase in wafer capacity will push up demand for polysilicon, and the newly installed furnaces require three to six months to ramp up fully.  As a result, the supply of polysilicon is expected to remain tight in the first half of 2022, with prices decreasing too slowly to ease high PV module cost pressures. Polysilicon prices are projected to hover around CNY 190/kg ($26.35/kg) by mid-2022. Additionally, if the United States continues its sanctions against Xinjiang, polysilicon prices in regions outside of China may be slightly higher.  The news also highlights that PV module prices primarily appear to be the result of surging commodity prices, with polysilicon being a major contributor. The raw feedstock for crystalline silicon ingots and wafers has increased by 175% in the first six months of 2021 alone. While manufacturing costs have been reduced by module suppliers, the high prices of commodity inputs, including polysilicon, are out of control for manufacturers.  In terms of recent developments, Daqo, a polysilicon manufacturer based in Xinjiang, has announced a RMB33.3 billion (US$5.2 billion) investment plan to expand production capacity in Baotou City, Inner Mongolia. This investment includes the deployment of a further 200,000 metric tons of annual production capacity for polysilicon. The expansion of polysilicon production capacity by Daqo and other companies is expected to contribute to the tight supply of polysilicon in the first half of 2022.  Overall, the news suggests that the supply of polysilicon will remain tight in the first half of 2022 due to the increasing demand from the expansion of wafer capacity and the slow decrease in prices. Polysilicon prices are projected to hover around CNY 190/kg ($26.35/kg) by mid-2022. The expansion of production capacity by companies like Daqo will contribute to the tight supply situation. Additionally, the international trade situation and China's power rationing pose major threats to 2022 deployments and may impact the pace of PV module price decreases./n

According to the news from pv magazine, China's PV demand is expected to reach 70 GW next year, while global module demand is projected to range between 196 GW and 212 GW, up more than 20% from this year. The rising deployment of solar+storage is also expected to accelerate solar growth. However, there are major threats to 2022 deployments, including the international trade situation and China's power rationing. If China relaxes power rationing, the pace of PV module price decreases will be subject to polysilicon prices.  Polysilicon manufacturers are expected to bring new capacity online as scheduled, leading to an annual polysilicon production of 700,000 MT, which is enough to supply approximately 255 GW of end-user demand. However, the supply of polysilicon is expected to remain tight in the first half of 2022 due to the ramping up of in-house wafer capacity by vertically integrated companies and the expansion of new wafer players. This increase in wafer capacity will push up demand for polysilicon, and the newly installed furnaces require three to six months to ramp up fully.  As a result, the supply of polysilicon is expected to be insufficient to ease high PV module cost pressures, leading to a projection of polysilicon prices hovering around CNY 190/kg ($26.35/kg) by mid-2022. Additionally, if the United States continues its sanctions against Xinjiang, polysilicon prices in regions outside of China may be slightly higher.  The news also mentions that PV module prices primarily appear to be the result of surging commodity prices, with polysilicon being a major contributor. The raw feedstock for crystalline silicon ingots and wafers has increased by 175% in the first six months of 2021 alone. While new capacity is set to come online, high prices are expected to continue through at least the first half of 2022.  In terms of production capacity expansion, Xinjiang-based polysilicon manufacturer Daqo has announced a RMB33.3 billion (US$5.2 billion) investment plan to expand production capacity in Baotou City, Inner Mongolia. This includes the deployment of an additional 200,000 metric tons of annual production capacity for polysilicon.  Overall, the news highlights the tight supply of polysilicon in the first half of 2022 due to increasing demand from wafer players and the slow ramp-up of newly installed furnaces. This, coupled with the potential impact of sanctions on polysilicon from Xinjiang, suggests that polysilicon prices will remain high in the near future./n

According to recent news, major polysilicon and wafer producer GCL-Poly Energy Holdings has completed its granular silicon facility and is expecting a net profit of RMB5.4 billion (US$850 million) for 2021. The company credits the granular silicon project for strengthening its financial position, with the gross profit margin of the granular silicon products higher than that of the rod silicon. GCL-Poly completed the construction of its 30,000MT granular silicon facility in 2021, with a production capacity of 20,000MT. The remaining 10,000MT is expected to come online in February. The company expects a significant increase in profit for 2021 compared to the previous year, due to a decrease in aggregate losses for its non-solar material business segment and a decrease in finance costs.  In terms of polysilicon prices, a downward trend is anticipated this year, with prices expected to improve from the current levels of $26-$30/kg to as low as $19/kg by the end of the year. However, prices have recently ticked back up to about $30/kg due to decreased polysilicon inventories driven by seasonality ahead of Chinese New Year and a rebound in utilization levels from the end of 2021. Inventory levels across the solar value chain are expected to begin building through the first half of 2022. Currently, inventory levels are below healthy levels, with polysilicon inventory at about two weeks and wafers holding less than one week of inventory.  The report also predicts an increase in production of polysilicon and wafers globally in 2022, with an inventory build of about 30 GW above forecast production for modules. This may result in pricing support for polysilicon and wafers throughout 2022. Capacity expansions are expected across the value chain, driven by inventory considerations due to ongoing Covid logistics. Lowered polysilicon pricing is expected to have a ripple effect through the supply chain, leading to a drop in module prices.  In terms of specific companies, solar manufacturer Longi has unexpectedly raised the prices of all its PV wafers, marking the first time prices have increased since May last year. Polysilicon supplier and solar cell maker Tongwei has agreed to buy a large quantity of wafers from solar wafer manufacturer Shuangliang Eco-Energy, and Yingli has announced that its aggregate PV module capacity has reached 8GW. Polysilicon maker and inverter company TBEA expects a significant increase in net profits for 2021, attributed to the increase in both polysilicon price and sales volume.  Overall, the news suggests that while there may be a downward trend in polysilicon prices, inventory levels are expected to build and capacity expansions are underway. These factors, along with the strong demand for renewable energy installations, may impact the future prices of polysilicon in the China and global PV market./n

According to a strategic expert, the future scenario for polysilicon prices is difficult to predict due to the unprecedented levels it is currently at. However, it is expected that polysilicon prices may decline throughout the year and reach around $20/kg by the end of December. In the longer term, there is likely to be overcapacity in the global polysilicon industry by late 2023. The expert also mentioned that the evolution of gross margins for polysilicon manufacturers and electricity prices in China will play a significant role in determining prices in late 2023 and through 2024. If electricity prices continue to increase, it could push up costs for manufacturers and subsequently increase prices. Non-Chinese producers are unlikely to change the current scenario in the near term, as capacity expansions are mainly focused in China. However, there could be capacity additions in India under the PLI scheme in 2024 or 2025, and in the USA if proposed manufacturing incentives are introduced.   In recent news, solar manufacturer LONGi Solar has increased prices for its PV wafers, reaching four-month highs due to spikes in polysilicon prices. This is the third consecutive month that LONGi has increased its prices. The average spot price for polysilicon, including China's 20% sales tax, fell towards the end of last year but has risen again following the Chinese New Year. Last week's average prices indicated a rise to around RMB240/kg, with some quotes reaching as high as RMB250/kg.  The China Electricity Council (CEA) has estimated that 500,000 tons of annual polysilicon production capacity will come online this year, leading to a reverse in polysilicon prices that rose sharply last year. Chinese polysilicon manufacturer Daqo has signed a five-year deal to supply around 30,000 tons of polysilicon to a leading solar manufacturing company in China. The CEA expects expansions in cell and module production lines to resume this year, with around 45GW of new annual solar panel manufacturing capacity arriving by the end of December and more than 55GW next year. Chinese demand and manufacturing plans in Europe are expected to contribute to the growth of the solar market in the coming years.  Solar wafer prices have continued to rise, with a price increase of between 10.8% to 14.4% since the start of the year. LONGi Solar increased its wafer prices to a four-month high, and the average price for 182mm wafers corresponds with the average price issued by PV InfoLink. The recent price hikes highlight the link between polysilicon and wafering prices. However, polysilicon prices appear to be stable this week, indicating that wafer manufacturers may be beginning to flex utilization rates again. Polysilicon provider Daqo New Energy reported selling slightly less polysilicon than expected in the fourth quarter, with lower-than-anticipated average selling prices. This reduction in demand caused the polysilicon average selling price to fall. However, polysilicon prices have since recovered, and Daqo expects the average selling price to increase in 2022./n

According to recent news, LONGi Solar, the world's most valuable solar technology company, has signed an agreement with Tongwei, an upstream provider of polysilicon, to procure over 200,000 metric tonnes (MT) of polysilicon over a two-year period. The purchase price for the polysilicon will be settled through monthly negotiations, but based on current average selling prices (ASPs) of RMB245.3/kg, the contract is estimated to be worth RMB44.2 billion (US$6.94 billion), excluding tax. This agreement is expected to ensure the long-term and stable supply of polysilicon raw materials for LONGi and will not negatively impact its current performance.  Polysilicon pricing has been high recently, reaching a near four-month high, and this has had a significant impact on the solar value chain. Both LONGi and Tongwei have already increased their wafer and cell prices earlier this month. However, it is expected that polysilicon prices may decline throughout the year, potentially reaching around $20/kg by the end of December. In the longer term, it is anticipated that the global polysilicon industry will be able to meet total demand, leading to potential overcapacity by late 2023. Until then, polysilicon prices may be subject to fluctuations.  The future scenario for polysilicon prices is difficult to predict, especially in the second half of the year. Factors such as gross margins for polysilicon manufacturers and electricity prices in China will play a crucial role. It is expected that gross margins will come down as new polysilicon capacity comes online, but if electricity prices continue to increase, it could push up costs for manufacturers and subsequently increase prices. The expectation is that polysilicon prices will come back down to around $10/kg by the end of 2023, assuming electricity prices do not increase aggressively.  Non-Chinese producers are unlikely to change the current scenario in the near term, as planned capacity expansions are primarily focused in China. There may be some capacity additions in India under the PLI scheme, but not until 2024 or 2025. The introduction of manufacturing incentives in the USA could also lead to capacity expansions. Overall, the global polysilicon industry is expected to meet demand, but the market will continue to experience fluctuations in the coming years.  In addition to the agreement between LONGi and Tongwei, other developments in the polysilicon industry include Wuxi Shangji Automation's plan to invest RMB11.8 billion ($1.67 billion) in expanding its manufacturing capacity for polysilicon by 100,000 MT and its capacity for silicon metal by another 150,000 MT. This investment will be implemented in two phases and is expected to contribute to the overall supply of polysilicon.  Furthermore, the chairman of the China Photovoltaic Industry Association (CPIA) has stated that the Chinese PV market is expected to grow significantly this year, with an increase of 36.7% to 64% compared to 2021. The Chinese polysilicon industry also saw growth, producing 505,000 metric tons of raw material last year, up 28.8% from the previous year. These developments indicate a positive outlook for the polysilicon market in China and the global PV market.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices are currently high but may decline in the future. The market is expected to experience fluctuations, but the global polysilicon industry is anticipated to meet demand. Factors such as gross margins for manufacturers and electricity prices in China will play a crucial role in determining future polysilicon prices./n

According to recent news, LONGi Solar, the world's most valuable solar technology company, has signed a two-year agreement with polysilicon provider Tongwei to procure over 200,000 metric tonnes (MT) of polysilicon. The purchase price for the polysilicon will be settled through monthly negotiations, but based on current average selling prices (ASPs) of RMB245.3/kg, the contract is estimated to be worth RMB44.2 billion (US$6.94 billion), excluding tax. This agreement is expected to ensure the long-term and stable supply of polysilicon raw materials for LONGi and will not negatively impact its current performance.  Polysilicon pricing has been high recently, with prices reaching a near four-month high. This increase in prices has had a ripple effect throughout the solar value chain. Both LONGi and Tongwei have already increased their wafer and cell prices earlier this month. The continued collaboration between the two companies is evident, as they have previously signed wafer supply contracts in 2020.  In addition, there are expectations of a reverse in polysilicon prices due to the increase in production capacity. The China Electricity Council (CEA) has estimated that 500,000 tons of annual polysilicon production capacity will come online this year, with many facilities set to hit full production in early to mid-2022. This increase in production capacity is expected to contribute to a decrease in polysilicon prices, which rose sharply last year and led to solar panel price hikes.  Furthermore, there are geopolitical factors that could impact the polysilicon market. The CEA speculates that Beijing may remove clean electricity from its "dual control" policy, which limits energy consumption and energy intensity of manufacturing processes. This policy change could potentially affect Chinese demand and have implications for the polysilicon market.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices have been on the rise, but there are indications of a potential reversal in the future due to increased production capacity. The agreement between LONGi and Tongwei for the procurement of polysilicon is expected to ensure a stable supply for LONGi. However, geopolitical factors and government policies could also play a role in shaping the future of the polysilicon market./n

According to recent news, LONGi, the world's most valuable solar technology company, has signed a two-year agreement with upstream provider Tongwei to procure over 200,000 metric tonnes (MT) of polysilicon. The purchase price for the polysilicon will be settled through monthly negotiations, but based on current average selling prices (ASPs) of RMB245.3/kg, the contract is estimated to be worth RMB44.2 billion (US$6.94 billion), excluding tax. This agreement is in line with LONGi's future needs for silicon business and aims to ensure a long-term and stable supply of polysilicon raw materials.  Polysilicon pricing has been on the rise, reaching a near four-month high last week. The high prices are attributed to the insufficient release of silicon materials from Tongwei, GCL, Xinte, and Asia Silicon, leading to a shortage in the market. The average transaction price for monocrystal re-feeding material in China has increased to RMB248,200/ton ($38,958/ton), a week-on-week increase of 0.16%. This increase in polysilicon prices has had an impact on the solar value chain, prompting LONGi and Tongwei to increase their wafer and cell prices earlier this month.  In terms of government policies, LONGi has expressed concerns about potential changes in electricity prices in Yunnan Province. The company had signed a strategic cooperation framework agreement with the People's Government of Yunnan Province in 2016 for investment in the monocrystalline photovoltaic industry. However, if the electricity price agreed upon in the original cooperation agreement cannot be enacted, LONGi anticipates an increase in production costs and potential risks for unfinished PV investment projects in Yunnan Province.  Overall, the news suggests that the polysilicon market is experiencing high prices due to a shortage of materials. The agreement between LONGi and Tongwei aims to secure a stable supply of polysilicon for LONGi's future needs. However, potential changes in government policies, such as electricity prices, could impact production costs and investment projects in certain regions. These factors should be considered when analyzing the future prices of polysilicon in the China and global PV market./n

According to recent news, LONGi, the world's most valuable solar technology company, has signed a two-year agreement with upstream provider Tongwei to procure over 200,000 metric tonnes (MT) of polysilicon. Polysilicon pricing has been on the rise, reaching a near four-month high last week. The prices for its G1 166mm and M6 158.75mm wafers have increased to RMB5.55 (US$0.87) and RMB5.35 per piece, respectively. This price increase is significant as it indicates a trend of rising prices for smaller silicon wafers since last year.  It is worth noting that logistic disruptions are starting to occur in China due to an increase in COVID-19 cases in some regions. This could potentially impact the supply chain and further contribute to the rise in polysilicon prices.  Overall, the news suggests that there is a strong upward trend in polysilicon prices due to the shortage of silicon materials and the increase in wafer prices. This could have a significant effect on the future prices of polysilicon in the China and global PV market./n

According to recent news, LONGi Solar, the world's most valuable solar technology company, has signed an agreement with polysilicon provider Tongwei to procure over 200,000 metric tonnes (MT) of polysilicon over a two-year period. The purchase price for the polysilicon will be settled through monthly negotiations, but based on current average selling prices (ASPs) of RMB245.3/kg, the contract is estimated to be worth RMB44.2 billion (US$6.94 billion), excluding tax. This agreement is expected to ensure the long-term and stable supply of polysilicon raw materials for LONGi and will not negatively impact its current performance.  The price of polysilicon has been on an upward trend, reaching CNY 255/kg ($40.04) recently, the highest level since mid-December 2020. This increase in polysilicon prices has had a ripple effect throughout the solar value chain, leading to higher prices for wafers and cells. LONGi and Tongwei have already increased their wafer and cell prices earlier this month. The China Nonferrous Metals Association (CNMA) has reported that polysilicon production output in China this month is expected to be between 54,000 and 55,000 metric tons, with poly imports anticipated to amount to 6,000-7,000 tons. The CNMA also expects wafer production to be around 24 GW, with supply and demand remaining tightly balanced.  In other news, NYSE-listed polysilicon company Daqo New Energy faces the risk of being de-listed from the US exchange in early 2024 unless it opens up its books to the US Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB). Daqo has been identified by the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) as having used an auditor whose working paper could not be fully inspected by the PCAOB. This could potentially lead to de-listing under the Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act.  Furthermore, LONGi has revised the price of its G1 and M6 p-type wafers, taking prices to a near five-month high. Logistic disruptions are also starting to occur in China due to an increase in Covid-19 cases in some regions. The average polysilicon price, including China's 20% sales tax, has remained steady at RMB240-246/kg in March, with supply remaining stable.  Overall, these developments in the polysilicon market, including the procurement agreement between LONGi and Tongwei, the increase in polysilicon prices, the potential de-listing of Daqo New Energy, and the revision of wafer prices by LONGi, are expected to have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices. It is important for industry players to closely monitor these developments and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

According to recent news, the price of polysilicon in China has been steadily increasing for the past 13 weeks. The latest price reached CNY 255/kg ($40.04) and rose 0.32% from the previous week. The China Nonferrous Metals Association (CNMA) also reported that polysilicon production output in China this month is expected to be between 54,000 and 55,000 metric tons, with imports anticipated to amount to 6,000-7,000 tons. The CNMA estimated that wafer production this month will be around 24 GW and stated that supply and demand will remain tightly balanced.  In other news, NYSE-listed polysilicon company Daqo New Energy is at risk of being de-listed from the US exchange in early 2024 unless it opens up its books to the US Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB). The company has been identified by the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) as having used an auditor whose working paper could not be fully inspected by the PCAOB. Daqo stated that it is actively exploring possible solutions to protect the interests of its stakeholders.  Furthermore, the Chinese Communist Party and the State Council have issued a joint document calling for a unified approach to polysilicon production. This indicates that the Chinese government is taking steps to regulate and support the polysilicon industry.  The rise in polysilicon prices can be attributed to various factors. The local epidemic in China has caused hindrances to raw materials, production, logistics, and other aspects, leading to an increase in the price of silicon material. The average transaction price for polysilicon has risen to RMB 253,300/ton ($39,303/ton), a week-on-week increase of 0.72%.  Additionally, Chinese polysilicon producers have been experiencing significant growth. Shuangliang Eco-Energy reported a year-on-year increase of 299.5% in operating income for Q1/2022. The company attributes this growth to the promotion of the dual carbon policy, the commissioning of new projects, and increased sales.  TCL Technology and its subsidiary Zhonghuan Co., Ltd. have signed an agreement with GCL Group and GCL Technology to build a 100,000-ton granular silicon project. This partnership indicates further expansion and development in the polysilicon industry.  It is worth noting that German polysilicon manufacturer Wacker Chemie has shifted its focus to semiconductor-linked material, which may result in a decline in its ranking among global polysilicon producers. Analysts predict that China will dominate more than 90% of global polysilicon supply by 2023.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices are on the rise due to various factors such as production hindrances, government regulations, and industry growth. It is important for stakeholders in the polysilicon market to closely monitor these developments and consider establishing non-Chinese supply chains to mitigate risks associated with overreliance on individual markets./n

According to recent news, the price of polysilicon in China has been steadily increasing over the past 13 weeks, reaching CNY 255/kg ($40.04). The China Nonferrous Metals Association (CNMA) reported that polysilicon production output in China is expected to be between 54,000 and 55,000 metric tons this month, with imports anticipated to amount to 6,000-7,000 tons. The CNMA also stated that wafer production this month will be around 24 GW and that supply and demand will remain balanced.  In other news, NYSE-listed polysilicon company Daqo New Energy is at risk of being de-listed from the US exchange in 2024 unless it opens up its books to the US Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB). The company has been identified by the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) as having used an auditor whose working paper could not be fully inspected by the PCAOB. Daqo is actively exploring possible solutions to protect the interests of its stakeholders.  In terms of market developments, Chinese vertically integrated solar PV company LONGi has increased the price of silicon wafers. Energy enterprise Ganneng plans to invest RMB 12.8 billion ($1.94 billion) in various clean energy projects, including centralized photovoltaic power generation. Zhonghuan Semiconductor, a Chinese solar wafer manufacturer, has also increased its silicon wafer prices. Automation equipment manufacturer Autowell Technology plans to raise RMB 530 million ($80.43 million) to develop high-end intelligent equipment.  Furthermore, the price of silicon material has been rising due to hindrances in production caused by the local epidemic in China. The price of silicon material has reached RMB 259,000/ton ($40,187/ton), with an average transaction price of RMB 253,300/ton ($39,303/ton). Shuangliang Eco-Energy has achieved significant growth in Q1/2022, mainly due to the promotion of the dual carbon policy and increased sales in polysilicon reduction furnaces and monocrystalline silicon ingots/wafers. Zhonghuan and GCL have signed an agreement to build a 100,000 ton granular silicon project.  In terms of global rankings, German polysilicon manufacturer Wacker Chemie has fallen down the list due to its increased focus on semiconductor-linked material rather than solar-grade polysilicon. China is expected to corner more than 90% of global supply by 2023, with Tongwei and GCL Technology becoming the top producers. Daqo New Energy and Wacker are ranked third and fourth, respectively.  Overall, these news developments indicate that polysilicon prices are on the rise in China due to various factors such as production hindrances, market expansions, and geopolitical conflicts. It is important for stakeholders to closely monitor these developments and consider strategic decisions to navigate the changing market dynamics./n

According to recent news, there are several factors that are expected to have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. One of the key factors is the increase in silicon wafer prices by Chinese solar PV company LONGi. This investment could potentially lead to increased production capacity for polysilicon, which could in turn affect prices in the market. Based on the news, there are several factors that are expected to have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.   Firstly, there is a shortage of silicon materials, which has led to a rise in prices. The average price of domestic silicon remained stable, but the demand for silicon materials is still high, resulting in price increases. In May, the domestic polysilicon production increased by 7.2% from the previous month, but it is still not enough to meet the demand.  Secondly, there has been a price war between companies in the PV market. Wafer providers such as LONGi and Zhonghuan Semiconductor (TZS) and cell producer Tongwei have all increased their prices multiple times in the past weeks. This trend of price increases has been ongoing since the beginning of the year, as demand continues to outstrip supply. The recent increase in polysilicon prices is also a result of this price war.  Thirdly, government subsidies play a role in the polysilicon market. The Chinese government has been promoting the use of solar energy and has provided subsidies to support the PV industry. These subsidies can have an impact on the demand for polysilicon and consequently affect its prices.  Lastly, geopolitical conflicts can also affect the polysilicon market. The COVID-19 lockdowns in China have disrupted the value chain, leading to supply chain issues and price increases. Additionally, the global supply chain has been affected by geopolitical tensions, which can further impact the availability and prices of polysilicon.  In summary, the shortage of silicon materials, price wars between companies, government subsidies, and geopolitical conflicts are all factors that are expected to have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. These factors contribute to the current rise in prices and are likely to continue influencing the market in the upcoming months. As a strategic expert, it is important to closely monitor these developments and make informed decisions based on the latest news and trends in the polysilicon market./n

The price of polysilicon in China has reached its highest level since 2011, reaching CNY 270 ($40.39)/kg. This increase is attributed to a combination of limited silicon metal supply and growing demand from downstream businesses. Despite earlier forecasts predicting a decrease in polysilicon prices, they have remained high and continue to rise, currently standing at more than 30% above estimations. There were concerns that the recent earthquake in Sichuan, where several PV manufacturing facilities are located, could lead to reduced output, but no confirmation of this has been reported so far.  While polysilicon prices have been on the rise, this increase has not yet spread to the solar supply chain, particularly to wafer prices. Prices for 166mm, 182mm, and 210mm wafers have remained flat for four consecutive weeks. However, Tongwei, a solar cell producer, has confirmed marginal increases for its 166mm and 182mm solar cells. Prices for 210mm cells have remained unchanged.  The China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association reports that the price of polysilicon has risen to CNY 226 ($39.90) per kg and may continue to increase due to strong demand. The association also notes that the current polysilicon supply glut could potentially lead to an increase in wafer prices. Additionally, recent earthquakes in Sichuan province have affected three ingot casting factories, potentially impacting wafer production and prices.  In terms of new investments and projects, Longi, a module manufacturer, has commissioned a 5 GW solar cell factory in Ningxia Province as part of a larger 10 GW project. Gokin Solar, a wafer manufacturer, has signed an agreement with the government of Yibin City for the construction of a monocrystalline ingot factory with a capacity of 50 GW. Jinchen, a PV production equipment manufacturer, will provide India's Adani Solar with 2 GW solar panel production lines. Xinyi Solar, a photovoltaic panel glassmaker, experienced a significant shareholder revolt at its AGM, potentially impacting the company's future decisions.  Overall, the news indicates that polysilicon prices in China are on the rise due to limited supply and increasing demand. While wafer prices have remained flat for now, there is potential for them to increase in the future. The recent earthquake in Sichuan province could also have an impact on wafer production and prices. It is important for stakeholders in the polysilicon market to closely monitor these developments and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

The price of polysilicon in China has reached its highest level ever recorded, reaching CNY 280/kg this week. This increase is mainly due to a reduction in production output, as several factories are undergoing seasonal maintenance. The China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association predicts that this limited supply will continue to drive up prices in the future.  In terms of company developments, Tongwei has agreed to supply Yuze Semiconductor with 161,100 MT of polysilicon over a four and a half year period. This partnership will involve a monthly negotiated price for the polysilicon supply. Additionally, Beijing Energy International has reported an increase in the engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) bill for a 112 MW agrivoltaic project in Shandong province. The bill has risen by CNY 42 million to CNY 478 million, with Nenggao Automation serving as the EPC contractor.  Golden Power has announced plans to invest AUD 104,000 in a 51% stake in Australian electricity software developer Ienergy Power. This investment is contingent on Ienergy securing a license from the Australian Energy Regulator to operate as an energy retailer. Golden Power also plans to provide funding for the development of heterojunction PV modules and flexible modules in the Australian residential PV market.  Huasun has signed a cooperation agreement with EcoSolifer Group, a Switzerland-based company with 100 MW of annual production capacity in Hungary. Under this agreement, EcoSolifer will share technology with Huasun and provide engineering, procurement, and construction services for large-scale heterojunction PV projects. Huasun aims to expand its annual production capacity from 2.7 GW to 6 GW by 2023.  In terms of recent news, the China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association reports that the price of polysilicon has reached CNY 270/kg, the highest level since 2011. This price increase is attributed to a difficult silicon metal supply and increasing market demand. Furthermore, Longi has commissioned a 5 GW solar cell factory in Ningxia Province, with plans to invest CNY 6.6 billion in the facility. Gokin Solar has also signed an agreement with the government of Yibin City for the construction of a monocrystalline ingot factory with a capacity of 50 GW.  Jinchen will provide India's Adani Solar with 2 GW solar panel production lines, marking the second major contract between the two companies. Xinyi Solar experienced a significant shareholder revolt at its AGM, with over 37% of stockholders voting against a proposal to issue shares. Lastly, IDG Energy Investment Ltd has announced the production of its first solar cell wet processing equipment as part of a two-unit order for an undisclosed customer.  Overall, the limited supply of polysilicon, coupled with increasing market demand and company developments, is expected to continue driving up prices in the future./n

The news related to polysilicon prices in the upcoming months suggests that there is a significant effect on the China and global PV market. This increase in price is mainly due to a reduction in production output of around 3,500 metric tons, as well as seasonal maintenance that will further weigh on supply and drive up prices.  In addition to the supply shortage, there is also a price war between companies in the polysilicon market.
