The price of polysilicon in China has reached a record high of CNY 280/kg, driven by a reduction in production output and seasonal maintenance of factories. This increase in price has also led to a rise in silicon wafer prices. The supply shortage has been further exacerbated by a fire at an East Hope-owned facility, which is expected to reduce output for about a month. Despite the high demand in the industry, other polysilicon production facilities in the country are also expected to undergo maintenance works. As a result, manufacturers are being forced into long-term orders without specifying the price just to secure supply. The bottleneck in the polysilicon and ingoting stage is expected to keep prices rising, with prices expected to remain high until the end of the year when new polysilicon production capacity is expected to come online. Power rationing has also contributed to the limited supply of polysilicon, with one producer reducing output and another experiencing an unplanned shutdown. The sustained price rises have defied projections that pricing would decline as more capacity comes online. However, it is expected that polysilicon prices will fall in the fourth quarter of this year as more production capacity becomes available./n

TZS has confirmed the acceleration of new manufacturing capacity construction, with the completion of the construction phase of its 50GW polysilicon facility. This facility is touted as the world's largest and most advanced mono silicon factory.  Polysilicon prices in China have continued to climb due to limited supply and power rationing. The average price for polysilicon reached RMB 273.1/kg, representing an 11-year high. One polysilicon producer reduced output due to power rationing, while another had an unplanned shutdown. The high prices are attributed to strong demand and limited supply. Although there was a short-term effect from a factory accident, it is expected to be minor in the annual context. Polysilicon producers such as Tongwei, TZS, and Daqo New Energy have announced plans to scale up production, but the sustained price rises have defied projections of declining prices with increased capacity. However, it is expected that polysilicon prices will fall in Q4 of this year as more production capacity comes online./n

The news highlights that polysilicon prices in the solar industry have reached a new high, with prices rising by around 2.6% compared to the previous week. This increase marks the first time prices have surpassed last year's high and represents an 11-year high. The surge in prices can be attributed to sustained demand and panic buying from wafer manufacturers. Additionally, a fire at an East Hope-owned facility in Xinjiang has further exacerbated supply shortages, as the facility's output is expected to be reduced for approximately one month. Despite the high demand in the industry, other polysilicon production facilities in China are also expected to undergo maintenance works.  The high polysilicon prices have had a ripple effect throughout the solar value chain, leading to an increase in solar wafer and module prices. Manufacturers are now being forced to place long-term orders to secure supply, without specifying the price. The bottleneck in new capacity at the polysilicon and ingoting stage is expected to continue driving up prices, as demand for polysilicon and wafers shows no signs of abating. However, there is hope for increased supply in the future, as TZS is accelerating the construction of new manufacturing capacity.  In the following week, polysilicon prices continued to rise, increasing by around 3% compared to the previous week. The upward trend in prices has persisted for nearly three months due to strong demand, planned maintenance, and incidents that have disrupted production capacity. It is expected that prices will continue to rise until maintenance schedules are completed and facilities are restarted. There is a possibility that prices may surpass the RMB300/kg barrier. Reports suggest that the Chinese government is considering intervention in polysilicon pricing, similar to the measures taken in late 2020 to address the spike in solar glass prices.  The increase in polysilicon prices has led to higher costs for solar component manufacturers. Both LONGi and Tongwei have confirmed price increases for solar wafers and cells, respectively. LONGi increased its wafer prices by 3.2% to 4.2% for August, while Tongwei implemented price rises of 3.2% to 4%. These price increases are directly influenced by the rising costs of polysilicon.  Furthermore, there have been significant developments in the polysilicon market. Xinte has secured an eight-year deal to supply polysilicon to wafer maker Shuangliang Silicon Materials, valued at CNY 58.5 billion. Beijing Energy International has also announced that its subsidiary has secured an EPC contract for a 100 MW agrivoltaic project. These developments indicate the continued growth and investment in the polysilicon market.  Overall, the news highlights the significant impact of polysilicon prices on the solar industry. The sustained demand, supply shortages, and potential government intervention are expected to continue driving up prices. Manufacturers are facing challenges in securing supply and are being forced into long-term orders without price specifications. However, there is hope for increased supply in the future with the construction of new manufacturing capacity./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that are expected to have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.   Firstly, TBEA, a solar-grade polysilicon producer and PV project contractor, has signed a contract to supply 201,900 MT of polysilicon to Shuangliang Silicon Materials from January 2023 to December 2030. The contract value is estimated to be approximately 58.470 billion yuan. This indicates a strong demand for polysilicon in the coming years, which could potentially drive up prices.  Secondly, there are reports suggesting that the Chinese government may intervene in polysilicon pricing. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT) is said to be exploring its options regarding a possible intervention. In the past, the MIIT has enacted measures to release new production capacity quicker in response to price spikes in other solar components. If the government decides to intervene in polysilicon pricing, it could have a significant impact on prices.  Thirdly, there have been price increases in solar wafer and cell prices, driven by the rising cost of polysilicon. Companies like LONGi and Tongwei have confirmed price increases for their solar wafers and cells. This trend is expected to continue as long as polysilicon prices keep rising.   Additionally, there have been announcements of new production facilities and capacity expansions by polysilicon and solar component manufacturers. GCL Tech has started production at two new facilities with a total annual production capacity of 130,000 tons. Jolywood plans to expand its annual backsheet capacity, and Shuangliang Eco-Energy has agreed to sell a large number of wafers to Chint Group. These expansions indicate a growing supply of polysilicon, which could potentially stabilize or even lower prices in the future.  Overall, the combination of strong demand, potential government intervention, and capacity expansions in the polysilicon industry will likely have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the PV market, particularly in China, to closely monitor these developments and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. According to recent news, the average price of polysilicon in China has continued to rise due to electricity rationing, reaching the highest level ever recorded at CNY 312 ($45.47)/kg. This increase in prices has put pressure on both spot market rates and long-term contract holders. However, it is expected that prices will remain in the mid-US$30/kg range for large-scale buyers until the end of 2022, with the first declines anticipated in Q1 2023 as the market rush in China and increased polysilicon expansion lead to oversupply.  In response to the rising prices, the Chinese government has called for regional authorities to take action to halt further increases. The government agencies have encouraged cooperation between polysilicon and wafer producers, wafer and cell producers, module and inverter manufacturers, and PV glass makers. They have also called for the creation of strategic alliances, long-term agreements, and technical cooperation.  Furthermore, it has been reported that the production output of polysilicon in September is expected to reach a new high, driven by the completion of overhaul procedures and the release of newly added capacity. This increase in supply is expected to improve the operating rate of silicon wafer manufacturers and lead to considerable profit margins. However, once downstream demand weakens, the operating rate of silicon wafers may decline, leading to a reversal in market supply and demand patterns.  The rise in polysilicon prices has also caused upward price pressure on the costs of components and solar power plants. Wafers, cells, and components have all experienced price increases. Additionally, LONGi, a major player in the polysilicon market, has announced plans for capacity expansion to meet production targets. They aim to achieve an operating revenue of more than RMB100 billion (US$14.62 billion) in 2022 and have set targets for annual production capacity of mono silicon chips, mono cells, and mono modules.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices in the future will be influenced by factors such as government actions, supply and demand dynamics, and the expansion plans of major companies. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon market to closely monitor these developments and consider their potential impact on prices./n

According to recent news, the average price of polysilicon in China has continued to rise due to electricity rationing, reaching the highest level ever recorded at CNY 312 ($45.47)/kg. This increase in price has put pressure on both spot market buyers and long-term contract holders. However, it is expected that prices will remain in the mid-US$30/kg range for large-scale buyers until the end of 2022, with the first declines in pricing anticipated in Q1 2023.  In response to the rising prices, the Chinese government has taken action to halt further increases. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, the State Administration for Market Regulation, and China's National Energy Administration have called on regional authorities to coordinate efforts to reduce prices. The government agencies have encouraged cooperation between polysilicon and wafer producers, wafer and cell producers, module and inverter manufacturers, and PV glass makers. They have also called for the creation of strategic alliances, long-term agreements, and technical cooperation.  The price fluctuations of silicon and other raw materials have greatly affected the profits of companies in the polysilicon industry. If the price of upstream raw materials fluctuates sharply and companies fail to effectively manage their inventory, their profits may be dampened. Silicon prices have reached a decade high this year, leading to concerns about inventory prices and production costs.  Furthermore, a new policy is expected to increase wafer costs and non-silicon costs by 6% to 8%, and the cost of polysilicon production by 12% to 15%. This is due to the fact that power costs account for a significant portion of wafer production costs and the cost of producing polysilicon. Companies like Longi and Zhonghuan are carefully evaluating the potential impact of this policy shift.  It is worth noting that regional governments in China often offer preferential pricing policies to attract investment, but policy uncertainty can have a negative impact on investor sentiment. Therefore, it is important for companies in the polysilicon industry to closely monitor government actions and policy changes that may affect prices in the future./n

Based on the news articles, there are several factors that are expected to have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.   Firstly, the average price of polysilicon in China has been rising due to electricity rationing, which has caused constraints in the supply of polysilicon. This has led to high prices even for long-term contract holders. It is expected that prices will remain in the mid-US$30/kg range for large-scale buyers until the end of 2022, with the first declines in pricing anticipated in Q1 2023 as the market rush in China and increased polysilicon expansion may lead to oversupply.  Secondly, the fluctuation of upstream raw material prices, such as silicon, can greatly affect the profitability of companies in the polysilicon industry. Sharp fluctuations in raw material prices can result in inventory price drops or production cost fluctuations, which can dampen profits. Silicon prices have reached a decade high this year, and the suspension of polysilicon price publication by the Silicon Industry Branch of China Non-Ferrous Metal Industry Association suggests a desire to avoid over-interpretation and misunderstanding of the market.  Additionally, there have been some developments in the industry that may impact future polysilicon prices. For example, LONGi, a Chinese solar PV company, has released its latest silicon wafer prices, which have remained unchanged from the previous month. Jolywood, an N-type solar module manufacturer, has completed a 4 GW high-efficiency cell facility and is preparing to begin construction on the remaining 4 GW facility. Hongling Silicon Materials has signed a deal for an annual output of 100,000 tons of high-purity crystalline silicon, which will provide high-quality polysilicon for N-type wafers. Zhongli has also begun construction on a 2 GW PV module factory.  Furthermore, there are government actions and policies that can impact polysilicon prices. For example, a new policy in China is expected to increase wafer costs and non-silicon costs, as well as the cost of polysilicon production. This is due to the fact that power costs account for a significant portion of wafer production costs and the cost of producing polysilicon. Changes in power price policies in different regions of China can create uncertainty and impact investor sentiment.  In summary, the news suggests that the future prices of polysilicon in the China and global PV market will be influenced by factors such as electricity rationing, fluctuations in raw material prices, industry developments, and government policies. It is expected that prices will remain high in the short term but may start to decline in 2023 as the market reaches a state of oversupply./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market. One major factor is the fluctuation of silicon and other raw material prices. The H1 2022 report of a company mentioned that its profit is greatly affected by price fluctuations of silicon and other raw materials. If the price of upstream raw materials fluctuates sharply and the company fails to effectively manage its inventory, the company's inventory price may drop or production cost may fluctuate, dampening the company's profits. This indicates that the prices of polysilicon could be influenced by the volatility of raw material prices.  Another factor to consider is the suspension of the publication of polysilicon prices by the Silicon Industry Branch of China Non-Ferrous Metal Industry Association. The association decided to suspend the publication of polysilicon prices to avoid over-interpretation and misunderstanding. Before the pause was announced, polysilicon prices had risen for 29 straight weeks this year without a sign of correction, hitting a 10-year high. This suggests that the suspension of price publication could create uncertainty in the market and potentially impact future polysilicon prices.  Additionally, there have been significant developments in the production and supply of polysilicon. Companies like Jolywood and Hongling Silicon have completed or signed deals for the construction of high-capacity polysilicon facilities. Jolywood completed a 4 GW high-efficiency cell facility, marking the partial completion of its 16 GW high-efficiency monocrystalline cell factory. Hongling Silicon signed a deal for an annual output of 100,000 tons of high-purity crystalline silicon. These developments indicate an increase in polysilicon production capacity, which could potentially affect future prices.  Furthermore, there have been policy shifts and geopolitical conflicts that could impact polysilicon prices. Changes in power price policies in certain Chinese regions, such as the termination of power price discounts in Yunnan province, have led to companies like Longi suspending projects and adjusting their plans. Policy uncertainty and geopolitical conflicts can have a negative impact on investor sentiment and potentially influence future polysilicon prices.  Lastly, major companies like JinkoSolar have signed significant polysilicon supply contracts worth billions of dollars. These long-term contracts indicate a commitment to securing polysilicon supply and could potentially impact future prices.  In summary, the fluctuation of raw material prices, the suspension of price publication, developments in production and supply, policy shifts, geopolitical conflicts, and major supply contracts are all factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market./n

According to the news, the price of polysilicon has been greatly impacting the profits of companies in the PV industry. Trina Solar, a leading PV and smart energy solution provider, has stated that the price fluctuations of silicon and other raw materials have a significant effect on their inventory prices and production costs, which in turn affects their profits. The price of silicon has reached a 10-year high this year, and polysilicon prices have been rising for 29 consecutive weeks without any signs of correction.  In response to the rising prices, the Silicon Industry Branch of China Non-Ferrous Metal Industry Association has decided to suspend the publication of polysilicon prices to avoid over-interpretation and misunderstanding. The Chinese government has also started talks with major PV companies to regulate the market and address the rise in polysilicon prices. It is believed that some companies have contributed to the price rise by stockpiling products for better deals, and the government is urging PV companies to regulate their sales activities and stop stockpiling.  In terms of market demand, Tongwei, a polysilicon supplier and solar cell manufacturer, has reported a significant increase in net profit attributable to shareholders due to rising market demand and higher polysilicon prices. This indicates that the demand for polysilicon is driving up prices and contributing to the profitability of companies in the industry.  Additionally, there have been updates on the capacity and production of PV modules and polysilicon. Trina Solar, JinkoSolar, Longi, Da-Solar, CSI, Risen, and Tongwei have shared a 5.55 GW PV module order, indicating a strong demand for PV modules. Jolywood, an N-type solar module manufacturer, has completed a 4 GW high-efficiency cell facility, marking the partial completion of their 16 GW high-efficiency monocrystalline cell factory. Hongling Silicon Materials has signed a deal for an annual output of 100,000 tons of high-purity crystalline silicon, indicating an increase in production capacity. Zhongli has also begun construction on a 2 GW PV module factory.  Overall, the news highlights the significant impact of polysilicon prices on the PV market, with rising prices affecting the profits of companies and prompting government intervention. The strong demand for PV modules and polysilicon indicates a positive outlook for the industry, but the price fluctuations and government regulations will continue to play a crucial role in shaping the future prices of polysilicon./n

According to the news, there are several factors that are expected to have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices. One of the key factors is the rise in polysilicon prices since 2020, which has led to talks between major Chinese polysilicon suppliers and the government. The government is urging PV companies to regulate their sales activities and stop stockpiling products, as some companies have contributed to the price rise by hoarding polysilicon.  In addition, the report highlights the increasing demand for high-power modules in the global market. High-power PV products, with capacities of 600W or more, are becoming more popular, and many module manufacturers are showcasing such products using technologies like PERC, HJT, and TOPCon. This trend is expected to drive the demand for polysilicon, which could have an impact on its prices.  Furthermore, the report mentions the construction of new polysilicon production facilities. Hongling Silicon Materials has signed a deal to build a facility with an annual output of 100,000 tons of high-purity crystalline silicon. This new facility is expected to provide high-quality polysilicon for N-type wafers. Additionally, the global polysilicon manufacturing capacity is expected to double by the end of this year, which could potentially stabilize polysilicon prices by the end of next year.  The news also highlights the impact of various factors on polysilicon prices. The upstream sector of the PV industry has recorded higher prices, driven by high polysilicon prices as well as high silver and aluminum prices, increased logistics costs, and a shortage of semiconductors. The solar industry has seen a significant increase in the use of polysilicon, with China being the largest producer accounting for 94% of global polysilicon production in 2021. However, other countries like Germany, Malaysia, Norway, Turkey, and India are also entering the market or increasing their production capacity.  Overall, the news suggests that the rise in polysilicon prices, the increasing demand for high-power modules, the construction of new polysilicon production facilities, and the expansion of global polysilicon manufacturing capacity are all factors that could have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices. It is important for PV companies to monitor these developments and make strategic decisions accordingly./n

According to recent news, the price of polysilicon is expected to have a significant impact on the global PV market, particularly in China. The rise in polysilicon prices since 2020 has prompted talks between major Chinese polysilicon suppliers and government agencies, including the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, the State Administration for Market Regulation, and the National Energy Administration. These talks aim to address the increase in polysilicon prices, which have exceeded CNY 300 ($41.85)/kg.  The agencies have attributed the price rise to companies stockpiling polysilicon for better deals, leading to a shortage in supply. As a result, the government has urged PV companies to regulate their sales activities and stop stockpiling products. This intervention by the government suggests that there may be measures taken to stabilize polysilicon prices in the future.  In terms of production capacity, the global polysilicon manufacturing capacity is expected to double by the end of this year compared to the previous year. This increase in capacity is likely to contribute to the stabilization of polysilicon prices by the end of next year. Additionally, the entry of new players in the market, such as Norway, Turkey, and India, is expected to further increase production capacity in the coming years.  The impact of polysilicon prices on the PV industry is evident in the upstream sector, where higher prices have been recorded. Factors such as high silver and aluminum prices, increased logistics costs, and a shortage of semiconductors have also contributed to the overall increase in prices. However, it is expected that polysilicon prices will gradually decrease in the first half of 2023 and see a steep decline in the second half of the year.  China is expected to remain the world's largest polysilicon producer, but non-China polysilicon is predicted to represent up to 10% of total global capacity. The Uyghur Forced Labor Prevention Act in the US is expected to lead to an increase in polysilicon production in the country. Other countries, including Norway, Turkey, and Germany, are also ramping up or starting production.  In conclusion, the news suggests that polysilicon prices have been on the rise, prompting government intervention and talks with major suppliers. However, with the expected increase in production capacity and the entry of new players in the market, it is anticipated that polysilicon prices will stabilize in the future. This stabilization is likely to have a significant impact on the PV market, including the prices of high-efficiency modules, cell, wafer, and module manufacturing capacities./n

According to recent news, the price of polysilicon is expected to have a significant impact on the global PV market, particularly in China. The rise in polysilicon prices since 2020 has prompted talks between major Chinese polysilicon suppliers and government agencies, including the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, the State Administration for Market Regulation, and the National Energy Administration. These talks aim to address the increase in polysilicon prices, which have exceeded CNY 300 ($41.85)/kg.  The agencies have attributed the price rise to companies hoarding polysilicon for better deals, leading to stockpiling and contributing to the price increase. In response, the government has urged PV companies to regulate their sales activities and stop stockpiling products.  In terms of market demand and performance, Tongwei, a polysilicon supplier and solar cell manufacturer, has reported a significant increase in net profit attributable to shareholders. The company attributes this growth to rising market demand and higher polysilicon prices.  The International Energy Agency Photovoltaic Power Systems (IEA PVPS) has also published a report on trends in the photovoltaic industry, highlighting the impact of high polysilicon prices on the upstream sector. The report states that the global polysilicon manufacturing capacity is expected to double by the end of this year compared to the previous year. However, the report also suggests that the polysilicon price will stabilize by the end of next year.  Despite the increase in polysilicon prices, the PV industry has seen growth in various countries, including China, Malaysia, Vietnam, Germany, the US, India, Norway, and Turkey. These countries have gained space in the PV supply chain, with China remaining the largest producer. The report also mentions the entry of new players in the market, such as Norway and Turkey, and the expected increase in production in India and the US.  Looking ahead, PV Infolink forecasts a decrease in polysilicon prices from the current CNY 300/kg to below CNY 150/kg by the end of 2023. The consulting firm expects polysilicon production capacity to increase significantly, reaching 975 GW by the end of 2023. However, there may be a lag between nameplate and effective capacity.  China is expected to remain the largest polysilicon producer, but non-China polysilicon is predicted to represent up to 10% of total global capacity. The US is expected to increase polysilicon production following the Uyghur Forced Labor Prevention Act, and other countries like Norway, Turkey, and Germany are also ramping up or starting production.  In addition to polysilicon, cell, wafer, and module prices are also expected to decrease. PV Infolink predicts a gradual decline in cell pricing and a fall in wafer and module prices by the end of 2023.  Overall, the news suggests that the polysilicon market is experiencing significant changes, with price fluctuations and increased production capacity. These developments will likely have a strong impact on future polysilicon prices, particularly in the Chinese and global PV markets./n

The latest report from the IEA PVPS highlights that the PV industry has experienced higher prices in the upstream sector, primarily driven by high polysilicon prices. This increase in prices can be attributed to various factors such as high silver and aluminum prices, increased logistics costs, and a shortage of semiconductors. China continues to be the largest producer in the PV supply chain, but other countries like Malaysia, Vietnam, Germany, the US, India, Norway, and Turkey are also gaining prominence in the market.  The report suggests that the global polysilicon manufacturing capacity is expected to double by the end of this year compared to the previous year. Furthermore, it predicts that the polysilicon price will stabilize by the end of next year. The high prices in 2022 were maintained due to the growth in demand and the shutdown of several plants in China caused by electricity shortages.  In terms of production and consumption, the solar industry used 604,812 tons of polysilicon in 2021, accounting for 94% of the global polysilicon consumption. China was the largest producer with 623,000 tons, followed by Germany with 65,000 tons and Malaysia with 3,000 tons. However, other countries like Norway, Turkey, and India are entering the market or increasing their production capacity.  Several companies are also making significant developments in the polysilicon market. TBEA expects to produce around 120,000 MT of polysilicon in 2022, with plans to increase production to 250,000 MT next year. Daqo New Energy has approved a $700 million share repurchase program, indicating confidence in the market. PV Infolink forecasts a decrease in polysilicon prices from around CNY 300/kg currently to below CNY 150/kg by the end of 2023.  China is expected to remain the largest polysilicon producer, but non-China polysilicon is predicted to represent up to 10% of total global capacity. The UFLPA in the US is expected to increase polysilicon production in the country. Other countries like Norway, Turkey, and Germany are also ramping up or starting production. PV Infolink predicts that it will take two to three years for new entrants to be competitive with established players in terms of capacity, yield rate, and purity.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices are expected to decrease in the coming years due to increased production capacity and competition from non-China producers. This could have a significant impact on the China and global PV market, leading to more affordable solar energy solutions./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices.   Firstly, TBEA, a major polysilicon producer, expects to increase its production by 53.5% in 2022 and up to 250,000 MT in the following year. This increase in production capacity could potentially lead to a decrease in prices as supply outpaces demand.  Additionally, PV Infolink forecasts a decrease in polysilicon prices from the current level of CNY 300/kg to below CNY 150/kg by the end of 2023. This decline is expected to be gradual in the first half of 2023 and then steep in the second half of the year. The consulting firm also predicts a significant increase in polysilicon production capacity, reaching 975 GW by the end of 2023. However, there may be a lag between nameplate capacity and effective capacity.  China is expected to remain the largest polysilicon producer, but other countries such as the US, Norway, Turkey, and Germany are ramping up or starting production. This diversification of production sources may lead to higher prices for polysilicon from outside of China, with estimates ranging from 5% to 10% higher.  Furthermore, the shift towards n-type technology in solar cell manufacturing is expected to drive demand for polysilicon. Daqo New Energy, a polysilicon supplier, has signed long-term supply agreements with Chinese manufacturers and expects to benefit from the growing demand.  Overall, the combination of increased production capacity, diversification of production sources, and the shift towards n-type technology is likely to impact polysilicon prices in the future. Prices are expected to decrease, but the extent of the decrease will depend on various factors such as supply and demand dynamics, production costs, and geopolitical conflicts./n

According to PV InfoLink, polysilicon prices are currently experiencing a distinctive downward trend after months of high prices. The consulting firm predicts that prices will continue to fall significantly from the end of November into early December. This is attributed to an unhealthy inventory in the polysilicon sector, which is expected to persist until the end of the month. PV InfoLink also anticipates the first decline in polysilicon inventory in two years.  In terms of company developments, Longi has announced a reduction in its wafer prices, with p-type M6 products and p-type M10 wafers experiencing price decreases. JA Solar plans to invest approximately CNY 7.44 billion in a new 10 GW solar cell factory, aiming to reach a panel capacity of 50 GW by the end of this year and 75 GW by the end of 2023. JG Solar is currently testing n-type wafers for its heterojunction solar cell lines and expects to begin trial production in the first quarter of 2023. Solarspace has inaugurated the first stage of a 16 GW n-type TOPCon solar cell factory and plans to produce cells based on 182 mm and 210 mm wafers starting from 2023.  TBEA projects a significant increase in polysilicon production, expecting to produce around 120,000 MT in 2022 and up to 250,000 MT in 2023. The company has signed long-term polysilicon supply agreements with Chinese manufacturers such as Shuangliang and JinkoSolar. Daqo New Energy's board of directors has approved a $700 million share repurchase program, and the company maintains its full production capacity and production guidance for 2022. Daqo's subsidiary, Xinjiang Daqo, has signed a five-year polysilicon supply agreement with an undisclosed solar manufacturing company in China.  The demand for solar grade polysilicon remains strong, and Daqo New Energy expects solar cell technology to shift to n-type technology in the next few years. The company has increased its annual polysilicon production guidance and aims to benefit from these trends. Global polysilicon capacities are projected to reach 295 GW by the end of 2022 and 536 GW by the end of 2023.  Canadian Solar is facing challenges with volatility in foreign exchange rates and is closely monitoring the impact. The company's IPO to be listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange is still pending, and it is tied to a planned $9 billion polysilicon expansion. Canadian Solar expects polysilicon prices to have peaked and anticipates a decrease in input costs in the coming weeks. The company's manufacturing subsidiary, CSI Solar, is expanding its battery storage pipeline and has launched new products for the utility-scale and residential markets. Canadian Solar has also been involved in solar projects in Chile and Japan.  Overall, the news suggests a significant impact on future polysilicon prices, with a downward trend expected in the coming months. Factors such as inventory levels, company investments, production capacity, and market demand will play a crucial role in shaping the polysilicon market./n

According to recent news, polysilicon prices are expected to experience a significant decline in the coming months. PV InfoLink, a consulting firm, has stated that polysilicon prices are now on a "distinctive downward" trend after months of high prices. They anticipate a significant fall in prices from the end of November into early December. This decline is attributed to an unhealthy inventory in the polysilicon sector, which is expected to persist until the end of the month. PV InfoLink also predicts that this will be the first decline in polysilicon inventory in two years.  In October, PV InfoLink had already predicted a decrease in prices from around CNY 300/kg ($41.85) to below CNY 150/kg by the end of 2023. This indicates a substantial drop in prices over the next couple of years. However, polysilicon analyst Johannes Bernreuter remains cautious about a stronger decrease in prices, particularly in the first half of 2023. He believes that the current stabilization of polysilicon prices at high levels will only experience the usual seasonal drop at year-end.  In terms of market dynamics, there have been some notable developments. Longi, a major player in the industry, has recently lowered its wafer prices, which could have an impact on the overall polysilicon market. Additionally, JA Solar has announced plans to invest in a new 10 GW solar cell factory, indicating potential growth in the PV market. JG Solar is also testing n-type wafers for its solar cell lines, while Solarspace has inaugurated a new n-type TOPCon solar cell factory.  Furthermore, Daqo New Energy, a leading polysilicon producer, has signed multiple supply agreements with LONGi and an undisclosed Chinese manufacturer. These agreements involve the supply of high-purity mono-grade polysilicon over several years. The prices in these agreements will be negotiated monthly based on market conditions. Daqo New Energy has also recently approved a share repurchase program, indicating confidence in its future prospects.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices are expected to decline in the coming months, driven by factors such as inventory levels and market dynamics. However, caution should be exercised in predicting the extent of the price decrease, particularly in the first half of 2023. The signing of supply agreements by Daqo New Energy and the investments in new solar cell factories indicate potential growth and demand in the PV market. These developments should be closely monitored to assess their impact on future polysilicon prices./n

The introduction of industrial silicon futures trading on the Guangzhou Futures Exchange by the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) is seen as a reaction to the surge in silicon metal prices in the third quarter of 2021. This move is expected to improve the risk-management capabilities of market entities, including polysilicon manufacturers who can now hedge against fluctuating silicon metal prices.  In terms of company developments, Longi, a major player in the PV market, has lowered its wafer prices. This could potentially have an impact on the overall polysilicon market. Additionally, JA Solar has announced plans to invest in a new 10 GW solar cell factory, indicating continued growth in the PV market.  Furthermore, polysilicon producer Daqo New Energy has signed multiple supply agreements with LONGi and an undisclosed Chinese manufacturer. These agreements involve the supply of high-purity mono-grade polysilicon over several years. The prices will be negotiated monthly based on market conditions. Daqo New Energy has been experiencing strong demand for its polysilicon, leading to better-than-expected performance and increased production guidance.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices are expected to decline in the coming months, driven by factors such as inventory levels and market dynamics. However, caution is advised regarding the extent of the price decrease, particularly in the first half of 2023. The introduction of industrial silicon futures trading and the signing of supply agreements by major players in the industry also indicate ongoing developments and growth in the PV market./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices.   Firstly, the introduction of industrial silicon futures on the Guangzhou Futures Exchange by the CSRC aims to improve the pricing mechanism for industrial silicon. This move could potentially allow polysilicon manufacturers to hedge against fluctuating silicon metal prices, which could impact the overall polysilicon market.  Secondly, PV InfoLink predicts a distinctive downward trend in polysilicon prices, following months of high prices. They expect prices to fall significantly from the end of November into early December. This could be attributed to the first decline in polysilicon inventory in two years, indicating an unhealthy inventory in the sector. However, it is important to note that polysilicon prices have already stabilized at high levels, and any decrease may only be a seasonal drop at year-end.  Additionally, the signing of polysilicon supply agreements by Daqo New Energy with LONGi and an undisclosed Chinese manufacturer could also impact future prices. These agreements involve negotiated prices based on market conditions, indicating that the prices will be subject to change. Daqo New Energy has also increased its annual polysilicon production guidance, which could potentially affect the overall supply and demand dynamics in the market.  Furthermore, the expansion of polysilicon production capacity by companies like Jiangsu Sunshine Group and Qingdao Gaoce could also have an impact on future prices. Increased production capacity could potentially lead to a higher supply of polysilicon, which could put downward pressure on prices.  Overall, the combination of factors such as the introduction of industrial silicon futures, the downward trend in polysilicon prices, supply agreements, and the expansion of production capacity could all contribute to the future prices of polysilicon. It is important for stakeholders in the polysilicon market, particularly in China, to closely monitor these developments and make strategic decisions accordingly./n

According to recent news, polysilicon prices have been experiencing a downward trend after months of high prices. PV InfoLink predicts a significant fall in prices from the end of November into early December. This decline is attributed to a slight reduction in demand at the end of the year and the increasing capacity of the Chinese polysilicon industry. The China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association (CNMIA) reports that the average price of polysilicon has fallen by more than 42% compared to the peak registered in November. The CNMIA attributes this decline to the increasing capacity of the Chinese polysilicon industry and a slight demand reduction at the end of the year. It estimates that China's domestic polysilicon capacity will reach 2.4 million metric tons by the end of 2023.  In terms of future developments, the introduction of industrial silicon futures on the Guangzhou Futures Exchange is expected to provide polysilicon manufacturers with the opportunity to hedge against fluctuating silicon metal prices. However, polysilicon prices have already stabilized at high levels, and any further decrease is expected to be the usual seasonal drop at year-end. Polysilicon analyst Johannes Bernreuter remains cautious about a stronger decrease in prices for the first half of 2023.  In terms of industry expansion, several companies have announced plans to increase their polysilicon production capacity. Jiangsu Sunshine Group plans to build a high-purity polysilicon facility with an annual output of 100,000 tons and another facility with an annual output of 10 GW wafers, cells, and modules. Qingdao Gaoce Technology plans to invest in a 5 GW photovoltaic large silicon wafer project to alleviate its shortage of slicing production capacity. Shuangliang Eco-Energy is also planning to invest in a mono silicon ingot pulling project with an annual output of 50 GW.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices are experiencing a downward trend due to a combination of factors such as increasing capacity, slight demand reduction, and the introduction of industrial silicon futures. However, the stabilization of prices at high levels and cautious forecasts for the first half of 2023 indicate that significant price decreases may not be expected in the near future. The expansion of polysilicon production capacity by various companies also indicates the industry's confidence in future demand and the potential for growth in the PV market./n

According to recent updates from the CNMIA (China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association), polysilicon prices have experienced a significant decline. The average price of monocrystalline silicon has fallen by more than 42% since its peak in November, ranging from CNY 148/kg to CNY 182/kg. Similarly, polycrystalline silicon prices have dropped to between CNY 145/kg and CNY 177/kg. This decline can be attributed to a slight reduction in demand towards the end of the year and the increasing capacity of the Chinese polysilicon industry.  The CNMIA estimates that China's domestic polysilicon capacity will reach 1.2 million metric tons (MT) by the end of 2022 and is projected to reach 2.4 million MT by the end of 2023. This increase in capacity further contributes to the downward pressure on polysilicon prices.  In addition to the domestic market factors, there are global trends that impact polysilicon prices. Countries worldwide are emphasizing domestic PV manufacturing and supply, driven by factors such as energy independence, increasing international demand for solar PV, and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) considerations. For instance, the US has implemented the Inflation Reduction Act to incentivize domestic manufacturing, the European Solar PV Industry Alliance was recently launched, and India has set a target of 65GW for domestic manufacturing.  Furthermore, the recent decline in polysilicon prices is also influenced by the oversupply of solar wafers. China alone produced around 329GW of wafers, with an additional 10GW produced elsewhere. This excess production has led to a 27% decrease in 182mm M10 monocrystalline wafer prices between mid-November and December 21, according to Bernreuter Research. As a result, polysilicon prices have fallen by 39% in the same period.  The downward trend in polysilicon prices is expected to continue until the Chinese New Year. However, as surplus inventories are depleted and downstream manufacturers need to replenish stock, the price collapse is likely to stabilize. This stabilization is predicted to occur by the end of the month.  It is worth noting that the decline in polysilicon prices may lead to challenges for tier-two and tier-three manufacturers, as the price gap between tier-one companies and others widens. Some manufacturers may need to cut production and struggle to fulfill orders due to the low prices.  Overall, the current news suggests that polysilicon prices are experiencing a significant decline due to factors such as oversupply, increasing domestic capacity, and global trends towards domestic PV manufacturing. These developments have a significant impact on the future prices of polysilicon, and strategic decisions in the Chinese market should consider these trends and their potential implications./n

According to recent updates from the CNMIA (China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association), the prices of polysilicon have experienced a significant decline. The current prices for monocrystalline silicon range from CNY 148/kg to CNY 182/kg, while polycrystalline silicon prices are between CNY 145/kg and CNY 177/kg. This represents a decrease of more than 42% compared to the peak prices registered in November.  The CNINA attributes this decline to a slight reduction in demand towards the end of the year and the increasing capacity of the Chinese polysilicon industry. It estimates that China's domestic polysilicon capacity reached 1.2 million metric tons (MT) by the end of 2022 and is projected to reach 2.4 million MT by the end of 2023.  Furthermore, recent data from EnergyTrend and Shanghai Metals Market indicate that the downward trend in polysilicon prices is expected to continue, at least until the Chinese New Year. As of 4 January, the average spot price of mono-grade dense polysilicon was RMB175/kg (US$25.54), which dropped to RMB150-165/kg (US$21.89-24.08) on 6 January. This represents a significant decrease from the average price of RMB223.4 (US$32.60) observed in late December 2022.  Despite the price decline, polysilicon supply and production have continued to increase, according to research firm InfoLink. However, the falling prices may lead to a situation where much of the supply remains unused as buyers wait for more favorable prices, potentially resulting in a depreciation of inventory. Additionally, InfoLink suggests that tier-two and tier-three manufacturers may struggle to fulfill orders and cut production due to the widening price gap between tier-one companies and others.  The decline in polysilicon prices can be attributed to an excess supply of solar wafers. China alone produced around 329GW of wafers, with an estimated additional 10GW of production elsewhere. This excess production led to a 27% decrease in 182mm M10 monocrystalline wafer prices between mid-November and 21 December, which further contributed to the decline in polysilicon prices.  In terms of government subsidies and agreements, SPIC Inner Mongolia Energy Group and Urad Middle Banner in Inner Mongolia have entered into a framework agreement for a demonstration project of Ganqimaodu Port. This agreement includes cooperation on 5 GW new energy, 200,000-ton polysilicon, and 300,000-ton industrial silicon projects, with a contract value of RMB 61.06 billion.  Longi Solar, a major player in the industry, has announced plans to invest CNY 42.5 billion to more than double its PV wafer and cell capacity. The company aims to build new wafer and cell factories, with construction expected to be completed within 18 months. Longi expects the factories to be commissioned by 2025, creating over 15,000 jobs. These expansions in capacity indicate the company's confidence in the future demand for polysilicon and its commitment to meeting that demand.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices have experienced a significant decline due to factors such as reduced demand, increasing capacity, and excess production of solar wafers. The downward trend is expected to continue in the coming months, at least until the Chinese New Year. This may lead to supply sitting dormant as buyers wait for more favorable prices, potentially impacting tier-two and tier-three manufacturers. However, government subsidies and agreements, as well as investments by major companies like Longi Solar, indicate a positive outlook for the future of the polysilicon market./n

According to recent updates from the CNMIA, the prices of polysilicon in China have experienced a significant decline. The prices for monocrystalline silicon currently range from CNY 148/kg to CNY 182/kg, while polycrystalline silicon prices are between CNY 145/kg and CNY 177/kg. This represents a decrease of more than 42% compared to the peak prices registered in November. The decline in prices is attributed to a slight reduction in demand at the end of the year and the increasing capacity of the Chinese polysilicon industry.  The CNINA estimates that China's domestic polysilicon capacity reached 1.2 million metric tons (MT) by the end of 2022 and is expected to reach 2.4 million MT by the end of 2023. This increase in capacity is likely to have contributed to the decline in prices. Additionally, the recent aggressive decrease in prices can be attributed to inventory clearances at the end of the year and a temporary lull in demand.  The decline in polysilicon prices is expected to taper off in the coming weeks, but further, more modest declines are anticipated later in the year. However, for U.S. module buyers, there is a risk that the price declines for polysilicon will be muted due to the requirement to use polysilicon produced outside of China to comply with UFLPA enforcement. The price gap between China and non-China polysilicon has been approximately 5-10%, but it may now be growing as Chinese polysilicon prices decline.  The shift to TOPCon technology in China is also underway, which may further impact polysilicon prices. Wafer manufacturers have started reducing their utilization rates to deplete surplus inventories, which could alleviate the pressure on wafer prices. The lunar new year holiday in China is expected to temporarily ease production, reducing demand for polysilicon. However, as surplus diminishes and downstream manufacturers need to replenish stock, the price collapse is likely to end.  Overall, the news indicates a significant decline in polysilicon prices due to factors such as increased Chinese polysilicon production, inventory clearances, and a temporary reduction in demand. The decline is expected to continue until the Chinese new year, with further declines anticipated later in the year. The shift to TOPCon technology and the requirement for U.S. module buyers to use non-China polysilicon may also impact prices./n

According to recent news, polysilicon prices have been on the rise since the beginning of the year after a period of decline in the latter months of 2022. Monocrystalline silicon is currently selling at an average price of CNY 217.5 ($32.30)/kg, which is 31.02% higher than the levels registered in mid-January. Polycrystalline silicon is being priced at an average of CNY 215.2/kg, up 31.22% from mid-January.  The increase in prices can be attributed to the fact that wafer manufacturers in China returned to high operation rates after the new year holiday in order to handle downstream orders. This led to a quick consumption of all polysilicon in stock, resulting in a tense supply situation and higher prices.  In addition to the supply and demand dynamics in China, there are other factors that could impact polysilicon prices in the future. One such factor is the expansion of global solar production, with a focus on highly efficient n-type technologies. This expansion is expected to drive down future polysilicon prices due to significant new production capacity.  Furthermore, there is a potential price war between companies producing polysilicon, particularly between Chinese and non-Chinese producers. The price gap between Chinese and non-Chinese polysilicon has been approximately 5-10%, but it may now be growing as Chinese polysilicon prices decline. This could have implications for U.S. module buyers who may be required to use non-China polysilicon to comply with UFLPA enforcement.  Government subsidies and geopolitical conflicts can also have an impact on polysilicon prices. Government subsidies can incentivize the production and use of polysilicon, while geopolitical conflicts can disrupt supply chains and lead to price fluctuations.  Overall, while polysilicon prices have been on the rise recently, there are several factors that could influence future prices. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon market to closely monitor news related to polysilicon inventory, price wars between companies, government subsidies, and geopolitical conflicts in order to make informed decisions./n

According to recent news, the polysilicon market is experiencing a drop in prices due to changes in supply and demand. Wafer companies, which previously faced shortages of polysilicon, are now tapping into their inventory as polysilicon makers increase their capacity. This combination of factors has contributed to the recent plummet in polysilicon prices. Additionally, the rapid loosening of China's anti-pandemic policies has accelerated the release of supplies. However, industry professionals and analysts believe that polysilicon prices will rebound and stabilize in the long term, as polysilicon manufacturers still have power over pricing compared to wafer and cell production capacities.  On the other hand, recent reports indicate that polysilicon prices have increased since the start of the year. Monocrystalline silicon is currently selling at an average price of CNY 217.5 ($32.30)/kg, while polycrystalline silicon is priced at an average of CNY 215.2/kg. This increase in prices can be attributed to the high operation rates of wafer manufacturers after China's recent new year holiday, leading to a tense supply situation.  In terms of future developments, Trina Solar and SUMEC Engineering have signed a memorandum of understanding to strengthen their cooperation in Southeast Asian markets. Trina Solar will be supplying all the solar modules required for SUMEC's 159 MW solar project in the Philippines. Additionally, Tongwei has announced plans to set up a 120,000-ton high-purity crystalline silicon project in China's Sichuan province, which is expected to start construction by the end of June 2023. These developments indicate continued growth and investment in the polysilicon market.  Overall, while there has been a recent drop in polysilicon prices, industry experts believe that prices will rebound and stabilize in the long term. Factors such as changes in supply and demand, government policies, and industry partnerships will continue to shape the future of the polysilicon market./n

According to recent news, four Chinese polysilicon manufacturers, GCL Technology, Xinte Energy, Tongwei, and Daquan Energy, have reported increased net profits due to increased sales or short supply. GCL Technology expects its net profit in 2022 to be at least RMB15.5 billion, with a year-on-year growth of at least 204%. Xinte Energy forecasts a net profit of no less than RMB13 billion, increasing by more than 162% from the previous year. Tongwei is expected to achieve a net profit growth of 207% - 231%, while Daquan Energy anticipates a year-on-year growth of 231.94% - 235.44%.  The increased profits are attributed to the booming PV industry globally, with polysilicon products experiencing short supply and rising demand and prices. Granular silicon has been the most beneficial among all types. Tongwei's high-purity silicon production line operating at full capacity and new projects being put into immediate production have contributed to their volume and profit surge. Daquan Energy noted that capacity growth in other links of the PV industry and high-purity polysilicon being in short supply have led to increased silicon prices.  However, despite the increased prices benefiting Chinese manufacturers, data from the Silicon Industry Branch shows that the price of polysilicon has fallen since November 2022. Although the price stabilized in mid-January, it began to rise again. The branch also predicts that China's polysilicon output will reach about 1.35 million tons in 2023.  In addition to the Chinese market, global trade disputes have also affected the polysilicon supply and demand balance. After 18 months of tight supply and skyrocketing prices, the early weeks of 2023 saw a dramatic recalibration of polysilicon markets, with prices falling 55% from December 2022 to US$18/kg. This plunge was driven by a massive wave of capacity additions in China, with Chinese polysilicon supply forecasted to nearly double in 2023.  However, there has been a whiplash increase in poly prices of upwards of 30% following a meeting of Chinese polysilicon makers. This volatility in pricing during the first quarter of the year may prompt additional governmental engagement to limit price gouging. Despite the recent price fluctuations, industry professionals and analysts believe that polysilicon prices will stabilize at around 100-130RMB/kg over the long term.  Overall, the news highlights the impact of supply and demand dynamics, capacity additions in China, and government interventions on polysilicon prices. It also emphasizes the importance of monitoring global trade disputes and geopolitical conflicts that can further influence the polysilicon market./n
