The global polysilicon market has experienced a significant shift in supply and demand dynamics, leading to a dramatic drop in prices. After 18 months of tight supply and soaring prices, the early weeks of 2023 saw a recalibration of the market, with polysilicon prices falling by 55% from December 2022 to US$18/kg. This plunge in pricing was driven by a wave of capacity additions in China, which is forecasted to nearly double its polysilicon supply in 2023.  However, the market pricing quickly reversed course following a meeting of Chinese polysilicon manufacturers, resulting in a sudden increase in prices by upwards of 30%. While the first quarter of the year is typically volatile for materials pricing, this increase may prompt additional government intervention to limit price gouging. Government action has been minimal thus far, but there have been notices provided to polysilicon manufacturers in 2022 to control pricing and avoid disrupting PV module prices.  The drop in polysilicon prices can be attributed to various factors. Businesses that had hoarded polysilicon for one or two quarters are now tapping into their inventory, while polysilicon makers have rushed to ramp up capacity. The loosening of China's anti-pandemic policies has also accelerated the release of supplies. As wafer makers reduce their stockpiles, prices are expected to balance out and remain at a reasonable level. However, polysilicon manufacturers are not motivated to further depreciate costs, as they still have power over pricing compared to larger wafer and cell production capacities.  It is worth noting that China's share of global solar-grade polysilicon output has been increasing, reaching 88% in 2022. This is a result of China ramping up new production capacities to address a severe polysilicon shortage in 2021. As China continues to expand its domestic capacity, the future of non-Chinese polysilicon feedstock may lie outside of China.  Overall, the news highlights the volatility and complexity of the polysilicon market, with factors such as capacity additions, government intervention, and geopolitical conflicts playing a significant role in shaping future prices. Strategic decisions in the polysilicon market should consider these factors and closely monitor supply and market conditions to navigate potential risks and opportunities./n

According to recent news, four Chinese polysilicon manufacturers, GCL Technology, Xinte Energy, Tongwei, and Daquan Energy, have reported increased net profits due to increased sales or short supply. GCL Technology expects its net profit in 2022 to be at least RMB15.5 billion, with a year-on-year growth of at least 204%. Xinte Energy forecasts a net profit of no less than RMB13 billion, increasing by more than 162% from the previous year. Tongwei is expected to achieve a net profit growth of 207% - 231%, while Daquan Energy anticipates a year-on-year growth of 231.94% - 235.44%.  The increased profits are attributed to the booming PV industry globally, with polysilicon products experiencing short supply and rising demand and prices. Granular silicon has been the most beneficial among all types. Tongwei's high-purity silicon production line operating at full capacity and new projects being put into immediate production have contributed to their surge in volume and profit. Daquan Energy noted that capacity growth in other links of the PV industry and high-purity polysilicon being in short supply have led to increased silicon prices.  However, despite the increased prices benefiting Chinese manufacturers, data from the Silicon Industry Branch shows that the price of polysilicon has fallen since November 2022. Although the price stabilized in mid-January, it began to rise again. The branch also predicts that China's polysilicon output will reach about 1.35 million tons in 2023.  In addition to the Chinese market, global trade disputes have also impacted the polysilicon supply and demand balance. After 18 months of tight supply and skyrocketing prices, the early weeks of 2023 saw a dramatic recalibration of polysilicon markets, with prices falling 55% from December 2022 to US$18/kg. This plunge was driven by a massive wave of capacity additions in China, with Chinese polysilicon supply forecasted to nearly double in 2023.  However, there has been a whiplash increase in poly prices of upwards of 30% following a meeting of Chinese polysilicon makers. This volatility in pricing during the first quarter of the year may prompt additional governmental engagement to limit price gouging. Despite the recent price fluctuations, industry professionals and analysts believe that polysilicon prices will stabilize at around 100-130RMB/kg over the long-term, as polysilicon manufacturers still have power over pricing compared to larger wafer and cell production capacities.  Overall, the news highlights the impact of supply and demand dynamics, capacity additions in China, and government interventions on polysilicon prices. While Chinese manufacturers have seen increased profits due to rising prices, the market has experienced fluctuations and is expected to stabilize in the long run./n

According to recent news, several Chinese polysilicon manufacturers have reported increased net profits due to increased sales or short supply. GCL Technology expects its net profit for 2022 to be at least RMB15.5 billion, with a year-on-year growth of at least 204%. Xinte Energy forecasts a net profit of no less than RMB13 billion, increasing by over 162% from the previous year. Tongwei is expected to achieve a net profit growth of 207% to 231% in 2022, while Daquan Energy anticipates a year-on-year growth of 231.94% to 235.44%.  The increased profits are attributed to the booming PV industry globally, with polysilicon products experiencing high demand and rising prices. Granular silicon has been particularly beneficial. Tongwei's high-purity silicon production line operating at full capacity and the implementation of new projects have contributed to their surge in volume and profit. Daquan Energy noted that capacity growth in other links of the PV industry has accelerated, leading to increased silicon prices.  However, despite the recent price increase, polysilicon prices have fallen since November, although they stabilized in mid-January and began rising again. The Silicon Industry Branch reported that China's polysilicon output is expected to reach about 1.35 million tons in 2023, thanks to companies' capacity expansion.  Furthermore, China's share of global solar-grade polysilicon output has increased to 88% in 2022, up from 82% in 2021 and 55% in 2017. This is due to China's ramping up of new production capacities after a severe polysilicon shortage in 2021. As a result, polysilicon imports into China are expected to shrink further, and the future of non-Chinese polysilicon feedstock lies outside China.  The China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association's silicon branch has reported that polysilicon prices rose after the Chinese lunar year and are expected to remain at current levels for a relatively long period. This is due to increasing demand from wafer manufacturers. The recent drop in polysilicon prices is considered a temporary phenomenon, and a long-term price rebound is expected in the first half of the year before new polysilicon plants go online.  In response to the increase in upstream polysilicon prices, Longi, a solar manufacturer, has raised the prices of its wafer products. This adjustment is necessary to align with the market./n

According to recent news, polysilicon producer Daqo New Energy has reported record revenue of US$4.6 billion in 2022, with a gross profit of US$3.4 billion. This increase in revenue and profit is attributed to higher polysilicon average selling prices (ASP). The company expects polysilicon prices to remain above RMB220/kg during Q1 2023, with prices ranging between RMB210-250/kg until mid-year. However, prices are expected to decrease in Q3 to RMB150-200/kg. Daqo is also expanding its polysilicon production in Inner Mongolia, with Phase 5A expected to reach full capacity by June 2023 and Phase 5B construction starting in March 2023.  In terms of sales volume, Daqo experienced a slowdown in Q4 2022 compared to Q3, with sales dropping to 23,400MT. However, this is still double the sales volume in Q4 2021. Polysilicon production volume in Q4 was 33,702MT, slightly higher than Q3. For the full year of 2022, Daqo produced 133,812MT of polysilicon, exceeding its estimates. The company expects to produce 31,000-32,000MT in Q1 2023 and a total production of 190,000-195,000MT for the year.  The ASP for polysilicon in 2022 increased by 50% to US$32.54/kg from US$21.76/kg in 2021, driven by high demand for solar PV products globally. However, the production cost also increased to US$7.69/kg in Q4 2022 from US$6.82/kg in the previous quarter.  In other news, Wuxi Autowell Technology has won a bid to supply equipment for LONGi's wafer sorter, cell, and module production project. This is expected to have a positive influence on Wuxi Autowell's operating performance in 2024. Additionally, LONGi has released its latest silicon wafer guidance, indicating that silicon wafer prices have remained the same.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices have stabilized after a significant drop prior to Chinese New Year. Prices are expected to remain relatively high in the first half of 2023 before decreasing in the third quarter. The expansion of polysilicon production and supply agreements with various manufacturers indicate a positive outlook for Daqo. However, the slowdown in sales volume in Q4 2022 and the increase in production costs may pose challenges for the company. The bid won by Wuxi Autowell and the stable silicon wafer prices from LONGi also contribute to the overall market dynamics./n

Based on the news articles, there are several factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market.  Firstly, the Chinese Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT) reported that China's production of polysilicon has increased by over 60% annually, reaching a total of about 176,000 tons in the first two months of 2023. This increase in production has led to a decline in prices, with the price range of monocrystalline compact materials being around RMB 220,000/ton to RMB 244,000/ton. This indicates that the oversupply of polysilicon in the market could put downward pressure on prices.  Additionally, the China Photovoltaic Industry Association (CPIA) reported that China's exports of silicon wafers, cells, and modules have experienced both growth and decline. In January and February 2023, exports grew by 22% annually, but experienced a 4.0% drop in February. This fluctuation in exports could impact the demand for polysilicon and subsequently affect prices.  Furthermore, the news article mentions that the capacity for module production in China could exceed 1,000 GW per year, while installations are expected to be near 500 GW. This increase in capacity could lead to a tripling of polysilicon capacity from 2022 to 2024. The expansion of production capacity could potentially lead to a further oversupply of polysilicon in the market, which could drive prices down.  It is also worth noting that the price of silicon materials, including mono recharging chips and mono-grade dense polysilicon, has been declining. The average trading price for these materials has decreased by around 2.63% to 2.66% in the week beginning March 20, 2023. This decline in prices could be attributed to companies not placing new orders and the operating rate of wafer enterprises reaching a relatively high level. The supply-demand relationship and the presence of high-priced orders that were removed from the weighted average system have contributed to the downward trend in prices.  In conclusion, the increase in polysilicon production, fluctuating exports, expanding module production capacity, and declining prices of silicon materials all suggest that there could be downward pressure on future polysilicon prices in the China and global PV market. These factors indicate an oversupply of polysilicon, which could impact the profitability of polysilicon manufacturers and potentially lead to a price war between companies. Additionally, government subsidies and geopolitical conflicts could further influence the market dynamics and prices of polysilicon./n

Based on the news related to polysilicon, there are several factors that could have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices in China and the global PV market.  Firstly, the Chinese Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT) reported that China produced over 60% more polysilicon annually during the first two months of 2023 compared to the previous year. This increase in production could potentially lead to a decline in polysilicon prices due to the higher supply in the market.  Additionally, the MIIT stated that the prices of polysilicon materials and modules have declined steadily, with the price range of monocrystalline compact materials being around RMB 220,000/ton to RMB 244,000/ton. This indicates that there is already a downward trend in polysilicon prices.  Furthermore, TCL Zhonghuan, a leading solar wafer supplier, has announced a decrease in silicon wafer prices. This could also contribute to a potential decrease in polysilicon prices, as silicon wafers are a key component in the production of polysilicon.  On the other hand, there are also some factors that could potentially impact polysilicon prices in a different way. For example, Wuxi Autowell Technology Co., Ltd. has won a bid to supply equipment for LONGi's wafer sorter, cell, and module production project. This could have a positive influence on Wuxi Autowell's operating performance in 2024, but the impact on polysilicon prices in the upcoming months is uncertain.  Additionally, the cooperation agreement between France and China in the renewable energy sector, particularly in the solar PV industry, could have implications for the global PV market. This agreement could potentially lead to increased demand for polysilicon, which could in turn affect prices.  Overall, while there are some factors that could contribute to a potential decrease in polysilicon prices, such as increased production and decreased wafer prices, there are also factors that could impact prices in a different way, such as increased demand from cooperation agreements. It is important to closely monitor these developments and consider the overall market dynamics to make strategic decisions regarding polysilicon in the China market./n

In recent news, Daqo New Energy has announced the operational status of the first phase of its high efficiency polysilicon project in Inner Mongolia, China. This project aims to produce 100,000MT of high-purity polysilicon per year, which will increase production capacity and reduce costs for the company. This development is expected to have a significant impact on future polysilicon prices.  Additionally, Shuangliang Eco-Energy Systems has held a groundbreaking ceremony for the construction of the third phase of its mono-crystalline silicon material production project in Baotou City, Inner Mongolia, China. This project is planned to have an annual production capacity of 50GW of monocrystalline silicon material for large-scale PV solar products. It is expected to create more than 5,000 jobs and have a significant annual output value after completion. The completion of this project will likely affect the supply and demand dynamics of polysilicon in the market.  Furthermore, the Chinese Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT) has released statistical data indicating that China has produced over 60% more polysilicon annually during the first two months of 2023 compared to the previous year. This increase in production has led to a decline in polysilicon prices. The ministry also reported an increase in the production of crystalline silicon wafers and cells, reflecting a growing demand for PV components.  The recent price trends in the polysilicon market have shown a decline, with the main reasons being a balanced incremental supply and demand of silicon material and the expansion of the downstream n-type market. The increased price difference between n-type silicon and p-type silicon has contributed to the declining trend. Additionally, the newly built production capacity has led to more supply of lower quality silicon material in the market, further impacting prices.  Overall, these developments in polysilicon production, supply, and demand, as well as the expansion of downstream markets, will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon industry, particularly in China, to closely monitor these trends and adjust their strategies accordingly./n

According to recent news, GCL, a major polysilicon manufacturer, is planning to enter foreign markets with higher-priced products. This move comes as countries around the world are trying to develop their own supply chains to compete with China's solar industry. GCL is considering establishing factories in Europe, the Middle East, and BRICS countries, as the prices of polysilicon outside of China are higher, which could lead to higher profits for the company.  The demand for polysilicon has been soaring in recent years, surpassing the capacity of existing factories and causing prices to surge. However, with the commissioning of new factories, polysilicon prices are expected to fall in the second half of this year. The prices may reach as low as $10 to $13 per kilogram, compared to last year's peak of $39. The future prices are predicted to be more flexible, ranging between $17 to $20 in 2023, due to strong demand for high-quality materials. This is expected to bring the polysilicon market back to a relatively normal profit margin as the supply and demand imbalance eases.  In addition to the new capacity additions in China, the global polysilicon market has also been affected by the price war between companies. The Global Polysilicon Marker (GPM) fell to a six-week low of $37.218/kg, and the price of mono-grade polysilicon in China reached an 11-week low of CNY 189.93 ($27.58)/kg. The addition of new polysilicon manufacturers in China is expected to have an impact on international markets.  Furthermore, the availability of high-purity quartz (HPQ), which is used in the wafer manufacturing process, has also affected the polysilicon market. Low inventories and tightness in HPQ have buffered the wafer sector against the weakness in the upstream polysilicon market. The recent arrival of HPQ imports in China is expected to ease some of the manufacturing bottlenecks, but the respite may be unevenly distributed.  Overall, the news suggests that the polysilicon market is experiencing changes in supply and demand dynamics, with new capacity additions in China and the potential entry of GCL into foreign markets. These factors are expected to have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices./n

Based on the news, there are several factors that will have a significant effect on future polysilicon prices.   Firstly, GCL, a major polysilicon manufacturer, plans to enter foreign markets with higher-priced products. This indicates a shift in focus towards markets outside of China, where polysilicon prices are higher. GCL is considering establishing factories in Europe, the Middle East, and BRICS countries, which could result in profits two to three times higher than Chinese factories.  Secondly, the US government's Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) is encouraging manufacturers to establish themselves in the United States. However, the cost of building a factory in the US is still five times more expensive than in China, which may limit the impact of this policy. GCL's potential expansion into Europe and other regions may be a response to the higher costs in the US.  Thirdly, the commissioning of new polysilicon factories in China is expected to increase supply and potentially lead to lower prices. China's new polysilicon manufacturers are projected to add a total of 150 GW of polysilicon output in the third and fourth quarters of the year. This increased supply may spill over into international markets and contribute to a decrease in prices.  Additionally, the Global Polysilicon Marker (GPM) for polysilicon produced outside of China has already fallen to a six-week low. This suggests that market sentiment for the raw material has become more subdued, potentially indicating a decrease in prices.  Furthermore, the tightness in high-purity quartz (HPQ), a critical material for wafer manufacturing, has buffered the wafer sector against weakness in the upstream polysilicon market. The recent arrival of HPQ imports in China may help ease manufacturing bottlenecks, but the impact may be unevenly distributed.  Overall, the news suggests that polysilicon prices may fall in the second half of the year due to new capacity additions and increased supply. However, the demand for high-quality materials may result in more flexible prices in the future. It is important to monitor the market dynamics and consider the potential impact of geopolitical conflicts, government subsidies, and price wars between companies on polysilicon prices./n

According to recent news, the production capacity for mono-crystalline silicon wafers, cells, and modules is expected to increase in 2023. This increase in production capacity is attributed to LONGi's efforts in digital transformation and smart manufacturing development, which have helped reduce costs and improve efficiency. As a result, the prices of silicon materials in the industrial chain have returned to normal levels.  LONGi also plans to maintain a high intensity of R&D investment and technology innovation. In 2022, the company invested a significant amount in R&D, accounting for 5.54% of its operating revenue. The company has achieved a record-breaking power conversion efficiency of 26.81% for its silicon-based solar cells. Additionally, LONGi has made progress in laminated technology, although there are still technical issues to be resolved for mass production.  In terms of market expansion, LONGi aims to enter foreign markets with higher-priced products. This is in line with the global trend of countries developing their own supply chains to compete with China's solar industry. The company is considering establishing factories in partnership with local industries in Europe, the Middle East, and BRICS countries. The higher prices of polysilicon outside of China could potentially lead to higher profits from overseas factories compared to Chinese factories.  The news also mentions the recent drop in polysilicon prices. The average prices of different types of polysilicon have decreased, indicating a downward trend. This is attributed to the entry of new production capacities and the growth of silicon material output. Industry analysts predict that the overall supply of polysilicon will be sufficient and gradually become a surplus, leading to further price drops. By the end of June, silicon material prices are expected to drop to about RMB100/kg.  This downward trend in polysilicon prices will likely impact the distribution of profits in the PV industry chain. As the price of silicon materials decreases, the profits of the upstream of the industry chain may be intercepted by the wafer production price. However, as the price of silicon materials gradually stabilizes, the profits will be allocated to the middle and lower reaches of the industry chain.  Overall, the news suggests that the future polysilicon prices will be influenced by factors such as production capacity expansion, technological advancements, market expansion, and the balance between supply and demand. It is important for strategic decision-makers in the polysilicon market, particularly in China, to closely monitor these developments and adjust their strategies accordingly./n
